Mad Max is an intriguing game to review, and a tough one to succinctly assess. It captures the atmosphere of its source material very well, presenting an open world of majestic dunes and industrial wreckage, replete with anarchy, chaos and quasi-spiritual linguistic quirks. Avalanche toss players right into this turbulent land, and the game thrives in the moments where Max is jostling with War Boy raiders on the open road or tossing ignited cans of gasoline into their scrappy fortresses. But it’s also a title which seems, at some point, to have gone through significant changes (perhaps related to its delay in 2014), and some of the hastier joins around the story pacing, resource systems and progression mechanics still remain.  Befitting of a Mad Max game, the vast majority of the plot concerns Max’s tireless quest for a V8 engine. He’s forced to build a new car (with the help of the irrepressible sidekick/acolyte Chumbucket), after his famous Interceptor is stolen by a roid-abusing chap with the very Mad Max name of Scabrous Scrotus. Though this encounter leaves him bruised and bereft of car, clothes and equipment, Max does at least leave a chainsaw blade in Scrotus’ forehead for good measure. In order to piece together a vehicle worthy of Chumbucket’s ‘Magnum Opus’ moniker, Max needs to roam the dusty wastelands, scavenging scrap, trading favours with local warlords, and ramming or punching every War Boy, Buzzard or general road filth who tries to get in his way.  Pretty much everything in Mad Max is upgraded through the scrap resource (including, somewhat bizarrely, Max’s combat skills), so any of the open world activities that reward scrap are potentially worth doing. Luckily, that’s basically all of them; so unless you have a worrying compulsion to clear the entire map of icons it’s possible to almost exclusively stick to the things you enjoy. A few of the story missions will force you into owning certain upgrades or tackling specific side-areas, but this is kept in moderation.  Avalanche’s art team have done just as tremendous a job as their technical division (the game runs incredibly well even on minimum-spec PCs), creating a dozen or so desert zones that actually look distinct from one another. Red, Mojave-like scrublands border rolling dunes, which in turn become rockier, mesa-filled landscapes, or areas pocketed by vents of near-luminous sulfur. For an area of land that’s ostensibly barren, it offers a palette of bold colours and striking, post-civilisation landmarks.  Roaring through these realms in pursuit of a convoy, harpoon primed to pull wheels off escorts, War Boy boarders tumbling in your wake, and a well-aimed shotgun blast turning another wheeled foe into a spinning, combusting ball of debris, is one of Mad Max’s most exhilarating diversions. The versatile Shadow of Mordor-esque photo mode isn’t just in the game for moody shots of the desert, it’s also for snapping some of the magnificent explosions in full bloom.  The various camps, hide-aways, and ramshackle dwellings scattered across the wastes do eventually end up seeming over-familiar. For a decent while though, it’s a delight to roll up on a new location, comb it for scrap, engage in some un-gentlemanly BatMax fisticuffs with the locals, and explore whether there are any unique, handcrafted little dioramas contained with. Such encounters are only enhanced by the random events of Max’s world. You may end up having to deal with a honking patrol showing up while you’re on foot and vulnerable, or a powerful dust storm bellowing its way across the dry earth.  Of such things are the finest of Mad Max’s moments made. There are some shonkier aspects though, which aren’t gigantic problems in themselves but are amplified by being repeated across hours upon hours of playing. Max has a bit of a case of ‘Geralt movement’, where the weight of his animation will often carry him beyond the ladder, box of scrap, or weapon you’re trying to line him up with. A great many things in this game demand that you stand somewhat perfectly in front of them and hold down E (or equivalent) for a bit, so that gets rather old.  It’s also extremely aggravating to have to watch an almost-cut-scene every single time Max tips gasoline into something or refills his water canteen (effectively your back-up health potion, and probably preferable to the other options of consuming maggots and dog food). This is borderline crazy, because I’m pretty sure it all still happens in-engine. Having the game cut to black after those actions makes very little sense. If modding is ever possible, the removal of these repeat irritations must be a priority.  Though it doesn’t directly detract from a lot of the fun, Mad Max shows various signs of features being hastily changed or wrapped up before they were quite ready. The game’s opening tries to impress the importance of fuel and water for survival, when in fact those resources are now found in abundance across the wasteland (I never ran out of fuel, and having an empty canteen has no additional penalty).  Every ‘Top Dog’ mini-boss looks basically the same, attacks in the same manner (a couple do have assistance from underlings), and may even use the same voice actor. Encounters in the wasteland offer ‘intel’ on these fights, vaguely hinting at a sort of Mordor Nemesis system of particular weaknesses, but it’s obvious stuff like ‘he doesn’t like being shivved in the neck!’ The same tactics which work on all of them. Clearing minefields seems like a hold-over from a time where Max was intended to regularly use a wider selection of vehicles than the Magnum Opus. You can still collect a full set of cars, but outside of races or a sneaky plan to drop mines in front of a convoy, only the mine-clearing buggy (and attendant dog) has such a specific purpose.  Unfortunately, some of the Magnum Opus upgrades are tied to the reduction of ‘threat’ in different regions, and that can mean having to take time off from your campaign of chaos to settle into some familiar busywork. Getting the top level harpoon (the only one which can reliably yank down the most hardy ‘scarecrow’ structures dotted around the land, and one of the most hilarious weapons overall), means sniffing out a whole lot of minefields.  Some of the unlocking methodology may irritate, but the way upgrades for the Opus are handled is quite novel. Later armor and ramming options are not automatically the best way to go; they’re heavy, and become a trade-off with speed and handling. In this sense, you do actually have to design a workable car to some extent. It’s refreshing that the ‘last’ upgrade in a chain isn’t automatically superior by default, but is instead a new variable to consider.   Mad Max has its fair share of quirks and odd design decisions, but creates a sandbox of anarchic chaos that’s both wonderfully rendered and, on PC, a technical marvel. A word on the sound design too, which is just as responsible as the art design and animation for capturing the whump of explosions and jaw-breaking punches alike. There’s much to revel in. But although it’s appropriate that a game from this universe should feel like some aspects are misshapen or hastily bodged into shape to fit a grander vision, the annoyances really peel away at you over the course of a title as long as this one. Like the original 1979 film, Mad Max seems destined to be a cult classic; beloved by many, in spite of the components that appear to have been ripped out and reassembled, or otherwise abandoned to the desert basin.

An accurate simulation of life in the Australian wilderness.   Edit:  Because SOME PEOPLE are incapable of enjoying lighthearted commentary on games I happen to thoroughly enjoy, I'd like to amend this review with some form of legitimacy.  What exactly do I mean? Well, it's simple --  Mad Max  is an excellent amalgamation of tried and true, well-polished sandbox mechanics that serves as the ideal interactive tribute to the extensive Mad Max film canon. Hardly revolutionary, but by all means fun, engaging and superbly optimized.

What a surprise! The best action post-apo game since 'Rage'.The game is great on so many levels. First of all it works great (nice optimalization) ! 60 FPS as a starting point gives smoothness especially needed in car chases (btw car mechanics are cool). Incredible vistas! They are rather minimalistic in details but this is a good thing. The feeling of isolation is palpable here. Also the different color moods are fantastic! Another good thing is hand to hand combat. It's got batman's formula and It's enjoyable. The story is ok with many cool looking characters but don't expect to much. The downside is too busy map. The core of the game is grinding for scrap but with two good mechanics like driving/combat you don't mind doing so. Overall I give it 9/10 score-(if you don't like post-apo then 8/10) great fluid car-combat gameplay with beautiful scenery!

Mad Max is good enough to recommend heavily discounted, but ultimately is made for those who enjoy grinding, collecting, and achieving.   +Driving and car combat done right.  +Huge open-world map.  +Very deep level up/upgrade system for both Max and car. +Level design makes most of repetitive areas to add challenge.  +Fury....beat the ♥♥♥♥ out of warboys without button mashing! +Gameplay hooked me a few times for hours.  +Chumbucket. Starts out as annoying hunchback-clone from 300, but grows on you.   -Repetitive. Repetitive. Repetitive. Re...you get the point.  -Minefields. These really suck. Drive around semi-randomly, wait for dog to cry, exit car, press and hold E.  -No story. I mean none.  -Large green or purple dot stays on screen to denote a destination removes immersiion. We already have a map, mini-map, and green line on mini-map leading us to destination. This is an over-the-top, unnecessary dumb-down. -Superflous button-mashing; I understand the batman style melee mash, but 'Press and hold E to mash' certain chests and doors? Why, developer, why?? -Ladders: first you have to line up with them just right, press E to get on, and slowly trudge rung by rung until you make it to the top.  -'Press and hold E to collect scrap' Why the hell do we have to hold a button for no damn good reason?   7/10 Will return to Jeet's Stronghold again.

Genre - Post-Apocalyptic 3rd Person Action/RPG  I have watched the Mad Max films and really enjoyed the latest installment. When I first heard of this game I thought 'oh a movie tie in that will follow the film plot and be pretty pointless'. However, I was able to get this game on a good deal and was surprised to find this a great example of how to do a movie tie in.  You take the role of Mad Max and meet a character called Chum Bucket early on. You then spend the time together helping out allies by destroying enemy landmarks and capturing camps. As you progress you earn scrap that can be used to upgrade your car and Max himself.  You spend a lot of the game in your car, which you would expect, and the battles you have with other road users seem to work well with Harpoons and your Shotgun being essential gear.  The story itself is short and sweet, and It is in addition to the film and allows you to delve into Max's world even deeper. As you are in a fairly open world you can also compete in races, collect relics or farm scrap to your hearts desire. I plugged many hours into the game doing just that and although I have had my fill, did not manage to get all the achievements by the games end. I might be tempted to go back though at a later date.  The game isn't too difficult but adds a fair challenge at certain stages and is great fun to play. Definately in my top 5 games of 2015. Unfortunately I think it was over shadowed by Metal Gear being released at a similar time.   Now I am just hoping for a Bullet Farm DLC.

*Note: I'm almost five hours into an open world game that could potentially take 30+ hours to completely clear based on the huge map. I've sampled every different type of open world activity and have unlocked all the core 'equipment' under Max's glossary.  Let's start with what Mad Max *isn't* for those who may be looking for something specific: Mad Max is not a survival game. It has gameplay elements that sound like they would belong in a survival game like water and food scrounging, but this is an open world sandbox action game. Because it's an open world game, it's not as focused on delivering a narrative and tightly scripted action scenes as the recent 'Fury Road'.  Now let's get down to what Mad Max is. Mad Max is an excellent open world sandbox in the vein of Just Cause. I say 'sandbox' specifically because this game gives you a vast number of things to do and unleashes you upon the world to do them. Besides a few main quest goals (the story is frontloaded in the first few hours, as far as I can tell), you are given leave to plunder the wasteland while reducing the threat level presented by the big bad warlord Max is seeking to topple.  The graphics in Max's wasteland are solid and I never felt like the world was merely one big desert. This really becomes apparent when you ascend in a scouting balloon and see just how many interesting land features there are to explore. In a way it reminds me of the Fallout series, barren but interesting. The sound design, though, is the real star. Engines revving, powerful explosions, and the crack of Max's shotgun and punches really sell the brutal experience.  I can see the core gameplay loop of Max getting old if you don't particularly enjoy the activities of car combat, fighting, and exploring camps. However, I quite enjoyed the 'Arkham' style combat and the great combat racing that allows you to slow down time to execute amazing attacks against foes that scream along the roads at breakneck speeds.I think it's safe to say that if you played tons of Just Cause (the other game these devs are famous for) then you'll love this game, but if you're looking for an open world game with an involved narrative like GTA or The Witcher, you may be less excited to take your twentieth bandit camp.  I'd say Mad Max is a definitely worth a buy if you love the post apocalypse and want to spend hours tweaking a cool car, exploring camps and caves, and turning Max from a scrawny survivor into a Top Dog of the wastes (with an epic beard to match).

An open-world adventure game, full of salt, gasoline, blood, crushed metals and souls. Bitterness prevails above all of it. Still, this one is the helluva fun ride, all the way down the road.  You can finish it in 10-20 hours, going straight through quests, but that would be a waste of time, from my point of view. Like I said, the game has bitter taste, and the story line will not give you satisfaction after final screen. So I beg you: play it like open-world adventure. Don't mind major quests, until you really have to. Just get yourself a decent car, and go for exploring this land. Eroded, crumbled to dust, but still striving for survival.  Some time ago, I was really fond to Far Cry 2, which was baptized as horrid and bleak by the majority of players. But I found in Far Cry 2 one thing, for it can be loved: the driving part. Here in Mad Max, the same feeling of driving through wasteland, where there are no actual roads, only directions, and it goes 10 times better than in Far Cry 2!  Let's settle pro and contra:  + Graphics and optimization are very good parts. All is smooth and fine with that.  + Driving is the selling point. It is one of a kind experience, I suggest everyone to get at least some of it.  + Fighting part is very similar to Batman's games, or Sleeping Dogs - strike and strong strike, parry&reposte, combo... It goes fine, for the most time. Although some moves Max showing are certainly not fit the realistic setting the game's narrative assuming. But the same can be said about the whole game: the realism is here, but steps away to make some emotions brighter. Still, after about 200-300 broken jaws, it is finally not that fun, as with Bats or Wei Shen... The Shadow of Mordor gives much more contentment, than Mad Max, at this point.  + The gameplay main features certainly looks familiar. Fighting from Batman, scrap collecting and gear tuning from Tomb Raider... you can proceed with the list, but here's the main thing: it was blended alright. Unlike Watch Dogs, Mad Max gameplay is not seems like Frankenstein style. All things there at right places, so the final expression the game gives is pure. You're getting a fresh new game out of long-known features. A good deal.  - The only strong point I have against this game is amusingly overall accolade to Death. All those skulls, achievement for eating maggots nesting in the rotting corpses... All that gore is an over-act, an over-kill and exaggeration of the Apocalypse theme. I felt disgust sometimes during playtime. So I'm certainly not recommending Mad Max to kids or to sensitive persons.  - The game is open-world, but it contains almost none of any sandbox experience. After you clear the given territory from the enemy presence, there are absolutely nothing to do. So you can't play this game by hundreds of hours, like Skyrim. Unless you really like driving in wastelands over all other gaming experience, of course.  In sum: Mad Max is pure and solid action game. Very brutal, and quite entertaining for some time. You ride a death car, right in the middle with the real world and hell. And while your good deeds somehow fixing something around you, your hero goes deeper and deeper on the dark side. Very nice and very grim adventure in the post-apocalypse crack of world we used to know. Give it a go, but leave any hopes before entering.  I mark it as 7.9/10. I like it very much, but it hurts something inside me. Let's just pray we'll never see this dream come true.

By no means perfect, but a solid and entertaining game. 7 ~ 8 / 10 from me.   Pros -  1. Car combat is addictive and excellently implemented. A great many types of vehicles are in the game, and a great many tactical options to fight them. No other game has handled car-combat with such finesse.  2. The game is a must buy for Mad Max fans. The atmostphere is very faithful to the movies.  3. Customizing and upgrading your vehicle 'Magnum Opus' is a lot of fun. There many options, most of them are meaningful and open up new ways to play.  4. Production values are superb. Audio, visuals, the design and voice casting of enemies and in-game characters, all beautifully done, bring the wastelands to 'life', as much as can be possible.  5. Combat is reminiscent of Shadow of Mordor, with a bit of gun combat mixed in.  6. The wastland is pretty massive. Quite a lot of things to do in the game - car combat, capturing strongholds, improving allied bases, boss fights, even car races. A lot more than many famous open-world games.   Cons  1. Some of the missions and tasks can be a bit of a chore (eg Mine clearing).  2. Melee combat can become monotonous by the end, especially in contrast to vehicular combat. Car combat remains so much more entertaining that I sometimes avoid getting out of the car whenever possible.  3. I wish there were more settlements and characters in the game (but given the wasteland setting, I doubt there is much the devs could have done).  Overall. a definite buy at anything more than a 25% discount. One of the better movie adaptations ever produced.

Mad Max is a open world, action, post-apocalyptic, survival type game. Mad Max is a third person, action game set in an open world enviroment, based on the Mad Max film series. It was released on September 1st 2015 on PC, PS4 and XBOX One. You can explore plenty of deserts, canyons, wreckage, tunnels, hills. In the story, Max's car was stolen in wasteland by Scrotus. Then Scrotus beaten and threw him into Chumbucket's region. After few minutes Max wakes up and found Chumbucket. Then Chumbucket helps Max to build a war machine for Wasteland War. After all this, journey begins.  Mad Max featured with massive open world map. We can do several things in Wasteland. Like terminating Snipers, Camps, Stop Dogs, Scarecrows. Even we can play Death Run races. Like Time Bomb and Finish The Line. We can earn cars by winning Death Run races as reward. There are many types of cars available for our collection.  We can make better and proper progress if we play this game accordingly. There are quiet numbers of Side missions. We can earn great numbers of scraps for upgrading Magnum Opus, Max, Chumbucket, Weapons.  If you wants to upgrade everything then you have to increase your legend rank. Making progress of legend rank will unlock new upgrades for Max. Terminating Camps, Convoys, Minefields, Snipers, Scarecrows will reduce threat meter to 0 from 5. This will also unlock new upgrades for Magnum Opus.  Pros ::: 1. Realistic Graphics Quality. 2. There are few things to do in Wasteland. 3. Plenty of Side missions. 4. The fuel system and filling my cane with water is really amazing way for better focus in this game. 5. This game featured with massive open world map. 6. Highly Optimized Game. I am really impressed with it's optimization. 7. Story feels really epic and emotional. 8. Really a great style of combat with Fury Killing Ability. 9. Driving Magnum Opus feels really comfortable. 10. We can upgrade Max, Magnum Opus, Chumbucket, Strongholds.  You can rebuild strongholds by Project Parts. You have to collect Project Parts after tracking them on your map. Like if you build Scrap Crew then this Crew will collect scraps from all over the Wasteland while your game is off. But you must need Internet Connection for collecting those scraps from Crew.  You can play this game better if you upgrade your harpoon to level 6 which is max level of harpoon weapon. Also try to upgrade Max's Knucles and Jacket for his better defence.There are many types of enemy out there with upgraded in highly power. So you need best defence for Max that he can fight longer and defeat them.  This game is highly optimized. You can play this game smoothly with low mode settings in your low config. If you got Intel Core i5 with 8GB RAM and 2GB GDDR5 then you can explore Wasteland in Ultra High Settings.  Let me tell you that i am the 1st finisher of this game in Bangladesh. Like Assassin's Creed II, Assassin's Creed Revelations, Life is Strange, Tomb Raider, Metro Last Light, Deus-Ex Human Revolution. Really it's a amazing game with epic and emotional ending. The ending of this game made me so much weak. The price of this game worth it highly. So that's what i want to say about this game.

Amongst a multitude of open world games with maps littered by icons for collectibles as a substitute for gaming content,  Mad Max  does something with the genre: it turns all of these collectibles into exploration pieces. This doesn't exactly  solve  the problem; exploring over a hundred of tiny settlements becomes as tedious as hunting down a hundred of other collectibles, but it does turn what would be a collectathon into a series of adventures and the resulting product is that much richer for it.  Mad Max is at its best whenever it turns into a dungeon crawler in post-apocalyptic Australia. Imagine  Middle-Earth: Shadows of Mordor  where instead of gaining intel on orc warlords you gain intel to take down enemy bases. Scout enemy camps from afar before taking out their perimeter defenses in your V6 engine car, then battle it out inside while seeking treasure troves of metal scraps.  The features are what sets Mad Max apart from other games. There are definite improvements to the traditional Batman-style melee while car combat has a range of over-the-top special attacks such as the harpoon slam, drive-by shootings, THUNDERPOONS and flaming jets of incineration. Meanwhile, the weakness in the main story actually made me wistful for the  Assassin's Creed  franchise! Say what you will about their game balance; you knew absurd action hero ♥♥♥♥ was gonna go down the minute you accepted that Story Mission! Here it's the opposite: Story Missions are quite tame and most of the value comes from investigating non-essential camps and hunting down enemy convoys.  One must enjoy the greater changes Mad Max brings to the genre if they are to appreciate their purchase. This could've just as easily been a negative review if I nitpicked every little thing that went wrong: Top Dog bosses follow identical patterns, the vehicles you collect from the enemy serve no purpose, ditto the archangel 'alternative car builds', some cars are deliberately rendered hard to maneuver as artificial difficulty, the greatest threat to your lifebar is an impromptu event against which you are completely helpless (OH NO, A MIGHTY DUSTER!), same ol' chore list of tasks to do ('kill 20 enemies with wall finishers.' No, stop adding those), not to mention the glaring elephant in the room:   you are STILL searching for collectibles!   They're just properly hidden as part of your (side-) adventure rather than showcased on a map, so you end up longing for those traditional map icons whenever you're stuck searching for that one final object and be done with a particular encampment!  Most games have you seek out upgrades in side quests, Mad Max makes upgrading your V6 engine into a V8 the main plot of the game. It's true! You get your car stolen in the opening, you vow vengeance, you find a substitute which you'll upgrade with better wheels, armor and such but ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ if Max Rockastansky is gonna drive anything with less than 8 cylinders of pure power! This is literally 'Upgrades: the Game'. Assault the various strongholds of Scabrous Scrotous to unlock upgrades, collect piles of scrap to pay for upgrades, perform feats of daring-do (or kill 20 enemies with wall finishers) for character upgrades. This is...  'pure extract of open world game' . Mind you; the upgrades are indeed wonderful, but there should be more to games than just upgrades. I don't want to play the world's most skillful scrap collector.  There's just so much good in this game for it to warrant a Thumbs Down, despite my numerous gripes. However, I obviously cannot recommend this to anyone burnt out on open world games at the risk of seeing them puke map icons. Important: check your system requirements before purchasing as this game actually caused my computer to overheat when played at its highest graphical settings. If you're still on the fence, consider watching a few Let's Plays. I promise it won't spoil the story.  REVIEW SLIGHTLY EDITED FOR LENGTH

The car combat is fun and i thrilling, there is nothing more satisfying than ripping enemy driver out of their car with the harpoon gun.   The hand to hand combat is reminiscent of Shadow of Mordor and the Batman games, i know not everyone likes that style of combat but i think it fits very well into this style of game.  I love richness of the upgrade system for the car, aswell as the items and clothing that you can unlock for Max himself.  Cons:  To be completely honest i haven't found anything that i dislike in the game as of yet. In certain open world games i get tired of the hugeness of the maps but by having the car to travel around in its not like it takes you that long to get you from A to B and engage in some vehicle combat inbetween.  Overall i am thoroughly enjoying it so far. In my opinion i feel its a shame that it was released on the same day as MGSV as i feel that a lot of people will play that first and probably try and pick this up later on in the year.

All I remember of Mad Max was a dusty Mel Gibson, a big bad car, and feeling a connection to the desperate wanderers he came across. In a way, it's one of the first apocalyptic worlds I'd ever seen. It has it's appeal. Thunderdome and Tina Turner with the crazies and bloodlust. These days it's all post-apocalyptic hell with zombies, so seeing a wasteland in a new but familiar universe of Mad Max wasn't hard to process and a nice change for all the end-of-the-world-ness in games I see.  Well then, what's it all about? Giant open world areas, some fun car caravan takedowns, the usual batman-eque fighting, using a fast car to destroy stuff, and mostly enjoying the world of Mad Max in a video game. A first I thought, 'Ok, Batman-junior with a car. Not bad'. There is a fervor in the knuckle-fighting that is Max. It's not a precise brawler, yet not a hack n slash either. I couldn't really stop, though. Insert coin, get video game fast food adrenaline rush. My goal was to try and take them all down without firing a shot, that made the fights extra edgy.   The fun bit for *me*, though....the open world car takedowns. And this varies from gamer to gamer because some folks dislike open world. Personally, I just dive in and forget to actually play the missions. After playing for a few hours I left the main campaign and drove around the open world leveling up for 20+ hrs. Then I got back to the campaign all uber-leveled with a wonderfully growling car only to find I could not get to the next mission. I wasted about an hour or more trying to get it to work. Finally, I gave up and looked online. I found I had to level *down* my car to get to the next mission. What is up with that? At least give me a hint, but to keep it completely out of the mission description? Weird. Why bother making an open world if you need a linear leveling playthrough? So, *that* kinda stunk.  Next up was learning to attack cars, gates, and snipers with my grapple hook. Soon to be upgraded to a THUNDERPOON. Yep, it's called a THUNDERPOON. Basically having a lightweight RPG gunner in the back of your car. Sweet. But I preferred the grapple personally. Maybe it's more batman-ish, but I enjoyed aiming it at tires and stopping bad guys with a hook to the chest. Pooning was a bit too easy and I only used it for aiming at gas tanks at camps. Some of those camps had several flame inducing gas tanks, snipers in tight areas, and defense towers made of shooting fireballs. These were a great joy to attack. That was the best part really. Once you got past the defenses, you crack some heads until you get to a mini-boss with minions and usually giant blazing stationary flamethowers. I ran my bosses into those as a fast way to finish. The problem? ALL the mini-bosses were like that. It got old after awhile. Even down to the last side mission, it was all the same attack, evade, attack. Not much to it. Makes me scratch my head how come they didn't add some variety to the bosses. It would have added so much more to the game if *any* of them had some special abilities.  Now I loved the driving and chasing the bad guy on their supply routes. It was sorta GTA style and even though the car was hard to maneuver I never got tired of it. You can add more armor and stabilizers to get better handling, but I found the armor slowed me down. Better to stay light to keep up. Unless you skid out of control and end up in a ditch. But, the car could take a good beating. The death runs were okay and just required a bit of practice to remember where to slow down and speed up. Using nitro was also a good help on a straight path with it's fast speed boost, but in general made me lose total control if I made any sort of turn. What NAILED me was the race against Stank Gum. It was there - after a bajillion attempts - that i realized i had too much armor and needed to lighten up the car to keep up. Once I did that, i was able to complete the mission with just a handful of tries. That can be the hardest part of the game, or the easiest. Depends how good you are at driving games and how heavy your car is when you start.  Right around that part of the game, the story *finally* gets interesting. Before, it was mostly summer-movie-story-action filler. But towards the last 15% of the game the story makes some good progress. Which is great because after awhile I would just get bored and chat with my buddies on steam or watch twitch while I played 10 minutes every hr.  Some nights I'd play maybe 20 minutes with the game running all night long. I was losing my interest pretty bad. Past the Stank Gum mission, though, you may finish the game a little faster because it's getting more varied as you go. I will say the end mission is pretty decent and I felt like it was a good ending. I'm not going to spoil it, but that ending was a lot better than say the ending to Shadow of Mordor. I had to play the Bright Lord DLC to get a good ending to Mordor - which is a shame because I *loved* Mordor other than that ending. Mad Max ends well and becomes a decent game towards the last 15% of the campaign.  Story isn't much, but it's voice acted well and frankly I liked the storyline more than the movie. That isn't saying much because the movie was mostly an action packed sequence with little dialogue going on ( in my opinion ). But the game has a lot more going on. What it *is* missing is the connection to the people surviving out there in the vast dry death of a world Max lives in. You get some connections here and there, but mostly you bounce from camp to camp and just do missions without really talking to anyone. Where is the love? Max is a loner, I get it. But, wow, there wasn't anything even close to a personal experience until the end.   Art direction is a gritty gorgeous wasteland. A perfect Mad Max open world with quite a lot of detailed landscape and nicely working physics. I got into it. Maybe I'm a loner too, who knows, but it appealed to me. At least until I finished and decided I need to move on to my backlog again. Lemme drive all over and smash into bad guy cars. I loved that.  One more thing towards the end - and here I will be critical - it gets more and more glitchy. A few scenes had my car inside of another car, I drove all the way to the end of a mission only to get stuck on geometry for 15 minutes while i wiggled everything possible, and the occasional cutscene where the person's head disappeared. But my biggest gripe was the last side quest. Someone decided to make it only work *at night*.  I could not fast forward time! I tried upgrading the camps with scrap metal which seems to fast forward time a bit, but it would miss the nighttime somehow. So, i drove around for over 2 hrs until I got to a night scene in order to finish the game sidequests. That was *so* annoying. Somebody got cut a check for that idea. Arrgh. Please WB, it's *not* fun or challenging. *Don't* do that again.  Overall, a solid entry. Nothing spectacular, but it has it's good points if you enjoy driving recklessly beating up brighly painted shirtless dudes in an open world. Amazing? Nope. Bad ♥♥♥? Nope. Worth the time? Um, yeah, as long as you like the above statement on driving and don't expect much variety in the bosses. Plus, you get to be Mad Max! 7/10.

It is a hell of a ride.   The game is definitely more than the sum of its parts, and it can be pretty rough in some parts, but man, what a damn ride.  The game's on foot combat is pretty much just doing a Batman/Sleeping Dogs thing. Not as fluid as either, and somehow less brutal than Sleeping Dogs's. It gets old. There are nice ways to avoid it, since the shotgun is pretty much a 'end this fight' button, and while the ammo for it is plentiful, it is scarce enough that you are encouraged to save it for big fights. It is always great to reenact the swordfightning scene from Raiders of the Lost Ark, but just like in that movie, you can run out of projectiles at the worst possible moment.   The driving is a VERY big part of the game, as it should be, since this is Mad Max we are talking about.  The environments are pretty distinct from each other, which makes travelling a pleasure. The bad part comes that for the optional races, you generally get to use a completely different car that handles unlike your custom rig, and it gets a bit hard due to not being used to the handling of the race cars.   Vehicle variety also suffers, since it feels like the factions each have the same cars, but with cosmetic differences.  The convoys start as an interesting activity, trying to replicate the feel of the chase sequences on the films, but unfortunately they fall flat after a while, since the experience is repeated over and over, though it gets easier when you get more tools at your disposal. Funnily enough, the closest I had to a chase sequence from the movies was in an optional 'wasteland mission', where you have to drive a big, slow truck with resources to a relatively far away point.  That felt a bit like the final chase from the Road Warrior, but not quite the same, obviously.  Apparently, if you reduce that area's danger level, there would be very few enemy encounters in that mission, which is an interesting detail, there were scripted pursuers AND ones drawn dynamically from the regular area spawns.   Enemy variety is kind of lacking. The factions each have similar archetypes. And the 'top dog' fights are unfortunately, not unique. All the top dogs behave the same, which gets fairly old. They are optional, but it would be neat if there were differences in them besides what comes in their arenas.   The strongholds and bases are quite fun to explore, often having far more going underground than what you can immediately see above ground, they feel like puzzle platformers at times.   The game is by far the prettiest of the open world games I have played. Which makes the use of the picture mode (shared with Shadow of Mordor) a VERY welcome addition. Both are ridiculous eye candy and worth absorbing.  The main story itself feels fairly aimless at first, but the set of endgame missions are ramping in intensity greatly, they are honed to a point. It ends with both a bang and a whimper, but be warned, this is Mad Max. This is not Road Warrior. This is not Beyond Thunderdome (even though it has a tacked-on thunderdome), and even though it looks a bit like Fury Road, this is not Fury Road at all. The tone and pacing is more like the original than anything else. And it manages to hit almost as hard as that one did.  Maybe even more so, because of the interactive nature of games.  There are many things that could have been better done, but for what it is, it is an amazing ride. If you have a chance to play it, do so. It might surprise you.

After taking my time and completing the entire story of the game along with so many of the side missions, I can safely say that this is not a bad game and it is worth the purchase. However, I don't recommend it at full price.  - The AI is very basic and very predictable, all of them are the same (including boss fights). So as soon as you learn the technique, you'll rarely ever get hurt from them throughout the entire game. - In terms of gameplay, you see everything there is to see within a few hours of playtime, aside from main story stuff. - Story isn't long at all if you remove all the filler missions they force you to take. - While the layouts of each camp are more or less different, the mission objectives of each camp are always the same. - You're apparently the only good guy driving around in the wasteland, everyone else is either bad or a straggler with info / side quest or beggar. - Your car is apparently a ticking time bomb whenever it's broken and if you don't get out within 5 seconds, it explodes, but if you do get out, your helper just fixes it back up and you can continue on your way... that is if the enemy that put you in that state don't just constantly run you over and not allow you any chance of dodging them since Max is ridiculously slow at getting back up and moving again once injured. - The NPCs in the game are so very afraid of the Sand Dunes area and always hype up the area to be extremely dangerous, yet it's much safer to hang out there than anywhere else in the entire game. Even the missions in that area are really easy.  - Giving beggars some water seems to have zero effect to the game at all... even running them over with the car has no effect either. What's the point of having them in the game?  - Apparently you're the only person that can save the world... or do anything at all in the game. Way worse than other games. - There is at least 1 known game breaking bug. There's a door that cannot be opened in one of the camps. You either have to do an extremely difficult stunt with your car in order to have a chance at shooting the oil pumps or you have to resort to cheating. For the record, I did the stunt. - Extreme weather events look awesome! But at the same time, they're stupid and they ruin the immersion of the game. By that I mean, the very second you go indoors, the weather effects go away, but if you stay outside and try to wait it out, it'll stay there forever (unless you drive through it). So if you trying to complete a mission and there's no way to go indoors, then you're probably going to die from it. I've also seen glitches where the weather effects continue happening deep underground. - Overall, I didn't feel like the game was challenging enough. The only time the game was challenging was usually due to the limitation of the game's mechanics or they just buried you in enemies hoping that will add some challenge. - I hated the ending too. It felt so rushed to the point where it just irritated the hell out of me.   I don't even care that certain individuals died in the game even though I liked them... it's just how they died and how they rushed it all to happen so quickly.   The story was only starting to get good and interesting and then wham! Stuff happens and the end, all within 20 minutes (that mostly includes actual gameplay, story is maybe 3 minutes?). But then, after the credits,   you go back to your destroyed car and see ppl that should be dead but aren't... all as though nothing had happened.   Talk about breaking immersion.   There's probably many more issues I didn't like about the game, but you get the point. And yet I still recommend the game... on a good sale price, which is what I paid for it. The graphics are nice and run smoothly. The overall game isn't frustrating enough to get me to stop playing it. It's almost like playing something like Euro Truck Simulator... there's really no point to playing it, but you do anyways cuz it kills a lot of time and you don't mind spending that time on it. I doubt I'll ever play the game from start to finish all over again though.

If devs could mix assassins creed combat with GTA racing, Mad Max would be born. The game starts with a roar and ends with the gamer wondering if doing it again is worth it.  The  story  (which is a pretty interesting one to say the least) revolves around the gamer playing as Max, a man scavenging the desert wastelands. As you progress through the game, you unlock upgrades for your car and perform different missions for various warlords. Max does this in hope of getting to gastown, a town filled with all the guzzoline (not gasoline) one could wish for. Unfortunately, the whole wasteland is overrun by Scrotus's War Boys. Max has to clear out their camps to get rid of the threat in different areas.  The  gameplay  is simple but has it's moments of fun. There are only two buttons required for combat : parry and strike. While it is simple, clearing out 10 to 15 guys in a in a camp is satisfying until it starts becoming redundant. Additionally while engaging in combat, cans of gas can be lit on fire to blow up enemies and shotguns can be used to get enemies at a distance. The driving part is fun due to it's simplicity but isn't as action packed as clearing a camp The driving controls are your basic right trigger to accelerate and joystick to control the wheels. The car has the ability to ram into others with a simple tap of the button. The car, the Magnum Opus is very customizable. The areas that of the car such as engine (transmission), body armor and thunder poons, which is the coolest weapon. Additionally, players can acquire cool hood ornaments that give the car upgrades. To take down enemies in towers, sniper rifles and harpoons can be used for extreme distances. There are many ways to keep entertained when roaming around, you may clear out scarecrows, scavenge war boy locations, and (of course) clear out gas camps.   Graphics  and  sounds  are also well done in this game. If your car takes damage, it's very apparent. Max will be bruised up and walk with a limp if he falls a certain distance. Your car can also go up in flames if you damage it too much. There is a neat visual feature in which Max's hair becomes longer over the course of the game. Max himself is also customizable. The sand looks very clean as do all the enemies. (When you bump into rocks or drive through a large pool of sand, the environment will react to you. There is a huge variation in the Scrotus War Boys compared to the many enemies that appear very different. The camps also look amazing. Many details are put into secret entrances into the camps so it is difficult to find the small opening you need to get in. The progression through camps is also what makes them special. Many small details go into making the huge world look clear to the human eyes. The water and sand look like they should but they vary in their appearance depending on which region Max is in. The enemies make noises when they fall off ledges and get hit. The sound is clear and grunts are well heard. Max seems to be in an active environment at all times.  The story line/campaign could have been better but seems to be the high light of the game. As I've said, it becomes repetitive : go collect or defeat this warlord can lose its grace after a while. Clearing out minefields and scarecrows can easily become tedious (and booooring). Also, when you have to drive across the map for sulphur, that's enough to drive anyone crazy. The game is good but has the potential to be a lot better. Following missions and clearing out camps can keep only keep you busy and entertained to a certain extent. All in all, this is a decent game. If you enjoy driving around in a free world like GTA and a bit of action raiding camps, this will appeal to you. It seems everyone I talk to either quit this game after 2 hours or kept playing it. It truly is a game in which I feel anyone can pick up and learn to play easily within an hour (which isn't always necessarily bad)!   I will recommend this game but with extreme caution. If one of your friends has this and their sharing this game with you, better to play it that way! So here we have it. Mad Max. Id never seen the movies until I bought this game and playing it made me watch Mad Max 1 and 2 tonight. I didn't even know about this game until a friend mentioned he was quite hyped close to release. I waited until after release to buy it actually due to the 'wonderful' launch of Arkham Knight (sarcasm). But in all seriousness this game has slapped me in the face and proven me wrong.   I have enjoyed 37 hours of Mad Max so far and I have not enjoyed a game this much since one of the Assassins Creed games which im not going to go in detail about as I am not here to promote AC. Every new title that comes out nowadays gets me worrying about optimization and whether the game will actually be in any way playable at launch. Mad Max is 100% playable and 99.9% bug free. A 2MB update could fix the only issues the game currently has and the best part is that the bugs aren't game breaking! The gameplay is extremely fun all the way through and even though im a guy im not afraid to admit that the main story has some emotion in it. There were moments that I actually gasped in shock lol. The driving is very smooth and I would compare it alot to GTA's style of driving but it feels like driving the Batmobile from Arkham Knight quite a bit when it comes to vehicle control and drifting etc. The vehicle customisation is great. You can change every little piece of your car to your liking but it comes at a price of course. Combat. Once again very like Warner Bros Batman Arkham combat although you do notice the difference in moves and overall let's say 'gore'? Yeah gore. So ive actually completed the main story now and I was worried that when it is done will I still play Mad Max? Yes is the answer. The main story may be complete but still I had only 43% completed the game. It was beautfiul in it's own way. When it comes to character customization I would choose the word endless. You can change Max's facial hair, his head gear, wrist armor, jacket, gun and unlock new fighting moves. So after watching the first 2 Mad Max movies I would compare the game to Mad Max 2 the most. I was watching the very long car battle near the end and right away I was getting flashbacks of vehicle combat in the video game! Even the map/scenery makes me feel like im a part of the 2nd movie.   Most interesting feature of the game:  Chumbucket. This is a character you meet in the game. After meeting him he leeches onto you and never goes away. After 45 minutes of playing you are very thankful to have him there. 3000 pieces of scrap later you are extremely happy to have him with you because your car will begin to look beautful because of him. He is very helpful throughout the game and got me through some situations. Ive usually found that having a character like this who constantly is with you in a game gets annoying. It's like Roman from GTA IV. 'Hey Nico! Want to bowling?'. I know Roman wasn't physically there but he still got me trying to find subways so I could escape the world of phone signal. Although Chumbucket knows what he is doing. He knows when to speak and when to shut the hell up. That's always a great thing. Right?  Sooooo graphics! Beautiful! Some may shoot me virtually for this but im gonna compare this game to the Arkham Knight graphics. I know ive compared it to Batman enough but seriously it is the best and most accurate example and it's by Warner Bros for god sake! Honestly the graphics are great. The game is very well optimized and im extremely shocked that it is due to more recent games and their examples. Warner Bros have done a great job at recreating the Mad Max world for us to free roam around in with our rumbling V8 engines. Good job. And yeah here is the gretaest part of all for people worrying if they can run this game. Im using an AMD Radeon HD 7870 with an AMD FX 6350 on high 1920x1080. No stutters no lag and 30fps+.  Also on the main menu I see a DLC tab. The excitement is real and the wallet is open!  9/10

Its actually the first time ever I take the time to review a game. I never had much to do with the Mad Max franchise until I saw Fury road and I was immediately sooked and almost made a salto when i heard of a standalone game instead of a crappy movie adaption for the franchise as I love cars, explosions and desert wasteland settings.  Technical aspect:   ♥♥♥♥ this game runs smooth, SHINY AND CHROME . Its been a long time since i have seen a so perfectly fine optimized game. I run an i7 4770k @ 4,5 Ghz CPU and a Nvidia Gforce 670 GTX and the game runs on ultra settings like a charm on a very very stable 60 fps. I only had minor camera bugs, like the camera trying as hard as it can to focus on something your pulling after you with the harpoon, but thats more a programming thing than a grapical bug.  9,5/10   Story:  the story needs some time to get going and as im at like 20% of the game ( yes i like exploring) i havent seen much of it- however the game takes its time to introduce you into the characters, story and wasteland as much as it rushes you into the customisation and missionobjectives- overall that makes a good balance to me as the objectives are fast paced and short, rough fun but the story promises to take a deeper breath and contrasts well with the overall pace. However the story builds up more with the questions that are not asked rather than with those asked- the game gives plenty of hints if you are willing to observe characters and the world as to what happened, why people are the way they are and how everything went to ♥♥♥♥- the brainchild you are producing while driving through endless dunes, seeing oiltankers and airplanes alike inbetween dried salty coral reefs and giant chasms is a sight to ponder and behold.  8/10  Gameplay:  As most people already delved into the way the game plays ill just quickly summarize it:  batman like hand to hand combat with powerful combos and finishers , but not as deep as one would like to wish... well what do you expect of a wastelander- meaty fistfights and crude mean weapons. The game doesnt do much in that regard but it does everything right that it attempts. the animations are fluid and dont evoke a repetitive sense as the enemies are plenty.  Stronghold invasions can be done the mad max style or the mad max style- one way or the other you will make stuff explode, fall down and die- here and there are some sneaky bits if you dont want to bother trying to rip down a fortresses defenses but eventiually things will explode.  Exploration is immensely fun, one would think a wasteland is hard to make feel alive but every time i started to get bored with the environment i got something new to look at and behold thrown at me. The game strikes a perfect balance of wasteland and living world to me and you can always spot a lovingly handcrafted wreckage or sightseeing spot around the next corner. (dont look too close tough- sometimes the graphics designers got a little bit lazy with the textures)  The survival aspect does get a mention but is rather something that adds a little athmospere than anything truly survival-esque -- youll never have to really bother about water, food and gas but its just a nice immersive aspect to take care of these things- i rather eat maggots and the occasional lizard that eating one medpack after the other and never actually drinking ( lookign at you tombrider) It just fits into the game and the developer noticed its a smart move to just immerse you a little bit more  scavenging is a good balance between exploring and reward- sometimes it gets a slight bit frustrating given the low rewards , but youll find story sniplets and nice vantage points ever so often- and overall the game isnt so littered with collectibles that you lose interest in picking them up at some point *cough far cry cough*  Cars:  now here lies the fun- the customization options are fun and plenty, you actually have noticeable impact on the behaviour and playstyle of your car when you modify it- its an actual second character- Drawing a line to assassins creed black flag here- in Assassins creed the ship felt like a static thing to me that i would just upgrade- the magnum opus however has its characterchange for every addition or substraction you make and that brings a lot of diversity and fun- if you get bored with your heavily armored boulder of a car- how about ripping all those armor plates and bumpers off to create a fast and furious but very squishy dune racer? You can even do this on the fly so you never have to enter a situation unprepared ( even tough i would rather have the garage only accessible in the safe havens- yet i understand that would hinder gameplay a lot, given the constantly changing world and objectives- so i understand the descision to make the garage acceccible at all times)  car combat is everything michael bay has to offer and it feels like the movies. Its fast, unfogiving and lots of metal will fly through the air.   Shiny and Chrome factor 9/10  Verdict:  you like desert wastelands, survival, cars ,explosions and mutated people ? get the game, its definitely one of the best releases 2015   9/10

An easy game to get into, a little 'console' in nature, it's just a fun way to spend an hour or two. No overt brain power required, just a good bit of escapism.  Pros:  Runs well on moderate systems. Cons:  A little repetitive ( but you can streamline and concentrate on the story line ) GasTown not as imposing as was elluded to in the movies and lore. Feels underpopulated, protected and generally underwhelming.  Knit Picking Side Notes:  For those who do not know or even remember such a thing as Aussie Slang.... Dinkie Dye ( yes, pronounced Die, not DEE as done in the game ) means 'The Real Thing' 'The Genuine Article' 'Not fake or artificial' 'The Real McCoy' 'The Real Deal'. You get my drift. At the time of writing, I have 41 Hours put into this, and still got about a third of the game left to complete. Loving every minute of it.  My belated game of the year for 2015. Gameplay's simple but extremely satisfying, combined with amazing post-apocalyptic atmosphere. HIGHLY RECOMMEND IT!  One of the only games I've ever played that makes me want to 100% it. Despite the fact that this game has the 'Ubisoftian' style of open world design, it's not like Assassin's Creed or Batman, where the world is filled with absolutely mind-numbingly boring activities. You drive around and visit decrepit locations, loot and collect scraps while sightseeing, beat up people with a satisfying Batman-like combat, maintain and upgrade your vehicle, run errands for Warlords and learn more and more about both Max and how the world turned into a wasteland. Everything is fluid, you go from one simple and satisfying activity to another. Not like AC or Batman where half the activities are clunky, time consuming and boring. Need scrap to upgrade car, drive around, find a camp, beat people up, reduce enemy presence in the region, take their scrap, upgrade car, need more scrap to upgrade further, rinse, repeat. Perfect and simple.  One single unsatisfying thing exists in the game, which is disarming minefields. Gigantic speed-bump. Very annoying. But not at all mandatory, it just triggers my OCD if I leave them undone.  Nobody hates the Ubisoftian design more than me. Seriously, I didn't even like Assassin's Creed 4. But Mad Max shown me that it can be done well. And I have to re-state how amazingly well done the atmosphere is. I will keep the studio behind this game on my radar, because it takes true talent to take the idea of a 'desert' and flesh it out into such a complete, detailed world. It's actually way better than the movie (Fury Road) in that aspect. Fury Road was just a desert. In this game, you go through dried out seabeds, an uncovered volcano, abandoned highways, decrepit buildings, an airport buried in sand... It's beautiful.  There's a host of cons, which would absolutely destroy a lesser game, but the fact that I don't care about them here is a testament to how good this game's core gameplay is.   Pros: -A simplistic, Ubisoftian game design actually being executed well for once. -Near-perfect PC port. The only thing I can nitpick is that Anti-Aliasing is just a simple 'Yes' or 'No', despite there being many other highly customizable graphical settings. -Long, if you want to do everything. -Photo Mode allows you to pause the game and take pictures while noclipping. There's also a selection of post-processing you can apply before taking the picture. -Highly detailed atmosphere and game world. -Good voice acting. -Very satisfying action. Vehicular combat is powerful and explosive. Melee combat feel powerful and requires you to pay just enough attention to make it interesting. It plays just like Batman, but the amount of handholding is taken down by a strong notch, making you have to pay attention to your positioning and timing. The sound design also makes your hits feel much more satisfying than in the Batman games. -Style. Not sure what else to call it. There's a bunch of little things that make me feel good. Like the way Max behaves while interacting with the environment, being able to use the Harpoon for more things than you'd expect, the chest-mounted flashlight actually having it's uses, etc. etc.  Cons: -The cars cannot be flipped. I can think of several good reasons why they made this decision, that go beyond the simple idea of 'handholding', but overall it really takes away from the game. There's no risk to making bad jumps or driving through uneven terrain. In the end they should have found a way to make it work. It looks goofy, too. -There's no enemy variety, which holds a really big threat to the game's replay value, but not a fatal issue. Not to me, anyways. Even the bosses are all the same. -The game is overall on the easy side, so long as you pay attention. -The gotdamned minefields are so stupid, I swear to god. Play the game to see what I mean. It can't be put into words. A huge break in the action. -Max has a shotgun and there's enemy Snipers littered all over the world, yet gunplay is not actually a part of the game. Nobody else carries any fire arms. It would have been hard to implement firefights into the game, but I hope they consider it, if there's a sequel.  -The soundscaping could have used some more work. The NPC that rides along with you constantly calls out events that aren't actually happening. 'THERE IT IS! THE MIGHTY DUSTER!' he tells us, warning us of a mini-tornado that is nowhere to be seen. 'YONDER! A WAR PARTY!' but not a single enemy unit anywhere. -The races are really dumb. Might have been an unfinished aspect of the gameplay that they didn't have time to flesh out. Or maybe it's an unwritten law of the Ubisoftian game design that your open world game needs some side-activities that nobody in their right mind would ever consider entertaining. Still, they're somewhat engaging at least and fast paced enough to not be a huge negative. Not to mention optional.
Not a Hideo Kojima game, but it's a damn good one, though!

tl;dr version in the end ----------- I usually don't make long reviews, unless it's a game that got overlooked and worth giving a chance.  Mad Max Is an Action RPG Open-World game developed by the same studio that brought you Just Cause games.  At first you would say 'Another game based on a movie? Nah, it will be crap' But this isn't the case. This is really probably the best movie tie-in Video Game in long, long time.  This Game feels like a 3rd person version of RAGE (remember RAGE? another post-apocalyptic game). You get a car, you upgrade it and your arsenal, gets to several areas/strongholds/camps, meets new people, gets missions and so on.   Story: 6/10

I went in not knowing what to expect. In my experience, movie games tend to be poorly made cash grabs, but I had heard good things about this one.   The leveling system is rather unique. Rather than being based on experience, quests or the like, you raise your legend rank by completing specific tasks, some of them repeatable. This in turn gives you 'tokens' which you can redeem with the enigmatic Griffa, who I am not entirely convinced isn't just one of Max's hallucinations. Now, how many tokens you can spend on any one aspect of Max's abilities is gated- a gate which increases as your olegend rank increases. While this does prevent you from just maxing out health right away, it also encourages you to spend tokens in other attributes- and you have to spend them all. Reaching the (heh) Max level is not that hard- by the end of the game, I was 84 levels over the 'max' level after I ground to around level 90 at the first stronghold. Not that you have to, but it does make the game significantly easier.   The Magnum Opus, well, she's a bit of a mixed bag. On one hand, once you get fully upgraded thunderpoons there is nothing in the game that can stand in your way. On the other hand, in order to have anything resembling decent handling you have to keep her relatively lightly armored. God forbid you want to do ramming attacks as well, although with thunderpoons, the stock harpoon, and a fully upgraded shotgun you won't really have need of those.   Strongholds... now there's a fun mechanic. Strongholds are safe havens which you can upgrade to give you various benefits, such as free ammo refills, water, a full tank of gas.... basically, everything you need. And the more you improve a stronghold, the more it improves visually as well- you can see the difference you are making as it gets more built-up. Getting all the pieces required to do so can be a bit of a pain, but the payoff is well worth it, and thankfully you can mark their locations on your map while you are in the stronghold.   The threat mechanic is two things: first, it determines how dangerous an area is by determining how many patrols there are, and second it acts to gate Magnum Opus upgrades. This is a bit of a mixed bag; on one hand, scarecrows and snipers are easy to find, and you can find a number of them just by using the omnipresent balloons which are in every region. On the other hand, clearing camps can become frustrating if you cannot find the last objective to destroy, as these are not in any way marked on your map. Minefields are actually not that bad, though- their is a mechanic for finding them, and it has a good bit of range to it. And generally, clearing out the camps is fun. Convoys are generally meant for when you are highly upgraded- the early ones can be taken out by Max with a fully upgraded shotgun, but the later ones almost certainly need high-powered thunderpoons to do readily.   Now, the story... the wstory actually made me not like Max that much, but it fits; he's trying to survive, and trying to avoid becomming close to anyone. He is very single-mindely focused on his quest to cross the plains of silence, and to build a car that will let him do so. And he does not let anything or anyone get in the way. Could the story have been deeper? Almost certainly. But I do think the story was decent.      My conclusion? The game is fun, but as with any game, there are cons. But in my opinion, they do not outweigh the pros.

Very under rated game.  Most open world games lose my interest fast as they involve a lot of repeat content. All those side activities and missions end up feeling indentical after you have done a few. I figured madmax would be the same. I was pleasantly surprised when I started noticing how each little side area and objective were not only hand crafted/designed to be different, but many had different mechanics from each other. No two warcamps are the same. Hell, even the balloon quick travel points are different and require a unique mechanic to complete (ie: one might require you to refuel the balloon, another has you driving your car around to remove the cables that are tieing it down).  The game feels very mad max. The world is closer to feeling like the newer film than the older (which is fine, I love all of them). Driving is a lot of fun, and the batman like combat is also fun. I enjoy the combat in this better than in batman for a few reasons. 1. The rage system - It makes combat that much more interesting than in batman. 2. Unlike batman, there are times when you realistically just cant counter an attack, even if you see it coming. If you are in the middle of grabbing some guy and breaking his neck, its just not realistic to think that you can suddenly counter another attack. Dont worry though, you can still counter 9 out of 10 attacks if your timing is good, but there is a bit more realism with the system than there is in Batman (where you will go flying accorss the screen no matter what you were doing, to counter an attack).  The amount of customization and upgrades in the game is pretty insane too. You have TONS of car options and upgrades, character upgrades, a skill/train system with upgrades, and a 'hideout' upgrade system that lets you build things in your base of operations. The car upgrades are by far the most impressive. The sheer number of things you can add and customize is great.  The voice acting is also top notch and very accurate with a Max film. The characters all have that no longer part of the reality we know behavior, much like the films.   The visuals in the game look very appealing too. Sure, its not super 4k ultra mega Alpha X resolution textures and special FX, but it still looks darn good. Not only that, it runs VERY well. Smooth framerates 99.9% of the time, plenty of video options to adjust. No complaints here, and im VERY picky about graphics and graphical options.  My ONLY 2 gripes about the game:  1. Getting enemies OFF your car is just a pain. Even after you put spikes all over your car, people will still jump on it. If you are low on shotgun ammo (which you are most of the game), you dont have an easy way to remove them. Smashing into another car sometimes does the trick, but if you dont have another car to smash into, then the best option, believe it or not... is to stop your car... AND GET OUT. WTF?? Really? It really breaks the whole 'high speed action car chase' if the best option is to stop and get out.   Id like them to add some more ways to remove enemies. Especially if they are on the driver side. Let Max reach out and punch or pull them off the car. Maybe your hunchback can push them off? Maybe once you have spikes, it drains their life the longer they are on the car, until they die and fall off? Something more needs to be added. Its a minor gripe, but one that pops up every so often during car combat.  2. Climbing up on things. Imagine this situation. 2 cargo storage containers. Both the same size. One has a yellow marked metal bar on top, signifying that you can jump up, grab it, and pull yourself up. The other doesnt. Er... why cant I climb the other one? Worse yet, there are things that are only 3-4 feet high that you cant grab and pull yourself up to.   Thankfully, most of the game doesnt revovle around needing to get up on these things, but from an open world exploration, or even 'which path should i take' aspect, it can be kinda annoying.   Both of these things however dont take away from the games fun, or keep me from recommending it. The game is a blast to play and a visual feast for mad max fans.   The one thing id like to see from a DLC, would be a co-op play via the net. Would be super fun to do all the racing and car combat with another person by your side. (doubt that will happen though)

I'll resume the game... Mix Flatout with Twisted Metal and Shadow of mordor... Which became such an awesome combination, loved almost every aspect of it, just wanted some more weapon possibilities, like crossbow, machetes and the possibility to create my own fort, a DLC with those and the game would be perfect.  9,5/10 :D

First off, this was not a lame made for movie game. It was actually in development years before so you don't have to worry about that. The game is very immersive, visceral, and brutal. There are a good amount of supplies available so it does a good job of making you feel like your in a wasteland without being annoying. The hand to hand combat to me feels like a mash up of Batman and Shadows of Mordor and the car combat is amazing. The progression system feels meaningful, the graphics are superb, the weather system is like another enemy (especially the storms), the voice acting was done well, and the story is engaging.  Cons:  1. The boss fights can become a bit repetitive due to a lack of diversity of NPC 2. Some of the side missions can become a bit repetative but no worse than taking outposts in FarCry 3 & 4 and there is more variety than those games 3. Replay value didn't quite hit the mark for me, but you can continue to play after the main campaign and it took me about 80 hours to 100% so you'll get plenty out of it 4. The main campaign is a bit short but the difficulty level is designed to encourage you to play a lot of the side mission in between to properly level up. So if you don't try to plow through the campaign you won't really notice this issue.  Overall, I definitely recommend this game.

7/10 - Where to begin.. Mad Max is an enjoyable game to play without thinking. Turn off your brain and shoot things, punch people, blow things up. Travel from one objective to another. I'll destroy this convoy, I'll blow up this scarecrow, I'll go to this location and pickup the collectibles. Do this repeatedly, this is Mad Max.   The story is decent, but short and few inbetween it's roughly 30 hours of playtime (50 for avid completionists).  The combat is similar to the Batman Arkham series so it's enjoyable enough.  Driving: The car mechanics are poor and clunky; it's overall quite bad. The main enjoyment comes from upgrading both the car and Max, adding stronger attack/defence, weapon capabilities etc.  The environments are bland and filled with nothing most of the time. Sometimes it's pretty to stop at certain locations and admire the sun setting or some mountains in the distance, but the majority of the time there's nothing, just sand and more sand.   Overall the game is fun, yet contains heaps of tedious collectibles and does nothing new to push the open world genre forward. I'd say look into it, if you've exhausted better open world games before it.

If it was possible, this would not be given a positive or a negative review but would be a 'meh' review. I have done multiple negative reviews where I seriously say that I want to recommend the game but can't. This is sort of the opposite.. So what's Mad Max, the game?  Well, it's a free roam, mostly open world wasteland with a mix of hostile bases, lootables, mine fields, race coordinators and baloons which are used for scouting the areas. It has a plot, that starts Mad Max-like but by the middle of the plot, it's gone completely convoluted, trajic mess that I feel was the worst part of the game.  It starts out very Mad Max like but the plot turns out more like a detour from Max's normal mundane life to be the driver of a super-car. It doesn't start that way, but with the help of his 'bud' for most the game, a mechanic called Chumbucket, it doesn't take long to become a rolling death machine. If I had to give one reason it's worth playing, it would be roaming around with the car in free-roam.

Mad max is an open world game set in the Mad Max universe. Wander the limited open world, blow up cars and destroy things.... lots and lots of things. If you are a gamer used to and enjoys open world style games, then you may enjoy this title. The game basically tries to do what Shadow of Mordor did, only in the Mad Max universe and for the most part it succeeded .   Flaws include:   - repetition (not a horrible amount of it, but can get tedious)  - imbalanced leveling/upgrade system (Max gains levels too quickly, but scrap gathering (which is the main currency of the game) is relatively slow  - Bugs (have not encountered any game breaking ones, but the small ones seemed pretty common)  The good:  - Combat (on foot: it's a variation of the Batman arkham series combat system/car is pretty fun and satisfying)  - Story (nothing groundbreaking but it manages to make you see it through and also gives some additional insight into Max's world)  - Enviroments (granted it's mostly desert, but it actually feels like a world in ruin which adds to the atmosphere)  - The Magnum Opus (your customizable car, fun to upgrade, fun to use, your main means of transportation)  Overall the game offers an enjoyable experience, considering you like arkham-sytle combat and twisted metal black vehicle combat, there's a ton of collectibles for people who enjoy it, it's also nicely optimized and runs smoothly.   7/10

Just finished the game after about 35 hours of playtime, and I thought I'd sum it up.  You get free range over a vast swath of beautifully-rendered wasteland teeming with lootable locations, bashable enemies, and lovable warlords. You can upgrade your car, the Magnum Opus, to your heart's content, thanks to Chumbucket, that ugly little sweetheart clinging to the back of your ride. The tools at your disposal include a shotgun, car-mounted sniper rifle, boomsticks, and Max's bare ♥♥♥♥ing fists. During your adventure, you will roam from stronghold to stronghold, capturing camps, killing the big baddie's Top Dogs, and just generally being a helpful guy. This is all well and good, and some of the coolest open world roaming I've ever experienced.  Then, you hit the last few missions, and ♥♥♥♥ gets real. I won't spoil anything, but the story breaches out of the rest of the game like a whale on Red Bull and stays there. It's a hell of a slap in the face, and I loved hating every second of it.  Bottom line: If you ever wanted to walk a few hundred miles and drive a few thousand more in Max's boots, this is the way to do it. If you like open world post-apocalyptic games, then this is obviously your kind of thing. If you want deep, complex combat, go back to DoTA, nerd.  9/10
