What's not to love about a game where your main course of action is putting fists through faces of some weird wasteland psychos, pumping lead from a makeshift shotgun through metal, flesh and bone alike and pulling guys out of moving vehicles with a friggin' harpoon at high speeds!?...Oh yeah. And blow stuff up, of course.   Big time.    And just imagine you can do all this in the most beautiful wasteland! Yeah, I mean it. It really feels remote and empty, but incredibly detailed at the same time. And even when some content may get a bit repetitive: there's really lot's of stuff to discover in nicely placed locations in a vast open world.  A game that idolizes, no, openly worships motor cars as true saviours in this harsh world. That makes fun of some roaring monster of a modified V6 engine, because it will forever be inferior to the most sacred V8 block. And the way, the vehicles are presented and used here, is so incredibly over the edge, that all those friggin 'don't try this, always wear your seatbelt' need for speed warnings don't even DARE to show up anytime on the screen. If Max had a seatbelt, he would rather fasten someone else   behind   his Magnum-Opus.  Car crashes have never been so aesthetic and satisfying. You can almost feel the flames! 11/10 Pyromaniacs AND skilled cameramen would recommend.  Only downside for some people may be, that in spite of it's awesome post-apocalyptic setting, this really isn't some kind of survival game. Even though food is rather scarce, you do just fine with your water canteen most of the time which is only used like a refillable med kit. No dehydration / hunger / bleeding whatsoever. Just refuel your car and take a sip of water from time to time.    Pros:      Easy combat and overall controls.    Blowing stuff up in incredible detail (even on slow machines, like...V6 engines).    Vehicular combat done right. Really nice driving physics and insane combat maneauvers at the same time. The cars really handle a lot different and you can feel the overall performance. AND: First Person driving. May be unwise in some combat situation, but the camera also does a decent job, when riding your wheels in third person.    No speed limits, no guardrails, just some paths for faster travel, but always the ability to go fully offroad and discover stuff on the way. (There are even fast travel locations but...b****, please. Who need's them anyways?)    Nice character upgrade system (which extents to your Magnum Opus Car, which is like a character itself and totally modifiable)    Lot's of stuff to do that keeps you busy.    Really catches the visual style of Fury Road.     Cons      Combat is fun but not that varied like Sleeping Dogs' for example.    Overall a bit too easy at the moment I write this. No difficulty settings. (22 hrs. of playing. You can boost Max' skills and his car quite fast, even though West Coast Customs wouldn't be proud of you. But why not tear through a fortress like a real man, without even a shirt on? Putin would be proud..)     Not really a Con for me, for this game really is fun, the way it is, but stuff like a Survival or Sneaking system might have made the experience even more interesting at certain points, but this one sticks to the action and facing the wasteland head-on, Mad Max style.   In my opinion, if you are not looking for a survival game but love postapocalyptic settings, fast and loud cars and a whole lot of explosions, this one is a must-have..  especially   when on discount like the moment I wrote this review.

Well, I do have to agree with almost every critique point people who don’t like this game bring up. Yes the missions and tasks are repetitive, yes it can be a humongous grind at times, and yes the story is a bit bland. But does it matter? Well, it depends. Sure, having more varied missions and tasks and a more compelling story would make this even better, but it’s not like the game is not enjoyable as is. I for one love just driving around the wasteland for hours, tearing down scarecrows, harpooning snipers from their towers, chasing after every enemy car I see or duke it out with a convoy. And I even enjoy the grind of looting every damn camp I find for minuscule amounts of scrap and ammo because it makes the world feel like it should: A harsh wasteland where resources are scarce and most of your time has to be spent on finding supplies to survive.   And surviving is not easy in the world of Mad Max. You don’t have insane amounts of health and armor, and enemies are plenty and dangerous. Your only way to heal is through water or food, both of which are incredibly rare and you’re sure to have none of both available when you most need it. I have spent quite some time just trying to find water. Of course, as you progress you can complete projects in the strongholds to provide you with all you need. But it takes quite some time to finish these (because you have to find the parts) and even after that, depending on how far out in the wastes you are, driving all the way back to the next stronghold just to fill up on water might not be all that appealing (unless you’re willing to use fast travel, which I’m not). Because the wasteland in Mad Max is freakin’ huge!   And it is also unbelievably beautiful. Avalanche really did an awesome job at providing the most beautiful wasteland possible. Despite it all being desert the terrain varies greatly between regions and is littered with ruins and awesome sights. The colors are just perfect, the textures and details gorgeous and the horizon always looks captivating. No matter where you look or where you look from, you just want to print out what you see, frame it and hang it on the wall. Best looking wasteland I’ve ever seen, both in games and movies!   Oh, and it has sandstorms, huge, monstrous, violent, end-of-the-world sandstorms that will rip you and your precious car to pieces! Best moments are when one of those is happening while in the middle of a convoy chase, that’s when things get really awesome! And it’s not just a weather effect that suddenly appears out of nowhere, oh no, you can see it coming on the horizon, and then you can either race ahead of it to the nearest friendly camp or stronghold to sit it out or take the risk and head right in to hunt for the loot the storm is carrying with it.  And it’s not just the landscape that looks gorgeous, the whole game looks absolutely fantastic. And it runs as smooth as silk on highest settings no problem if you have a halfway decent machine. I run it with a GTX 780Ti 3GB on 2560x1440 and didn’t have a stutter or freeze or anything. I haven’t checked the actual framerate, but from how it looks I’d say it must be around 50-60. Also so far no bugs and only a few minor glitches encountered and only one CTD in 30 hours. For a game that just came out and looks this stunning, this is really something.  And the combat? Well, the car combat is awesome, obviously. Especially when you take on a convoy which will start a battle that can last for minutes. Taking out the escorts one by one through various means like shooting their fuel tanks, harpooning parts off the cars or even the drivers out of them (which is exactly as hilarious as it sounds), exploding them with your thunderpoon (yes that’s really what it’s called) or just drive through them with your nitro boost and then going for the big price, the tanker. What do we need the movies for now? Why just watch it when you can start up your PC and do it yourself?  The only negative thing to mention here is that the car physics sometimes can break immersion a bit as they are quite unrealistic at times. It is almost impossible to flip the players car over and even then it will always land on its wheels. While I understand why it was programmed that way I still find it a bit off putting when I see my car magically level out midair. But that’s really just a minor thing. As long as you don’t get airborne physics are ok and make for some awesome crashes.  Also, taking down enemy camps is not as bland as some make it sound, at least not for me. I quite enjoy doing recon on them to find the weak spots in their defense and figure out the best approach to taking them down. And there are quite a few possibilities here. You can try to sneak in undetected, use the sniper rifle from a safe distance to kill everything you see, drive around the base and tear the defenses down with your harpoon or just storm in head on and hope for the best (and probably die in the process). It’s up to you, there isn’t a perfect way to do it, so you do whatever seems most fun to you. Now once you get into the camp is where things can get a bit annoying as swarms of enemies descend upon you while you struggle with the less than perfect melee combat controls. Mostly it’s just button mashing paired with hope. But once you get the hang of it and have your tactics down it can also be quite satisfying to break bones, smash in heads, finish someone off with a gutshot or just outright exploding someone with a thunderstick. Just don’t get stuck in a tight corner as this will completely mess up the camera!  A bit frustrating is the search for all the items you need to find or destroy to complete a camp 100%. Some are so well hidden that you can run several time through the entire camp without finding them. Or you find out you need the shotgun to destroy that last Scrotus insignia but you just run out of ammo. Bad luck, come back again when you have found some ammo… That’s actually a bit stupid. They should at least have put an ammo loot close to things you have to destroy with the shotgun, like they did with fuel cans next to things you have to blow up.  The progress system for Max and his car I think is well designed and balanced. It really requires you to do about everything that can be done in this game to finish all the challenges and unlock all the upgrades as opposed to games where you can just ignore huge chunks of the content and still max out. The pace is also just right, not to fast but also not frustrating. Yes it does require you to grind, especially to get all the scrap needed to actually buy the upgrades, but as I already said, I don’t mind the grind as it fits well with the scenario and is also quite fun to do at times.  As far as the scope of the game, I have played 30 hours so far and statistics say I have completed only 31% of it. So, I still have vast areas to explore and loot as well as many, many hours of insane road battles, violent explosions and bloody fights ahead of me. I’d say it is worth every cent I’ve spent on it.   To sum it up, I give it an 8 out of 10.  Pro:  + vast open desert world that’s harsh but incredibly varied and beautiful + insane, spectacular and highly enjoyable car combat + fantastic graphics and sounds + highly customizable car + good and well balanced progress system + very good and streamlined controls and camera while in car + car combat can be quite tactical at times  Con: - missions and tasks are repetitious - bland main story - some issues with melee combat controls and camera (especially in confined spaces) - unrealistic car physics sometimes break immersion  So, do I recommend it? Hell yeah! For me this is the best action game I have ever played, and I recommend it wholeheartedly to everyone who likes this type of game. Yes it has flaws, but I think I have pointed them out sufficiently. So it’s up to you to make up your own mind about it.

I bought this game on a whim. Although was expecting it and had seen pre-release material, I wasn't too hopeful, given movie tie-ins and was planning to wait reviews. After a weekend of a music-festival-turned-unplanned-Mad Max-cosplaying, I decided to buy the game, my face still covered in chrome spray.   Just like Fury Road to original three Mad Max films, this game follows its own continuity of sorts (although the ending suggests it might actually be a prequel to Fury Road).   First off, the game looks *amazing* and is incredibly well optimised to PC. This is a statement I had seen in reviews before I bought it and thought it was just people struggling to find compliments for a bad game ('Damned by Faint Praise') but it really looks good and runs very smooth. The distances show very well, there is little to no flickering, I have not encountered any obvious glitches. I had only one spot where the framerate dropped significantly. Flames and thunderstorms in particular look sublime.  Gameplay is fairly solid. Nothing too exciting if you have played AC or Batman, as elements of both are readily apparent. Controls are a bit off. Some of the default key mapping puts commands in odd places but you can re-map them. As a whole, the gameplay is fairly shallow. Most commands are reliant on holding the E button. Or mashing the E button. Or mashing the E button while mashing mouse keys if you're fighting. Controls are stable and it is fun to fistfight, use your gun, shiv or weapons. No real issues stick out.  Car controls vary but overall tend to lack handling, though nowhere as badly as the cars in Watch_Dogs did and they depend on the car you pick too. Still, without dedicated handbrake buttons and the like (though the vehicle slam button can substitute as one in some situations) the vehicle mechanics feel fairly shallow. Nitro boosts, harpoons and other abilities on the Magnum Opus make this a bit more enjoyable, almost to the expense of other vehicles. I honestly fail to see why you should even step in any other vehicles if Magnum as around. Given the abundance of interesting vehicles around, this is bit of a shame.  The pre-release material touted the game's survival element quite a bit. You would need to make sure you eat and drink to avoid starving/dehydrating and would be on the hunt for guzzoline like in the hunt for Mad Max: The Road Warrior. These never really come into play. You come across food (in the form of dog food cans with a reference to The Road Warrior, lizards and rats you can kill and eat or maggots on corpses) but they are all effectively static health pickups. There isn't a real hunger mechanic or picking up and hoarding food or spending hours in the wastes looking for it. Same with water. You can carry it in a canteen and it replenishes your health. Max will comment about thirst if canteen is empty but doesn't actually suffer for it. Most camps tend to have some gas canisters and locations where the gas is part of the objective they regenerate. Bullets are rarer and easier to run out and is effectively your only resource to keep an eye on. However if you fully upgrade allied camps, you will rarely be lacking resources.   Both Max and the Magnum Opus can be upgraded and customised, using scraps as resources. Most of the customisations improve abilities but some are purely cosmetic. Throughout the game, you also come across a wastelander called Griffa who has some cryptic conversations with Max, which lead to additional upgrades for Max's abilities. This allows for a degree of customisation and especially on-foot sections will challenge you even if you are fully upgraded. On vehicle, most of the fighting is fairly balanced, if prolonged. Once thundersticks are unlocked, they become a cakewalk.  Thoughout the game, there are many small camps/ as well as a number of bases belonging to Gastown. Most side missions involve taking these out for scraps, history relics, upgrades for friendly fortresses. Destroying Gastown bases also reduces the threat level in the region, reducing Gastown patrols and enabling you some of the upgrades. Taking all of these out can get a bit tedious and repetative. There are many camps that are just mooks + loot with nothing specific to flesh the world a bit more (other than some history relics). The more interesting places don't really appear until later in the game (especially in the Buzzard territories) and are still rare and in between. Most Gastown bases follow the same formula with no interesting sidequests (rescuing people for instance. There are many corpses in cages. Why can't some be alive to be rescued?) The %100 completion chase can sometimes kill any momentum, as the devs seem fond of showing how clever they are by putting things in really obscure spots. As a whole, this is the weakest part of the game and I enjoyed it a whole lot more once I got them out of the way. Outside these, there are the occasional wasteland encounters (mostly wastelanders with something to tell you and occasional questgivers with very simple quests) and a racing circuit that makes things a bit more interesting.   The setting and locations are a bit more interesting. As stated before, you play around the Wasteland surrounding Gastown and despite it being a desert wasteland, the creators went to some effort to make things varied. Jeet and Gutlash's territories used to be the ocean and there are plenty of reminders as you drive into a cave and notice all the dried corals or take shelter in grounded ships, giving a clear idea how messed up the world is. Heading inwards, you see go through old highways and abandoned towns. Eastwards, there are dunes which look empty but have a whole city that was buried beneath. Finally, the area around Gastown is a polluted wreck. So, kudos to to making the different locations a bit more varied. The history relics you collect give a sense of how things became the way they did and probably go into more detail about the nature of the apocalypse than any other Mad Max production so far. After a while, they don't say anything you didn't already know and could be a bit more detailed but are still a nice touch.   I initially didn't have much hopes of the story but it actually didn't turn too bad. As his is getting ready to travel to the Plains of Silence, Max is waylaid by Warlord Scarabus Scrotus (son of Immortan Joe, introduced in a Fury Road tie-in comic) and loses the Interceptor, gravely injuring the Warlord in the process. Max then comes across Chumbucket who is looking to create his own vehicle, the Magnum Opus. Believing Max to be a Saint of his strange religion, he enlists Max who only helps him looking after a new car. As they look to build it, they encounter settlements that have come under attack from the Warlord scouring the wasteland, gradually leading up to Gastown itself in pursuit of a V8 engine. The earlier parts of the story are fairly standard but as it develops, it goes more and more into Max's demons and his fears of attaching to people in fear of losing them just as he lost his Wife and child and these issues come pretty heavily later in the story. Between that and the optional encounters with Griffa, the game actually goes into a lot of detail regarding Max's solitude and survival guilt. Not going to spoil a lot more but there is a reason why I feel the game is a prequel leading up to Fury Road.  You won't find the charm and crazy-fun of Fury Road here. I doubt even the film sequels will have that. The characters aren't as memetic or memorable either, although the makers clearly tried to and Chum, Crow Dazzle and the Outcrier shine among the rest.  As a post-apocalypse game taking place in the Mad Max universe, this is a good, solid game that will keep you busy, so definitely buy it, though you may want to wait for a discount if you have doubts. I almost regretted a Day 1 purchase but it grew on me as I progressed, so I am glad I bought it then.

Loved every minute of it! And the scenery is gorgeous if you can handle the graphics. The gameplay is sort of a Far Cry style where the territories are controlled by the tyrant, and you can free territories by capturing camps. On-foot gameplay is in third-person, but there is the (suicidal) option to use first-person while driving. Vehicle combat feels great! Fast-paced and intense like in a movie. and the on-foot combat looks and feels just as brutal and intense! There are a few bugs like occasionally having the cursor stick around after being in the menu which can be easily fixed by quickly opening and closing the menu; another is very rarely (twice in 92 hours for me) being stuck in the menu, where I would have to turn off the game. This wasn't a big problem though since the game frequently autosaves. I've heard complaints about the game feeling repetitive, which I guess just depends on the person because I never got tired of exploding cars, chases, shooting, looting, surviving storms, and just exploring. I ~do~ recommend this game... with a gigantic qualifier. It's great... BUT...   This has been one of the most enjoyable games I've played in some time. No bugs to speak of, fluid ground combat, good car mechanics (in the open, anyway), good atmospherics. I had nothing bad to say about this game... until the Gastwon Race. This is a story mission that basically locks off the V8 engine and all further story advancement if you cannot complete it.   And I cannot.   It's not a matter of trying again or trying with a different configuration of car components. I've tried and tried, and I've read online guides (such as they are) and the bottom line is that this beautiful, fun game ~ruined~ its reputation with me because of this one, required, mission for which there is precious little precedent. The death races, the most similar mission, are wide open. Racing in the confines of the Gastown track is an entirely different experience.  I would have liked to have seen the ~rest~ of the game, but this one mission that I cannot beat has pretty much bricked the game for me. I got the game on sale, which is the only way I can advocate getting it, now. And at that, I would urge people to enjoy the game ~while you can~ because that Gastown Race would infuriate a pope.

As it starts out it was amazingly fun to drive around, get to a Stronghold and clearing sites. Eventually though, you realize how limited you are as a player. The melee fighting has you punching light or heavy attacks as well as being able to shoot the shotgun and stab with the shiv. How about being able to throw that shiv, to stealth inside and sabotage some things before assaulting. Things like that.  Strongholds themselves are surprisingly lifeless. No one moves around, it's basically a garage with an added space to it. Sure it evolves as you upgrade things, it adds some cosmetics. It would have been more fun if a stronghold actually was a settlement too, where you see NPC's doing their wasteland businesses.  It has a lot of fun elements, that could have been more fun if they had added some more functionality to it. Overall, it's a very fun game, but it wears off the longer you play it due to the extreme repetition. Storywise, it's more of a guide through the game and you don't really have anything to say about it. So, don't expect any deeper RPG functionalities.  Final words; Having said all the above, the game itself is really, really fun. It feels like a Batman (light) game set in the Mad Max 'universe'.

Mad Max is a third person (with and option for first person in car), open-world, single player game. Gameplay focuses on action and exploration, both on foot and in car.  The biggest thing Mad Max has going for it is the world. Avalanche Studios have crafted a wasteland that feels seamless, alive, and genuine while still maintaining faithful to the source material of the movies. This game is in fact treated as a prequel to the movie 'Fury Road'. For all the violence and terrible things that happen in this place of squalor it is almost always shockingly beautiful to look at. The map is absolutely giant and filled with different things to do.  With the help of your sidekick, Chum Bucket, your journey revolves around finding scrap to build your car, 'The Magnum Opus' into the perfect road warrior machine. Chum Bucket is probably my favorite video game sidekick. He was always entertaining, particularly when he starts spouting lines about his crazy religion and praying to his angel of combustion. If you have an understanding of mechanics and car parts there is a lot to enjoy here and will enhance your experience. Your car, The Magnum Opus, feels like a character itself and the more you build it the more you will get attached to it. I'm not sure if that was intentional game design or not but I thought it was really cool that it happened to me because that's how most characters in the game world are. They worship all things mechanical and are attached to their rides.  In addition to collecting scrap through exploration, combat is other core pillar of this title. Combat is split pretty evenly between on foot and in car. On foot, the game uses the Arkham Style fist fighting that you know and love. No complaints here. Its fun and rewarding. My favorite though is the car combat. I can't think of another title that delivers on this more. It's exciting, and at times even heart pounding. This is where you actually get to feel like Max from the movies. It's incredibly cinematic when you take on a convoy in first person view.  The game also offers a photo mode that you can activate at almost any time. Its a great addition and I used it often, given how beautiful the game is. I wish every game had an option like this.  The game isn't without it's shortfalls though. The main story is extremely short and underwhelming. I feel like you could complete it in under 8 hours. In contrast, if your're a completionist you can easily spend 50 hours in one play through. To me, that's a little unbalanced. Just like other reviewers have said all the filler here can become repetitive. For me though, it was more cathartic than anything. I was just so enraptured by the game world and loved exploring every nook and cranny to get my precious scrap.  In my opinion, the biggest offense here are the missed opportunities. You never get to drive a huge war rig in anger. And there's never a giant chase scene that lives up to the ones in the movies. And most disappointingly, 'The Big Nothing' (the maps boundary), never panned out the way the developers said it would. They said it would be a kind of procedurally generated area that would have high risk, high reward exploration that you could drive around in for hours. In an interview with GamingBolt, senior producer John Fuller said, 'There are no finite limits to the map… in other words, there is no ‘one side’. You can continue driving into The Big Nothing until you get bored or killed.' Sadly, none of this is the case. It's simply not in the game. If you enter The Big Nothing you will see an onscreen message that tells you to turn back. If you don't, you are killed and your last checkpoint is loaded. I couldn't find any developer comments online as to why this feature was dropped but it was something I was really excited about.  All in all, Mad Max has been some of the most fun I've had this year in games. Ever since I saw 'The Road Warrior' as a kid, I've been drawn to the Mad Max universe. A lot of people call this 'Open World Game: The Open World Game'. A lot of people will hate on this because it does nothing especially new with the open world genre, or close combat fighting systems, given that the fighting is basically completley cribbed off Batman: Arkham Location's fighting system pretty much.  Personally I don't think these people are wrong, but they are focusing far too much on that. When it gets down to it, Mad Max is a very capable, very good open world game. There's lots of sidequests and things to do, taking out camps is a lot of fun, clearing out convoys, upgrading strongholds, upgrading the car and Max's equipment and max himself are great fun, the scavenger hunt for history relics is actually really interesting and really does enrich the world and setting...  There's a good deal of great characters used remarkably well too, though the scant female presence in the game is relegated to 'current necessary 'move the plot forward' key', 'damsel in distress who could have been way more badass but in the end is merely a mcguffin for the story' and 'cute kid you see almost nothing of'. This is a little bit of a shame, but ultimately doesn't detract too much from the game's story.  Speaking of, I personally feel that the game's story is exceptionally well done. It's really well shot and acted, the graphics are fantastic and even when you aren't playing on full graphics with everything turned on it still looks great (apart from shadows feeling a little shonky at times). The cars drive well, the missions are great fun, and the story plays out wonderfully.  Hhhoooweeeverr... I do have one pressing issue. I am a big fan of all four Mad Max films. I actually have gained a new appreciation for even Beyond Thunderdome, despite how cheesy it is at times and how it devolves into Peter Pan: Wasteland Edition at the end. In all but the first one, Max isn't really the main character. He's not the character the story is really about. He is an observer to, a reluctant participant in, and essentially the mcguffin OF the storyline. The Road Warrior is more about a group of escaping survivors and their plan to be free of their pursuers. Thunderdome is about the rise and fall of Auntie Entity. Fury Road is about the rebellion of and eventual rise to power of Imperator Furiosa through brutal conquest. In all three of those, Max is simply (to steal a line from HL2), 'the right man in the wrong place'.  I suppose when it comes down to it, the game is more of a call back to the first film, where the story is rather squarely centralised around him, and that isn't necessarily a bad thing. It does feel a little like it's lacking somehow as a result, but honestly if you see it as a prequel to Fury Road, it does work rather surprisingly well, and the way it's all executed really grants a lot of depth to Max and his madness. There's lots of subtle details here and there, lots of tidbits of details that let you fill in the gaps on your own without you being left scratching your head in confusion.  Gameplay of course is pretty much rock solid, driving works great, fighting is visceral and brutal and very kinetic, and there's a lot to keep you busy. However I did find myself at certain points going through sidequests just so I could fully upgrade the car and wishing, wishing I didn't have to deal wth certain things. I imagine if you just went for the main plotline, the game would be over fairly quickly. I'd guess I spent the majority of my hours doing sidequests, exploring scavenging locations, building projects in strongholds and just bumming around doing stupid crap in the wastes, but I still had fun for the most part.  It does everything right for an Open World game, but it excels at very little. Nevertheless its story is definately worth experiencing and the game is really well done. Very, very, VERY few faults, and an exceptional port for PC.  Worth picking up, definately.

Pros:  + Fantastic Sandbox Gameplay with loads of freedom + Beautiful if bleak world to travel around + Great atmosphere - really captures the feel of Mad Max + Loads of great customization with meaningful choices + Top notch combat both in car and on foot (uses a modified version of the Arkham melee combat) + Loads of value for money - will take dozens of hours to complete everything + Travelling is fun thanks to rewarding car combat  Cons:  - Mad Max style dialoge gets old fast - Strange story that never quite finds its footing - Slow to get going - too much hand-holding in the first couple of hours  Overall I really love this game. It shares many of the great features of Shadow of Mordor, but also brings enough of its own ideas to be a worthwile addition. It took me a little while (perhaps a few hours) to find my momentum, largely due to the strange hand-holding the game foisters on you to start with. However, once I was free to head off into the Great White and start having my own adventures I soon fell in love with it.  If you enjoy sandbox style adventure games then this is a great purchase and will give you hours of fun. It's not a story game in the way that GTA or Assassin's Creed is, so do be aware of that. But take it on its own merits and it's a wonderful game that is unique enough to warrant a place in almost anyone's library.

VERY enjoyable game! (mostly)  First of all let me point out what is awesome about this game. Atmosphere! Oh! The atmosphere! If the movies did it well, then so too has this game captured the bleak-yet-beautiful nature of the wasteland. The skies, the weather, the STORMS!  The great addictiveness of Mad Max is perfectly executed in 3 things: 1) The development of your car - the Magnum Opus (a wasteland mistransaltion of the Greek - Magna Opus - Great Work of Magnificence) 2) The development of stronghold projects for benefits - every project is a mission and every project is a reward. 3) Collection of vehicles - who needs cards these days when you can collect cars?  Summary of things I loved: The majetsy of driving and fighting in the vehicle. The intensity of the physical fighting and great dynamic moves Did I laready mention atmosphere? I'm sure I did. The sandiest sandbox I have ever played in. Australian accents made by a real Australian. No-one can do a real Aussie accent . Seriously. You can't. We can tell. Also, right hand drive. Get used to it.   Now this game peaks on so many levels and it is well worth whatever you decide to spend on it, but that said - I do have a few gripes. A lot of peeps complain that the gameplay can get repetative, and whilst that is a little true, it also offers up a big variety of things for you to do - so when you are getting bored of busting bases, you can race, and when you get tired of that there are wastelander missions, scrap looting missions, convoys, minefields or just bombing around in your recently stolen vehicle admiring the scenery non-missions to do.  The intro could have been playable. The ENDGAME could have been playable - but no - all we are given is a cinematic. VERY unsatisfactory.  I don't want to spoli the end, but I'll say this:  Poor storyline at the end. Very poor in a way that makes you question whether the writers just couldn't care about putting any effort into the endings. The storyline is written to force you to fail - at EVERYTHING - and I don't care for it. It made me feel like the wiorters were just too damn lazy. I also felt very cheated on the outcomes of the major characters, both friend and foe. But, let's put that aside for a moment.  Neutral things: The car collection you can achieve is nice, but not particularly engaging unless you are a screenshot ♥♥♥♥♥ (and yeah - I find that fun). For all you other screncap ♥♥♥♥♥s, there is a nifty in-game feature to let you get your own caps and vid - and that's a very cool thing. Car collection? Well - I guess it might be what you make of it.  Races - well, very musch a lot of fun if you want to compete amongst friend or be the bestest of the bestest. A good addition.  Overall - this game certainly rocks!  My advice - Don't get too caught up with the storyline - get your V8 early-ish and have fun blowing ♥♥♥♥ up!

I like this game and yes I recommend it especially if you’re a Mad Max fan. I think the issue with some of the negative mainstream reviews is that we have non-Mad Max fans expecting the wrong things from a Mad Max game. Mad Max should be filled with brutal, fast paced action and that’s exactly what I’ve experienced so far. Sure it’s not perfect and it’s true that there’s nothing new or innovative here at all but that doesn’t mean the game is trash. The driving is decent (better than most), the gun combat is ok (par for the course) but the hand-to-hand combat is GREAT (above average for sure). So far the story is decent but again it’s not groundbreaking. The marks of a good game are how well the core mechanics function. If you have a great soundtrack, graphics and storyline but poor gameplay mechanics you’ve realistically paid $60 for some cool tunes with pretty pictures and some neat voice acting and that’s not the case here. The devs did a good job at nailing what makes Mad Max, Mad Max. For non-Mad Max fans I give this game a 6/10 (just a bit above average) and for Mad Max fans I give it a 7/10 (above average).

I went into Mad Max with absolutely no hype- I bought it on a whim 'cause GreenManGaming had a promo on which saved me $10ish off retail ( hurray $CDN :( )  Anyway, the game's a lot of fun. Driving the cars feels good, the fighting is a-la-arkham so you'll either love it or hate it (near the end, I chose to just shoot and stab everyone because a fully loaded shotgun + ammo belt makes Max a walking Guns-n-Shivs-r-Us.)  It's a big open world that you can do whatever you like in- and progresses nicely with the story. It truly is vast and for being out in a sandy desert is pretty varied.  Ammo, Guzzaline, Water and Food are how you survive out in the wasteland-- and all of them are waaaaay too easy to find. You can also upgrade strongholds to provide free top-ups of each. Upgrading Max makes the game really easy- which makes the hand-to-hand combat tedious, and if you decide to thunderpoon every vehicle you see, the car fights are also boring.  Sounds like I'm ♥♥♥♥♥ing more than praising-- sorry. The game is PRETTY and has a camera mode which is fun to play with. It's also optimized AMAZINGLY for PC-- kudos for Avalanche/WB for this, it's not a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ port. I have a GTX 960 and was nearly at 60fps all day long on the highest setting, the only time it dips is when you're inside a small dark area and using the flashlight.  The story's not bad and fills in what happens right before Fury Road (the movie.)  I'll liken the game to Assassin's Creed II-- a bit more varied than AC1 for sure, but there is a lot of repetition.  Also, the boss fights suck.  But who cares, you can upgrade the Magnum Opus into a sexy dune basher and burn all over the desert-- as speedy or as tanky as you personally like.  I didn't really understand the point of the Archangels at all-- by the time I could build one, I had gear better than what it provided. Meh.  I recommend Mad Max if you like open world, car driving, face bashing, apocalyptic kill-em-alls' and don't mind grinding to improve your car for the sake of posting sick screenshots of you setting ♥♥♥♥ on fire.  Buy it when it goes on sale.

I have played every 'Grand Theft Auto' game, every 'Saints Row' game, most of the 'Batman Arkham' series, 'Mafia' 1 & 2, 'The Godfather', every 'Dead Rising' game, every 'Elder Scrolls' game, 'Just Cause' 1 & 2, every 'Fallout' game... and I have to say that, although I enjoyed the HUGE open world experience, this game has a lot of problems as well as a lot of repetativeness.  Before I begin, I want to point out that I did say that this was a recommended game, but sadly after playing for 90 hours, I see that my over excited attitude was a bit misplaced and I need to change my review. For those who read this previously and agreed to it, I am very sorry, but for those who have not bought the game, please read what I have to say about this game.  PROs ==== 1.) The game has a HUGE world for you to work with 2.) Lots of missions to accomplish 3.) Lots of side quests to keep you busy 4.) Lots of locations to go to 5.) Lots of vehicles to collect 6.) Lots of upgrades to find and equip 7.) Lots of great places to restore supplies (water, gas, etc...) 8.) Lots of hand to hand combat fighting 9.) Plenty of things to do outside the main missions  CONs ==== 1.) Missions and side quests are more about fetching and returning 2.) The things you do are more repeated than seperate 3.) A lot of the required accomplishments are pretty easy (Although I played similar games) 4.) Combat is more hand to hand since you can only hold about 6 ammo for your shotgun 5.) Hand to hand combat is just 1 button while defense has 2 buttons 6.) Chumbucket will ONLY join you in the Magnum Opus 7.) Dinki-Di will ONLY join you in the buggy (Required for mine locations) 8.) Other vehicles don't really serve a purpose except possibly for the races 9.) The only real missions I enjoyed doing were the ones where you help build the bases up 10.) You can win the vehicles in races, but it's more satisfying to find them and steal them 11.) You can't have Dinki-Di and Chumbucket at the same time 12.) A lot of the locations which require destroying are not as challenging 13.) Overall, nothing unique about this game, a lot of elements are taken from other games 14.) You have to get pretty close to use the harpoon and gun when in vehicle combat  SOME THINGS TO CONSIDER ABOUT THIS GAME!!! ======================================== Many aspects of this game don't give the ideal concept of realism. On top of that, a lot of the missions, quests and other accomplishments don't give any real sense of accomplishment. The whole point to most of the quests are to lower the threat level of each region you enter so you don't get attacked as often, as well as to collect scrap, which is the games form of money to help build up your character, car, and outposts. Although this is actually fine, there's other things going on that don't show a sense of realism. For example, the fuel tanker routes don't really lead to ANY location on the map. To top it off, it doesn't serve any REAL purpose other than to gain a trophy and to lower the threat level. Why would a fuel tanker be a 'threat'? Most cases, it's more of a threat to anyone who would be near it when it explodes. I even managed to steal a tanker, only to find out you can't have a fuel tanker for any reason. I find this to be a bit odd as you can get other vehicles, but not a tanker. I would think that if you designed a 'route' that a vehicle is taking, it would do more than just lower a threat level. How about making it so that the tanker actually enters a building, and either steal it to gain fuel, or maybe destroy it so that the base it's coming from loses say electricity or the vehicles stop working after a while. (This is just one example) Clearly they didn't take into a more psychological point of view when making this game. These days, missions or quests should have a sense of accomplishment as well as have different ways to make you feel good in that it served an 'in-game' purpose throughout the whole game.  Also, I noticed that 'stealth' wasn't in the developers list of 'Things to add in the game'. Most games I have played offer some kind of way to 'sneak' or 'stealth' your way into a camp, base, even on someone who is walking away and can't see you. In this game, no matter where you are, you are noticed coming a mile away, even if you walked all the way there, you are still noticed. It's as if you can be seen and heard coming a mile away, especially in areas where it is almost void of life. I would have thought that this would be ideal for locations that have alternate ways of entering the base so you wouldn't 'set off alarms'. Oddly, the only purpose the 'alternate' routes of entering a base serves is to simply avoid wasting resources to open the 'front door'.  Plus, the jump button is almost useless, as you only jump a few 'inches' off the ground instead of say 3-4 feet off the ground. The jump may as well be left out of the game as the locations you reach have plenty of ways to climb up a high platform.  And hey, wouldn't it be cool if you could ride, say, a bike? Nope, no bikes at all in this game, even though it was clearly in all the movies. I guess they thought that since the enemy would only be using vehicles with 4 wheels, it would be a super disadvantage to make bikes.  My biggest one is why you need 2 different vehicles to transport 2 different passengers. For some reason there is no way to transport Dinki-Di and Chumbucket in the same vehicle, even though it's clearly big enough for Dinki-Di to fit in the back seat of the car. I guess it was to create a challenge for the game itself.  The hand to hand combat is okay, it's pretty cool to be able to bash their brains in while knowing when you block and counter attack the next guy that wants to do the same to you. The attack and counter attack is a neat idea and works well for this game.  The extra DLC has absolutely no outcome of the game nor does it serve a real function other than to have another car frame. The DLC doesn't even give you improvements over the other car frames you collect.  About the only real enjoyment I had was simply collecting the cars 1 by 1. I have only been stealing them as well as finding them from certain locations which have special vehicles parked at the landmarks. Although I have not particpated in the races, I think I would have enjoyed finding and stealing them more as they offer a certain satisfaction after stealing them. From what I could tell, the only purpose the races offered, outside gaining vehicles, was to open additional 'fast travel' as well as offered refueling locations for you to go to when you are running low on fuel.  This game starts out strong and enjoying, but you later see that all you are doing is playing 'fetch the stick'. So much repeated missions as well as so much repeated boss fights that this game loses challenge because you see the truth that you just repeat and repeat, over and over to accomplish all your missions and quests. My suggestion, wait til it's $20 or less.  OVERALL ======= The main thing to remember is that this game is a lot of fun. Regardless of my rants, there's plenty to do, lots of things going on while you accomplish your missions, and more than enough to keep you busy. The only thing to consider is that you will be doing constantly the same thing over and over. The map is insanely huge so there is that. Lots of vehicles to collect and make. Plenty of places to go and side quests to accomplish.  HIGHS ===== Huge map, tons of locations, lots of vehicles to find, plenty of things to keep you busy, and enough of a challenge to allow you to come back for more...  LOWS ===== Tedious meaningless mindless tasks that, although help you get more scrap as well as lower threat levels, takes way too much time to accomplish while you are trying to finish the main game itself.

Incredibly fun game engine, some top notch voice acting. Sound and visuals are excellent. Sadly the game itself lacks depth.  I would love to have seen a little more detail. The interior and exterior locations are beautifully designed and varied enough while still fitting into a wasteland environment. Sadly, you are almost strictly collecting 'scrap' which is the currency you use to upgrade your car and yourself. Would have been nice to see some variance in items (collecting wires, sheet metal, finding actual parts instead of amorphous 'scrap')  The NPCs you encounter in the wasteland serve very little point. Share your water with them, feel better about yourself? Good because it doesn't really seem to do much else. You can listen to them mumble and sometimes point you in the direction of scrap because there isn't already tons of it littering the countryside.  Exploring the interior levels was fun and they are gorgeous, but I was never 'discovering' anything. There were no surprises or secrets. It counts down how much more scrap you have to find and tells you when you've found it all. For all the work that obviously went into designing the levels, they seem sterile and missing personality. The incentive to explore new locations ran out when I knew all I could get was more scrap and already had plenty.  I still enjoyed all 50 hours that I played, and I can see myself going back and visiting my hunchback friend in the future just to make life miserable for the bad guys of the wasteland.

A fun, and enjoyable game.   Do NOT get hyped about this game. Take it slow and enjoy it, do not expect overly great things from this game.   It is 100% singleplayer with the only real multiplayer aspect being race times.  For an open world game, this game is very cinematic. Not just in the story, but also in how you destroy vehicles and watch them burn. A lot of really nice cinematic moments.  Pros: 1. Really really well optmized. Even on my weaker pc, the game handles pretty well with minimal frame drops.  2. Not too overwhelming of an open world game. I personally dislike open world games. I love the concept of them, but they don't do well with the balance between story or side missions and then fill them with meaningless collectables. This game balances the two and makes it feel like you can 100% the game within 100 hours. I like to take my time with games, specially ones that are single player and story driven (hehe). So I do recommend playing this game if you have time to spare and just enjoy the wasteland. It's definitely one that open world gamers will chew up really quickly. I, not being an open world gamer, took my time to enjoy what the game offers before finishing the story missions.  3. Tons of destruction: This game will constantly put you in fights throughout the wasteland. It's a little annoying at times but it's not too bad. More-so when you have your ride geared up. I've yet to get bored of destroying vehicles and watch them fall off cliffs and exploding.  4. Gorgeous: It's just a lovely, beautiful game with a ton of epic camera angles. I could probably spend a day driving through the wasteland and taking snap-shots of Max standing over a cliff and looking over the wasteland.   Cons: 1. Repetitive: I know this is a constant complaint about this game but it truly is repetitive. The boss fights are pretty much carved out of everything you've already done in the game, just with more health. It's still a fun game but I would've liked to see some more variations. About halfway through the game, you can experience almost everything it has to offer. 2. Story/side missions not replayable: I love replaying missions from my other games like Max Payne. Again, I'm not an open world gamer so this really does bug me a lot when I can't replay an epic mission.  3. A bit short: This is a double-edge sword. The game is fun but it is short with content and story. Just about any open world gamer will complete this game relatively quickly. If you don't play that many open world games or if you want to play open world games, I'd recommend to start with this one. Even for me, the story was too short and although it had some really cool moments, it didn't quite reach my expectations.  4. Not enough racing: So this is more of a car-combat game, like Twisted Metal. So although racing is part of this game and there are a few races to play, it focuses more on the vehicular combat. I'm a bit mixed about it and I feel they could've been a little more aggresive with the races.   Overall, if I had to rate the game, I'd give it a 7/10. It's great, it's fun, it can probably run on a toaster. It's just a bit lacking in story and would definitely need more content to have a higher rating. This is one of those very few times where I would beg for DLC.

As a PC gamer I was a little apprehensive going into this game, after feeling let down by Shadows of Mordor, which was similarly designed mainly with the console player in mind. In particular I was worried about the lack of difficulty levels or any real mod scene that could make the game harder. I like a challenge and I often find that lacking with these kinds of run-here collect-that kill-him kind of open world console games. I'm going to compare Mad Max below to Shadows of Mordor quite a bit, because its a nice way to highlight what this game does well.   The best thing I can say about Mad Max is this: Twenty hours in I definitely want to play this game right through to the end, unlike Shadows of Mordor, which I enjoyed initially, only to find that I just couldn't be bothered to pick up again after finishing the first area.  It does suffer from some similar problems. Repetition of a few basic tasks, looting, killing, looting, killing, again and again and again. A world that is a little too forgiving, allowing you to rarely feel seriously threatened even when vastly outnumbered.   However Mad Max, I think, is at its core a superior game.   Yes, Shadows of Mordor has the Nemesis system, which gives you a dynamic army of orc captains to fight. Meanwhile the bosses of Mad Max are your old static type. The orcs themselves in Shadows of Mordor are also a great enemy to hate, while a lot of the enemies in Mad Max feel bland. Going further, the combat in Shadows of Mordor is fluid and very professionally done, while movement and combat in Mad Max can feel a bit clunky. There is no sneaking, no acrobatics, and you often feel frustrated by your inability to even climb over simple barriers.  However the wasteland is a much more realised and lovingly crafted setting than mordor. From the overall design of the different regions, to the huge variety of gorgeous textures and colors, to the tiny details put into the little camps you raid, you really feel like you are in an actual world that is a pleasure to inhabit. The landscape nicely balances your two modes of play: Open vistas for high speed racing, and more cramped nooks and crannies for exploring on foot. Switching between these two helps alleviate any sense of tedium of always doing the same thing.  Meanwhile the world is also responsive in a way that Shadow of Mordor's is not. Bases can be taken over. Towers and snipers removed. Minefields cleared. And as a result the threat level of the area drops. The strongholds you 'upgrade' are also being saved by you from the brink of destruction, slowly coming back from the edge and developing into actual decent little towns.   This sense of progress is perhaps the strongest aspect of the game, beyond the pure fun of racing about the place. Your car gets better. Your equipment gets better. And these upgrades directly relate to your ability to take on harder enemies. Most importantly, the upgrade path seems well balanced, such that you won't quickly become capable of taking out everybody and everything, which is the biggest problem in Shadows of Mordor. As you progress further you find that you have to put a decent amount of work into getting the scrap you need to upgrade just one part of your car. Basically, Mad Max will reward your OCD tendencies. It's repetetive, but in a good way.  Above all, this is a fun game. It's been made with plenty of love and care, and with a decent budget. It's a little clunky in places. And the design falls down here and there. But it has a fully realized setting, a responsive world, a fairly decent difficulty scaling, a good upgrade path, great racing mechanics, and some fun characters (Chumbucket alone makes this game for me). I'd definitely recommend it to any PC gamer, even if not on sale.

While there are many jokes about this game being an Austrailian outback simulator, the game itself isn't a joke. For something sort-of was under the radar and had a very silent launch (If memory serves me right, MAD MAX launched alongside Metal Gear Solid V: The Phantom Pain.) and while people were preoccupied with MGSVTPP, those that did pre-order MAD MAX got a very pleasant surprise, The game ran well at launch, hell it was really well-optimized. To have to be surprised every time a new game does that sure shows the state of the games industry nowadays.   MAD MAX (2015) The game follows Max Rockatansky in his quest to cross the plains of silence. You are in control of Max, and while there are no far-reaching consequences to your decisions in game, playing as Max is interesting to say the least.  The game offers open-world exploration, driving in said open-world, melee combat and car customization. Melee combat is reminiscent of the Arkham games where combat is basically 'punch, punch, heavy attack, dodge, counter, dodge, counter, finishing move animation, rinse and repeat.' What makes the combat fun is when Max is swarmed and his FURY™ counter gets filled up and he goes into a powered up state in which he is almost able to one-hit almost any enemy type. This does not make you overpowered at all, but it does help in moments where you're really in need of a pick-me-up.  Driving in the wasteland is interesting as you will encounter enemy drivers who will not hesitate to ram you off whatever is left of the road so they can chew on your innards. Customizing your car, the Magnum Opus, grants you various advantages and disadvantages that you can of course tweak to your taste. You can also customize Max, but you are limited to a few options in terms of hair, facial hair, whether or not you want some oil, dirt or face paint on you, as well as different iterations of the leather jacket (or rather progression as it gets armored up as you progress.)  As I played the game, I tried to avoid the main quest for as long as I could before I either get bored or can't hold the excitement of wanting to know what happens next. If you want to finish the main quests easily, doing all the side activities will help. But if you choose not to, the experience gets a bit harder.   Do I recommend this game? Do I think you should pick it up? Do I think you should spend money getting it? Well, yes.

My only two gripes about this game is it will slow down in large bases. (This shoudn't be a problem though on an I7). The closest thing to being in the movie Fury Road.  If interstate 76 and fallout 4 had a baby this would be it.  Overall a fantastic experience and since it was on special a must have purchase. Keep in mind with this review, I didnt pay much for the game, 33% of retail. So that being said, I might feel better about its quirks than many others reviewing it.  Gameplay Impressions:  So far I like the game, to the contrary of many of the Negative Reviews, I like the controls, but they should have been thought out a little better as defaults. The game also plays extremely well with the mouse and keyboard, again contrary to many of the -Neg reviews. I guess I dont blame developers for thoughtless control mapping, but rather blame myself for not picking up on them fast enough.  Character movement and Vehicle movement / Map Navigation. Both are good, they have the perfect amount of feedback, the cars have very nice weight and slip systems and very easy to control.  Character and Vehicle Combat. I've never been a fan of the button mash style fighting system, but this feels just as good as any of the best games out there doing it, Including the Batman Series, Witcher 3 and GTA 5. Vehicle combat is also well thoughtout, but due to odd control mapping it can be challenging. I was able to figure it out pretty quickly after a few fails.  There is some bad level design decisions you'll discover, for one the character cant climb much and cant jump very high. This is normally not a big deal, but there are things you'll be trying, logically, assuming you can climb up certain objects, but you cant. Climbable objects are Designated much in the same way they are depicted in Tomb Raider. Dont expect Raider'ish control though, and once you've gotten over that, the movement is well done and works well.  The Story seems decent enough, C'mon, these game plots are nearly always crap, and you know it, 90% of gaming suffers from crappy storylines. Try to base your expectations lower here and you'll have a good time.  Graphics:  Visually, I like everything about the graphics, detailed models, great animations, solid voice acting, interesting locations I dig it. Would I change certain things, oh yeah. So much empy open space, yet nothing really to discover. This game needs tons of lootable caves to explore and gather stuff - (yeah, I'm refering to Skyrim here.)  Performance: The graphics look great maybe I wasnt expecting much, but theyre as good as they need to be. Simply put, the game looks great, even the wieniest of the graphics cards (in my case the a Stock '2gb GTX 650') with my settings (mostly Normal, but a few Ultra Settings @ 900p, the game is comfortably sitting between 45-55 fps, a few lower in complex environments and gameplay sections but its never dropped below 35 fps for me. I'm thinking I can increase the resolution to 1080 and it will sit at 30 fps or more. Not bad.  Thats it for now. I have a feeling the game becomes a grind after a few hours, but we'll see. I'll update this review as I go.

I got it on sale, but still, given the fun I've had, I wouldn't have minded paying the full price.   This game isn't perfect, though. I really missed stuff like those huge concentrations of enemy vehicles in pursuit, like in the movies...  Anyway, let's go with the good, the bad and the ugly.    The Good:  +Overall, the game has beautiful graphics, with some exceptions (more on that later).  +It runs like butter (i7+R9 290)   +Like the rest of WB games I've played (Batman saga, Shadow of Mordor), it's very stable and has very few bugs. It still has a couple of clamorous bugs, though (more on that later)  +Pretty decent voice acting, Chumbucket is pretty hilarious sometimes.  +Pretty decent progression mechanics, vehicle and character upgrades, stronghold upgrades, etc.  +Driving through the wasteland with the Magnum Opus, laying waste to enemy camps and chasing convoys is pretty sick. But, as I said, I missed certain things (more on that later).  +Combat is savage and enjoyable, although with certain limitations (more on that later)  +The game has very nice touches like massive and deadly sandstorms, survival elements which include eating worms from corpses, keeping your canteen and fuel tank filled, etc. Thunderpoons are also sick.    The Bad:  -The main story is perhaps too short and simple. So much happens so fast, without really giving the story time to build up for the big moments.    -Repetitive grind. This isn't an issue for me, since I don't mind grinding in games that I like. However, you might get tired of clearing enemy camps and collecting loot in repetitive ways. Personally, I didn't get tired since I took it as part of the experience. Anyway, there are plenty of games out there that force the player to grind in a much more painful and tedious manner.   -This game lacks those huge concentrations of enemy vehicles from the movies, it's pretty scarcely populated with enemy vehicles, overall. 'Large' concentrations of enemy vehicles are limited to convoys and war parties, and even then, those are pretty small (less than 10 vehicles).  Also, once you destroy a convoy in a region, it's gone for good, it won't respawn ever again.  -The game is way too easy. Very little challenge overall, plus the Magnum Opus is essentially indestructible, as long as you exit the vehicle within 5 seconds of having lost all hp points.  Combat is pretty straightforward, it's essentially the same combat system fround in other WB games like the Batman saga and Shadow of Mordor, but perhaps a bit simpler (less variety and density of enemies). This isn't necessarily a bad thing, since I quite like to keep it simple sometimes, it's just too easy, that's all.  At least in the Batman saga there was challenge introduced by the sheer number of enemies. In this game you'll find concentrations of up to 12 enemies, with some variation, that's about all the challenge you'll get... It's still fun to break skulls with savage strikes, but, you know, being that easy it kind of takes from the experience.    -The game lacks combat gore for my taste. No dismemberments, beheadings, etc. There are plenty of gore elements scattered around the map, like tons of corpses impaled on scarecrows, rotten corpses pretty much everywhere, truly disgusting body piles, etc., but there's almost no gore in combat, which is strange.  Although there are several combos that are painful to watch (broken legs, arms, necks and skulls), and you can stick enemies with the harpoon and drag their corpses around the wasteland, or stick thunderpoons in them and watch their bodies explode, there's almost no gore in combat.  Sometimes, if you get lucky, you can stick enemies to the Magnum Opus by equipping some spikes and running them over in the right way, but it's not a built-in feature (if it is, doesn't look like it). In my opinion, this game lacks the great combat gore found in Shadow of Mordor, but I guess we can't have it all, can we?  -Absence of fear effects in combat. Enemy cars do run away after getting overpowered by the player, but that doesn't happen in combat, which is a real pity. In Shadow of Mordor, it was delicious to make orcs panic by massacring their mates.  -I've found a couple of game breaking bugs, sadly.  There's a camp in Pink Eye's territory called Havoc Point. This camp can't be cleared in the usual way because the door is bugged. There's probably some script that fails to activate, preventing spawns that unlock the door, so it stays closed and there's apparently no way to open it.  So you have to find a workaround for it. I had fun getting creative, tbh, the workaround is kind of challenging and fun, but this is still a major bug that needs to be fixed. (I'll leave a description of the workaround at the end, for those of you who are desperate and don't know what else to try).  There's another bug that makes one of the scarecrows disappear as you approach it, so it can't be destroyed. I think it's located in Pink Eye's territory too, on top of a destroyed highway overpass. Some people claim that it eventually reappears, I still have to check it out, though. Last I checked it was still invisible.    Then there are other minor bugs, like some npcs that apparently don't unlock any side missions or anything when you interact with them... which looks like a bug, since those npcs are marked on the map and are supposed to unlock locations, loot, and other stuff.  You also tend to get run over by enemy patrols when you are interacting with said npcs, which shouldn't happen.    -Character jump...it's a joke.   The Ugly:  -Low polygon rock models in several places, which are masked with dark textures, in order to give the impression of grooves where there are none. Well, I NOTICED! And I don't approve of lousy 3D modelling work! XD.  -Low polygon chains, which basically consist of two lines of flat chain textures, arranged in a cross pattern.  This was common practice in the 90s and early 2000s, but it's 2016 already, chains must be modelled with the same level of detail as the rest of stuff, otherwise what's the point?  I mean... 'This looks amazing! Look at the nice detail and beautiful effects... oh wait, ♥♥♥♥♥♥ rock there and disgraceful chain here... we are still in the 90s after all'.   -Most npcs that you encounter throughout the game are basically clones of three or four character models.  This is common practice in a lot of games, but it's still ridiculous and detracts from the experience.  Also, most enemies are clones too. Sure there are different kinds of enemies, with different weapons, skills and armors, but they are all based on the same few models, making the game suck when it shouldn't.  It's like Shadow of Mordor, where all slaves were basically clones, unlike the orcs, which were pretty diverse and well modelled. It's sad to see games with so much potential being ruined by npc cloning.    That's pretty much all the stuff I could think of. Overall, I definitely recommend this game to all Mad Max fans and people looking to have a savage time raiding the post-apocalyptic wastelands in a sick Magnum Opus.  If you can get the game on sale, it's totally worth it.     *Workaround for the Havoc Point gate bug:  There are several things you can do in order to blow up the fuel tanks in the camp without having to enter it. One method consists in getting behind the camp and waiting for a sandstorm to come.  Hopefully, the sandstorm will carry lightning, blowing the tanks up for you, liberating the camp.  The method I used is funnier. I blew the tanks up by firing some thunderpoons at them, after jumping high above the rear fence with the Magnum Opus. The tricky part is achieving the jump. You'll need a maxed out V6 (or any V8). Keep the Margum Opus light and fast, without ramming grill. Get behind the camp and use the natural rock ramp located beside the convoy road to make the jump.

The game doesn't do anything new. If you like games such as Shadow of Mordor, Assassin's Creed, Grand Theft Auto, and other open world titles, you'll like this one.   The atmosphere is pretty good, and while the wasteland can get rather boring to look at, well, that's kind of the point of a wasteland to begin with. Death is everywhere, and seeing just how quickly and completely humanity has descended into barbarism is just as jarring as it is in the films; indeed it makes me think of the Comedian's philosophy from the comic and film versions of Watchmen. Sad thing is, I really don't think it's all that far-fetched, but that's a discussion outside of a review.   As said, it's a run of the mill open world game with the addition of a customizable vehicle. Vehicular combat can be a lot of fun, and there are a variety of different strategies and weapons at your disposal to deal with opponents. Should you use some of your precious ammo to blow up a few gas tanks, or wear down their armor so you can rip off a wheel with the harpoon? Is it worth it to spend precious fuel on your car's flamethrower, or are your rims spiky enough to grind their car to scrap? Really, the only downside of car combat is the sometimes wonky as hell physics. A full-on crash sometimes barely moves either vehicle, yet barely scraping a barrier can send you into a wild airborne spin. Out in the world it's not so bad, but during certain story races it's absolutely maddening.   Other than the vehicle, the one thing that stands out is the storms. These things are TERRIFYING during the early game, and even late game you can find yourself in trouble if you're not careful. There are several different types, ranging from relatively low winds but with lighting which behaves more like artillery fire, to turbulent winds which blow debris hard enough to knock your car straight off the road, and send poor Max ragdolling a good fifty feet. They're really well done and a lot of fun, but sadly they don't really occur as often as I'd like.   Ground combat is pretty much ripped from Arkham Asylum / Shadow of Mordor style games. It's fun, it works well, and Max's punches definitely feel very weighty. Countering can become problematic due to the camera at times, because unlike the Batman games or Shadow of Mordor, the parry prompt isn't visible if the enemy is off screen, which can lead to some very frustrating moments. Furthermore sometimes parrying just doesn't seem to work in really 'busy' fights, however this might be my own fault (don't have that problem in SoM though). Still, it's a relatively minor issue.   The game is a solid 8. Good open world fun, good ground and fantastic car combat. It's nicely done if you can forgive the fact that it brings very few new ideas to the table, and can get pretty repetitive. Still, I recommend it to fans of the genre, doubly so for fans of the Mad Max franchise.

A fine consolidation of 'open-world' (think Far Cry 3) game elements, and some other things: * arkham combat * gta driving * shallow but significant crafting/base-building * decent (in some cases, great) npc characterization via writing and voice acting  My main complaint about this game is the design decision to use the same button do six things when it is sometimes possible to do two or more simultaneously--the logic sorting isn't always good so one may find oneself frequently picking up or dropping held things while attempting to loot. This problem is not unique to Mad Max, but it stood out in a user experience that largely includes pleasant, even familiar things. Also, making deeper characters of the friendly/enemy warlords and their bands would have made building up friendly bases and crushing enemy lairs even more satisfying. So, what do I think of Mad Max? Even with its weak storyline, it’s such a pleasure to play. Even though scrap collection can be tedious, it’s all worth it when you buy the upgrade you’ve been waiting for and you feel the improvement it makes to your cars handling and performance. The best way to describe the feeling I have about this game is that ... I am pleased.  I admire the world. The post apocalyptic desert with scarce resources and people a half way or more closer to becoming an animals.   The graphics and easiness that my computer dealt with it (2yrs old PC with Radeon R9 200) is really impressive.  I love the locations. Their diversity, they looks, their climate. The biggest surprise that you can make so much out of sand, dirt, stones, rocks, rust and scrap and maybe a little bit of human flesh as decoration. Hands down the best part of the game. I am really impressed with e.g. camps (the ones you take over). Surprising how different they are.  I really like the story. It is not long but both main story missions and wasteland ones are really good. One disadvantage is that there is not as many of them as it should be ... for my taste.  I quite enjoy the cars, their looks, the feel when driving, the scope and selection of modifiers they have and the battles in them. Also the possibility to free-roam almost everywhere is quite satisfying.   I also really liked the characters. There is not much of them but they are created quite well in regards of looks, characters, behaviour and dialogues. Max included.  The amount and quality of opponents is also more than enough.  The melee fights was something I had some problems with in terms of having fun but when I got used to it and developed my main character I started to have some enjoyment out of it. Keep in mind it is just not my kind of thing.  Now the things I do not like. The repetitiveness of other than main story and wasteland missions. Most people will find it tiresome and too boring after a while (mine sweeping yay). I stuck with it cause of other things (mentioned above). It is something many sandbox games are struggling with and Mad Max tries to balance it with other qualities. Nevertheless it is not the best result.   I do not like the bugs. Only good thing about them that there is not much of them and are mainly a minor ones. The game only crashed once so with over 90 hours it is quite a good result.  Boss fights. They are almost the same with little variety to actual fights (shotgun and shivs ftw).  General difficulty. You cannot change it and most of the time I found this game quite easy. There are some difficulty peaks (main story boss fight) but I died like 10 times and mostly cause I wanted to test out some things not of actual challenge.  And there it is. My recommendation? If the post apocalyptic world is your thing, you like the carmageddon style of driving and beating people with your fists makes you smile then go for it ... or if it is below 5€ ... then pick it up even just for the main story (around 20 hours).  EDIT: ... and I even cried once ...

If you love the Mad Max movies then you will find a lot to enjoy in the game. I brought it a few days after release and was immediately blown away by the visuals and detail - superb, especially in 4k.   Having said this it isn't a fantastic game, at times I found myself becoming frustrated with the tedious elements that you have to do over and over and over again to progress. Like collecting scrap - don't have a problem with finding and getting it but gets annoying when you keep having to wait for the timer circle everytime you do something. Same goes for filling your canteen and more - long winded and takes you away from the pace of the game.  The two main elements of fighting and driving are fun along with big boss fights but they get pretty easy. Even fighting the main bad guy towards the end was just a simple evade move, let him take a big swing then roll back and beat the c%^p out of him.  The best part of the game for me was building up the Magnum Opus, very rewarding as you amass enough scrap to attain each new part. One flaw tho was the v8 engine late on - so cool with the distinctive Mad Max hum taken straight from The Road Warrior movie, except you only get to use it for the last 20 mins or so of gameplay if just playing to the end of story mode. You even get the drive a carbon copy of Max's legendary 8 interceptor - at the very end of the story mode in the game.  There is also a really frustrating race where you have to destroy Stank Gun's big rig, took me about 20 attempts to get past that! Some forum fanboys say how they did it first time or found it easy - to me it frustratingly wasn't.  So all in all a good game but no classic, but I enjoyed it being a die hard fan of the Mad Max movies - tons of subtle references throughout the game, even a scene in a thunderdome at one point.  Will say this for it too - no glossy Hollywood happy ending here, the developer was very brave and dared to go full on and tread into the blackest territory at the end of story mode - but then that is the essence of Mad Max.  Recommended.

This was made great for PC, and looks and runs great on PC. Mad Max is overall a great open-world wasteland with everything being scarce, and you get to decide what yout want to do.
