Forget the critics, this is an excellent game. Immersion is great; very faithful to the mad max universe. Stretch of desolate wasteland, vehicular combat with large displacement machines, twisted characters, constant scarcity of resources (not so much in game mechanic terms as it is thematically), pretty much all of the elements of a mad max movie are there. All of it is convincingly depicted via terrific audio and visual aesthetics. The desert feels hot and dry and electric storms feels dangerous. I'm no audiophile but the way the game audio adds an extra 'oomph' when max's fist connects with someones face is so damn satisfying, more so than many brawlers out there.   Speaking of brawling, the combat is pretty simple. It uses the same ol' single button attack another for counter system popularized by Batman Arkham series. Even though it can get tiresome if repeated too often, on foot combat portion is spaced out far enough that I personally had no issue with it. The previously mentioned brutal aesthetic of fights does alleviate the monotomy of it somewhat. Plus outside of clearing out fortications, you do have the option of simply running enemies over with a car.   The other part of combat is the vehicular combat. Vehicles control is good and as expected. Didn't say tight and responsive since different cars under different circumstance will expectedly exhibit varying degree of control and responsiveness. In fact, it's surprising to me how realistic the cars control considering how bad I thought the vehicles in Avalanche's Just Cause were. Granted, it's no Colin Mcrae Rally but it does a suffient job of convincing me that there's a car running on a solid surface. When the game is running on all 8 cylinders and you find yourself in the middle of a hostile convoy at full speed, it's a realization of the movie video game cliche of 'being in the movie' even if it's fleeting.   It's equally solid gameplay wise, even if it is not particularly original or innovative. Despite having nothing to do with Ubisoft, the game is actually pretty reminiscent of the typical Ubi open world games. You get to an observation point (maybe solve a simple puzzle) and reveal different cookie cutter activities in an area. And then there are 'strongholds' in the area you have to clear out to reduce influence of the hostile factions. Rinse and repeat. I think most of the negative reviews are based on this aspect of the game. And that criticsm isn't without warrant; it does make the game feel recycled. But I feel like there are so many other things that this game does right that that lack of originality in overarching game structure can be easily overlooked. In any case, the game is at least worth a try at ~$30 especially if you are a mad max fan.

This made me stop playing the game once I completed it however it doesn't take away from the main campain. If you are at all into gathering collectables and scavenging, this is defenitely the game for you.   Overall the game is what Mad Max fans have been looking for. It is very immersive, its has nice subtle references to the films and as the strory progresses you meet individual and memorable characeters.  Final Verdict - I would say the game is a solid 8/10. Combat and story is great, car customisation could do with a bit of work and the repetativeness toned down a little.

I have spent a little bit of time with the game and have just completed it. Overall, I would say it was a pleasant experience and I can and cannot see why critics gave it mediocre reviews. Below are the pros and cons I experienced during my time:  PROS -The game looks very, very good. The weather effects look awesome; the landscape is beautiful; the key characters have good detail. -The story gets pretty good, once you get to Gastown -- given all the criticism given to the game in regards to lack of story, makes me wonder whether critics just gave up on the game before getting to the climax portions. -The combat is fun and brutal -- if you like Batman style combat without any restraint on killing people, you will like this. I liked how the shotgun can be used during combat and how you could eliminate troublesome enemies quickly with it. -Overall, the car combat is quite fun and, once you get your rocket launcher (exploading harpoon), it becomes a blast -Using the harpoon on the Magnum Opus is very fun during car combat, as you can do lots of things, like pulling off the wheels of cars and harpooning land pedestrians and flinging them halfway across the map (Just Cause style) -The upgrade system for the car and Max are good, if not standard now for these kinds of games -Some of the setpieces and battles are pretty cool (e.g., going into an abandoned burried airport or church, with enemies surprising you in the dark) -The atmosphere is very bleak, which suits the character -The game ran well on my low end gaming PC. Optimized to a 'T'. -The voice acting was really good and I enjoyed Max's stern reserved hero characterization. The actor did quite well.  CONS -The majority of the gameplay revolves around doing very, very repetative missions. There are 4 major territories in the game, each with 4 sections with things that need to be cleared and scrap to be found. All the territory clearing missions consist of the same 5 types of missions (searching for mine fields, taking down totems, clearing bases, destroying a carravan of bad guys, or killing snipers) and random scrap bases. If you are like me, and like to try to get 100% clear in zones, you will find yourself getting worn out by the time you even get to Gastown. By hour 40, I was really slogging away, starting to get burnt out of doing the same things over and over again. This seems like really lazy gamplay design, and quite common for this genre. If it weren't for this aspect, I am sure the average critic review would have been over 8 easily. -Because of the above, the game has no replay value. Who would want to do all those same, boring, side missions again? There is no game + mode either. Once you are done with this game, you are most likely done. That said, I got 60+ hours out of the game, which isn't bad value. -The game is too easy. There was little challenge in the game, except for one racing mission. -The cars handle pretty poorly. For most of the game I didn't realize how poor the cars handled until a mission where I had to race on a real enclosed racing track. Then I realized that driving the car, even with all the upgrades in the game unlocked is like driving on ice. You will find that when you run over a rock or barely clip a wall your car will ALWAYS spin around, stop and face the opposite direction of the one you were facing previously. This can be pretty frustrating during races. -There is a notoriously bad racing mission in the game that comes out of the blue and took numerous tries to beat, not because it in itself was hard, but because the very poor car handling controls made it hard. -You need a controller for this game. From what I can tell, the game is pretty awkward using a keyboard and mouse. -There is basically no character development until you are almost done with the game. Probably the most regrettable flaw of the game is the lack of story throughout the game. The story content that is there is superb, but it only makes you realize how empty the rest of the game (the majority of the game) was. -There are bugs in the game. I found myself at times when trying to pick up scrapped warping through floors. Some climbing locations are not marked with yellow, like every other climbing location. Some scrap was not labled like every other. The UI suddenly disappeared sometimes. The fast travel and summoning Chumbucket was very inconsistent in working. And more. Overall, it was pretty smooth experience, but beware of bugs. -The sandstorms that randomly occur in the world are cool the first two times, as they look neat, kick your butt and are a great source for scrap. HOWEVER, the rest of the game they are super annoyance. They are annoying because you cannot fast travel while they occur and they take 10 MINUTES!!! So, if you are on your way to just complete a basic mission to clear a zone and sandstorm occurs, be prepared to just run around trying to live and wait it out. This became increasingly frustrating as I was trying 100% zones. Sometimes I would just come into the game and leave a base and it would immediately tell me beware of a sandstorm... if that occurs, just go back into the base or leave the game and come back in and the storm will be gone. -The day night cycle TAKES FOREVER! You probably won't notice the day/night cycle, except its aesthetics, for most of the game, until you get to two sidemissions that require you to do something at night and it is daytime. There is no way to speed up the clock and, if you log out, and come back, the cycle will be at the beginning of whatever part you were at previously. Thus, if you log out during the day, it will be morning. Therefore, the only way to get to these missions and make it night, is either go off and do something else in the game until it turns night or just sit there with the game out and check back later. Given that these missions occur near the end, and, if you had been clearing stuff out as you went along with little else to do, this will be a bit frustrating. -The combat was fun, but it didn't feel as smooth as some of the other Batman Arkham type games. -Some of the bleakness was a bit over-the-top, especially in regards to the 'relics' you find, which are pictures from the world prior to the apocalypse. For example, you will find a cheerful picture of a little kid with some stuff written on the back about the kid being turned into 'raspberry spray' and then Max will make some depressing remark about how we are in hell. I guess this fits the world he lives in, but the 'doom and gloom' of every comment does grate on you after hours and hours of play, especially once you start to realize that he is making the same comment over and over again with just new words. -There is car collecting in the game, but I didn't see the point of it, as every other car in the game pales in comparison to your main vehicle, as they don't have harpoons and the like. They tell you when you get in the car that you have some sort of stealth towards a faction, but it hardly works and usually as you drive past that faction, they will realize who you are in about 5 secs, if not before.   Though I do have a lot of negatives, and I probably wouldn't touch the game again in the future, I did have a fun experience and it was worth the discounted price I paid. The story at the end was pretty moving and and it saved the game from a lower score. I would probably give this game a 8/10, with the hope that it gets a sequel so they can try to resolve all the issues I listed above. If they made the game much more story centric and less rinse-and-repeat missions, it would be pretty amazing. If you are thinking about buying this game now, I suggest you wait and buy it on sale, as some places were selling it at 40% off at launch, which I image was because Warner Bros. just wanted to get the game out after all the trouble during the development cycle and figured it was going to bomb.

Car combat is great, and the convoy chases and explosions feel straight out the film. Less faithful is the ground combat: Max can disinterestedly take out dozens of enemies with his bare hands, a stark contrast to the brutal ferocity that he would, in a more realistic way, need to focus on single enemies in the movies (yeah yeah, it's a videogame). You'll also never have to contend with mis-firing shotguns, and will almost always have ample fuel. As such, it's not The True Mad Max Experience, but at least give it points for coming close.

I've spent hours in this game and the only problem I ran into was a little wonkiness in the garage menu but it was minor.  The combat system both on foot and in the car are very satisfying. The upgrade system on your car pushes you out into the world to gain more scrap just so you can have that extra boost/tweak to make your 'own' interceptor.  Get your video recording software ready on this one because the physics are top notch, you'll want to hit the record button just so you can relive the moment. I had a buggy heading right at me when the magnum opus was badly damaged, he hits a bump that launches him into the air a bit just as I was blowing up the car next to him. The explosion caused his buggy to explode which launched him into the sky like a rocket. Could'nt stop laughing....wished I had recorded it.  The story is decent but you actually end up exploring the world so much you tend to forget you're on one until you need that required part for your car. The world is really depressing and disgusting but yet beautiful at the same time. The capture mode system in this game is amazing, to be able to pause the game erase the HUD, adjust your camere settings/angle to take the perfect shot is something I hope future game developers implement into their games. Like I said, a lot can take pointers on the development of this game. Buy this game! After 50+ hours sunk into this game (single playthrough!!), I can tell you this: A very small number of games managed to captivate me this much in terms of its setting and subsequent possibilites. Here is the main positives gist version: - The vast desert, strongholds, wrecks, open sand dunes, they all create a desolate world so sO SO worth exploring,  - Customization (both character and car) is off the charts for an open world title.  - Graphics range from above average to HOLY SHEET!, depending on the scenery. Overall it is truly eye-candy in terms of art direction and color palette, I honestly loved it. - Sound is sweet as hell if you have the appropriate sound system. With a 7.1, the gunshots, punches (Fury mode !!) and engine sounds were a true treat. Obviously hearing authentic australian accents is a plus too:) - Car/fist fights. The core of the game. And yes, AAA action game/movie caliber. I dare anyone to dispute this.  - And last, but not least: it runs like a dream. Seriously. Knife through butter kind of smooth. This is how games are supposed to ship in the first place, so take note everyone else. But nevertheless, Avalanche did a stand up job here!  The story is passable, but then again, I did not expect Witcher/Mass Effect complexities in the 1st place. It is simple, with a few turns here and there. Enjoyable. I might have expected a bit more variation in the side quests or available stranger stuff, but I honestly cannot fault this game for that, as practically every other open world has the same, if not worse issues. No biggie, its the story + setting + options that count. And in this, Mad Max truly succeeds. My darkhorse for 2015 is exactly that. Bravo !

I love the Mad Max movies, and my love for Mad Max got reinjected with Fury Road.   With the game, I first noticed that it was developed by Avalanche Studios, a swedish game studio known for Just Cause-series. One of the absolutelty best Open World experience there is. So with the Mad Max game, I get the best of two worlds, being able to play and live as Mad Max and enjoy the wasteland as an open world.  My first experience with Mad Max was with TotalBiscuits PC-Port Report, and after that I decided to get the game.   So after a +25h of gameplay I am very glad that I did purchase the game, because it is really worth every little $$$ spent on it. The game is so rich of content, even if some may find it very repetitive, but I love it. I love Open World and I love exploring. The graphics is really amazing, and I can't wait for Just Cause 3. Even if I run the game with a 660 TI OC, I can still cramp up the graphics quality. I run smoothly at 60FPS.   The gameplay itself I find very enjoyable, I fínd a good balance between fighting with vehicle and fighting on foot. I love the fact that it really takes time to save up scrap (money). It is really amusing to just drive around and doing silly stuff or just waste time. I do agree that the story telling aint that strong, compared to other games, but I don't really see that is what Avalanche Studios wanted with this game, they wanted a beautiful Open World game with so much content instead. It wouldn't even surprise me if this was a intended joke, to other games in the genre.   It is above average, it is, but for me, I really do enjoy it, and I do not regret buying this game at all. It is worth all it's money.

First off I would like to say I don't normally like this style of game. Assassins Creed was a game I loved for the first two hours and hated the next 4 until I found myself not wanting to play it at all anymore. I didn't get this game for the reason of that and after watching some streams the game just looked like it might be great for killing time. Turns out I love it and even though I hated the rinse and repeat of AC towns, I find 77 hours later still loving the game.  Pros The three button combat is so well done I actually forget that it really isn't my style of action game. The driving and harpooning people just never gets old. So much upgrades and side quests to take hours, but most of the stuff not really required. Optimization, the game runs so smooth and I think that is the second biggest reason why combat is so fun.  Graphics and storms really look sharp overall.  Cons Mine fields (they just are so boring, but the plus is I haven't seen where they are required to do). Can get to overpowered if you find yourself enjoying the game and doing everything. A glitchy instant death. Overall I have 77 hours in and had the game a week. About 20 hours is probably AFK time to be honest. Some of it is just because I was trying to see if I got scrap faster while AFK versus offline and I didn't notice a difference to be honest. And the other is just the main menu running in the back ground while I stepped away.   I can't give you a score for you, but for me it is a 10/10. The game draws me in and the other night I started playing at 6 PM and before I knew it was midnight. Decided I wanted to finish up what I was doing and one thing led to another and it was 2 AM. Hard to complain about that entertainment value when the game cost me 22 buck!

Amazing sandbox game and I'm hooked, not immediately but gradually as the story unfold and the world opens up. I started off as a skeptic of this game, thinking i might have wasted money for a mediocre action game, as many movie based games are. At first glance, the graphics seemed a bit primitive at close up. Character models, furnitures and buildings are somewhat low polygon but serviceable. The open world felt inaccessible at first and many fun things are hidden from plain sight. But as i played on, i began to explore the nooks and crannies of this barren wasteland, and taking part in all the activities the game has to offer like car races, convoy raids, base takdowns, mine sweeping with Max's dog etc., and just surviving in the vast open world, i started to become one with Max and his car. Without a doubt, the outdoor environment and car combat are the highlights of this game. And when you spend a lot of time on the road by yourself with your car in a hostile environment, the world and the road began to take on a dangerous and personal outlook as crazies from the apocalypse start to scream at you chasing you off the road with their modded cars complete with spikes.   There is a lot of survival things you can do on your own in this game, such as finding water, food, gasoline and scraps in various camps that dot the map, or more dangerously by clearing out random caves or enemy bases populated by menacing enemies, some with red glowy eyes that looks especially menacing at night. The unarmed enemies on foot are generally not a match for Max but i still find myself in more than a few tight spots early in the game, as ammo is scarce in this game and you can quickly become outnumbered and surrounded by your enemies. Some even wield knives that are unblockable and can only be dodged. They would attack you when you are busy fighting the unarmed ones and do a lot of damage. Later on in the game you will fight enemies armed with shields and heavy weapons, which are deadly and even more so combined with dozens of unarmed ones that constantly harass you making you fight them while the heavily armed one charges you with unblockable attacks. There are even suicide bombers. In short, melee combat can be quite intense and challenging. These enemies don't wait around and take turns to have a swing at you like in Shadow of Mordor, they come at you all at the same time and they want you dead. For your character to level up and unlock new gears, you have to do missions or favors for NPCs and side quests, gears like jacket/armor to enhance your health, wrist guard to enhance your blocking power, ammo belt for extra ammo and shivs, and new fighting moves to help you in melee combat, which you definately need as enemy grows stronger. There is also a whole range of upgrades for your car such as tires, suspensions, engines, spikes, grappling hook, sniper rifle, flamethrower/sideburner etc.. The detail in this game is very deep and not at all apparent for people who only plays the game for a short amount of time.   I truely feel immersed and living the life of a wasteland wanderer, maybe more so than even the last fallout game could deliver. Fallout always felt small in terms of scope, but the world of Mad Max is huge and truely menacing but also eerily beautiful. At least for me i now see the Mad Max franchise becoming a strong contender to the fallout franchise in the post-apocalyptic genre. In the future, I hope they make Max completely customizable (name, appearance, voice etc.) so that we can create our own version of him/her, games like mass effect, fallout and knights of the old republic all have a market version and player versions of the main character, even the latest metal gear solid is allowing players to create their own solid snake, so i don't see why it can't be done.   My favorite thing to do is exploring the wasteland on my trusted Magnum Opus, complete with its hunchback mechanic that can repair your car even from near-explosion. With a press of a button, he would climb from the back of the car over the roof to the front hood. And it is quite amusing to watch him work from the driver's view :D The game is 3rd person while you are on foot and on wheels, but there is a very versatile 1st person driver view, and i frequently use it during open world exploration, car races, and even during car combat to get that full-on immersion ie. shooting your shotgun from your window during car chase at close range with the help of the game's slow-motion system for aiming. I can see myself continue to play this game after finishing the main story if the game permits it. I will certainly be a customer when they release DLCs for this game. And i hope they introduce a playable female character in one of the DLCs. It is quite an achievement how the game manage to faithfullly recreate the world of Mad Max from the movies and especially from Fury Road. The Cars, the enemies and the eerily beautifully desolate world in the game, they all look and feel like a natural extention to the films. Lastly, it is worth mentioning that the game has day/night cycle and full weather system complete with its own thunderstorms and sandstorms that come and go as they please. I have never experienced something quite like the storms in this game. Watching a huge 100 feet tall and miles wide storm front catching up on you from your rear view mirror as you zoom across the barren landscape in your fast car looking for shelter was quite the jaw-dropping experience. Nuances like these are like icing on a cake for making the game world feel that much more alive and menacing.

This is more of a first impressions review, but I am loving this game so far. I'm just gonna give a brief rundown of the game, and what I think about each section. At time of writing I have put 5.4 hours into the game.  Performance/Graphics On max settings, this game looks gorgeous. Now my rig could handle it at first, but once the world opened up a little more I did start to experience some slowdowns, but just dialing some settings back I could keep it at high resolutions with 60fps+ and it still looks great. Overall, really well optimized, but make sure you have the hardware for the higher settings.  Gameplay The gameplay on-foot isn't as good as in a vehicle, but it's still good, but it's not great. The melee combat is good, but I still wish they could've used a different system other than the FreeFlow. It works, and it's pretty simple to use and it is satisfying with the animations and the sound effects. And the vehicle combat is fantastic. Just the vehicles in general are amazing. With the customization and the way they handle, it's so much fun and it makes them a necessity in the game just like they are in the world. There is no handbrake, but I'm okay with that.  Sound I love the sound effects and what I've heard of the soundtrack so far. It's right up my alley with the heavy guitars and drums and all that good stuff. It's very similar to the movie soundtrack, so if you liked that, you'll love this too. Cars sound gorgeous and the guns sound good, but they could have more punch to them. Overall, the sound is good, although I did have a bug where Max stuttered on one of his lines for a second or two, then it was fine.  Bugs Speaking of bugs, I've seen two so far in the 5 hours that I've been playing. One was the sound glitch I mentioned already, and another where the cutscene froze for a second, but then it caught back up and it was fine. Like I said, performance was great and I haven't seen any other bugs that I can remember.  Overall This game so far is really well put together. My only issue with it is that there is a fair amount of grinding to get some of the car parts/Max's gear and it takes more grinding on top of that to afford the parts. But that's taken a little bittersweet, because that means you get to do more of the combat and traveling around and exploring to get the currency for these upgrades. I'm having a blast with it so far, and if you have any doubts about getting it, it's worth the $60 in my honest opinion. And I can see myself playing it even after I beat the main story, and perhaps even going for 100% completion for it.

Fantastic open world game by Avalanche Studios, made with the license of Mad Max Fury Road (the new one with Tom Hardy). The game looks great while running at a stable 120fps on max settings. The game sounds fantastic (especially the motors/exhausts and explosions) and has good audio settings (device, speaker type, dynamics). The vehicular combat is innovative (deeper than RAGE) and fun. Melee combat is Arkham style but a bit harder since you can't automatically parry every direction and the camera is a bit closer, you need to actually press the direction + parry button, which means you shouldn't get surrounded. Voice artist for main sidekick 'Chumbucket' is amazing, sounds just like the movie. I wish the game had more vehicular combat, as the regular combat is kinda boring.  Similar to Shadow of Mordor, the wonder wore off after some repetition. I 100% cleared the first area, 80% cleared the second, ~40% cleared the third and don't give a rats ♥♥♥ about the fourth. There are strongholds in each area and you can unlock buildings there which replenish your resources, but unlocking this multiple times is too much of a hassle. I'd rather fast travel to a fully upgraded stronghold and then fast travel back to another one. It's unfulfilling that most of the income is passive through unlocked camps. The only other big income are Scrapulances (special rare vehicles full of scrap which have to be driven to a stronghold) and scrap pallets during storms. Both of these are unreliable. The scrap rewards during normal gameplay do not scale. This is ok since scaling rewards would be unrealistic and wouldn't work that well with an open game world. The passive income scales naturally, but this also means that it eclipses all other sources of scrap.  Is this a design weakness or a design strength? I've played so much that I don't want to pick up every single piece of scrap. The camps got repetitive, so I stopped doing those. I'm a bit disappointed in the boss fights, they're very simplistic and samey. I'd rather have had more vehicular boss fights than melee ones.  I'm giving it a thumbs up since it's great during the first third and it's normal for games in this genre to get repetitive after a while. For my taste, these games should be shorter, but there have to be people who like the 'extra content'.

Mad Max is a very polarizing game. Although the Metascore is very solid, the individual critic reviews can range from positive to negative. But I've never found myself more satisfied by and more addicted to a game than Mad Max! This game, in a nutshell, is 'scrumptious', and you'll come back for more if you love open world games that have lots of objectives to fulfill.  Here's a summary of the positives (+) and negatives (-) so far, which will be added to as gameplay time goes on:  + Extremely well optimized and beautiful. This is one of the very few games that won't make your PC feel substandard and ancient if you had mid range hardware. Breathtaking all around, with a few average textures here and there that barely hurt the visuals. It's smooth as butter, with an excellent selection of video options.  + Very cool progression system. Leveling up in Mad Max is a joy filled with lots of fun rewards! His appearance even evolves over the course of the game!  + 'Car porn' are two words to describe Mad Max. There's a ton of customization and ways to make your vehicle truly yours. Vehicle combat is high octane and adrenaline pumping, but only after you unlock higher level harpoons and other weapons!  + Excellent characters that are often quite interesting, especially a few of the main characters and villains. Chumbucket is funny, and a charming companion for your journey. Griffa has an excellent aura of mysticism and mystery.  +/- The game IS a collect-a-thon, but is that a really bad thing? It encourages exploration around the various beautifully desolate locales. Yeah, it's not like Banjo Kazooie or something of the sort, but I don't understand why this aspect of open world games is considered so bad. Maybe to critics who tend to hate random busywork, it's bad, but for the average gamer who loves to fill up meters to 100%, collecting is quite fun in Mad Max! Many items actually affect things, such as scrap which is used as currency.  +/- Ground combat can be a mixed bag. I personally enjoy it a lot. The sound effects have impact, especially when your fist meets the faces of your many foes, but the cinematic combat is really just two or three buttons you push the whole time. Is that a bad thing? Perhaps, but it feels satisfying as hell to see how one button can cause so many varied and cinematic attacks to appear on screen. I don't agree that it's better than let's say, Devil May Cry, but I do like how it aggregates fancy combos into one button, and it's always fun to parry attacks then counter at the right time. Special finishers, weapons, and moves help add flavor to it.  - Ran into at least one gamebreaking bug that forced me to shut the game off, and the other bugs are minor. The most useful and strange bug caused enemies to vanish entirely during battle. Mostly random encounters on the road.  - There might be TOO MUCH to do, it's easy to get sidetracked for hours on end, spoiling the narrative flow. If you want to get to the heart of Mad Max, you'll have to skip a lot of the side content which makes up a majority the game in general.  - Some side objectives are repetitive as hell, but somehow I still enjoy them. But the game does indeed borrow heavily from other open world games... especially the 'vantage points'.  - Game does tend to lose performance in some car battles, or when there's a large number of enemies on the screen. Dense areas will lose some performance.  - Car combat is weak at the beginning of the game.  - Progression on Max, and his vehicle, is very linear. There is no reason to choose previously unlocked equipment... but baffingly, you can, which hurts your stats. Some vehicle customization options will lower stats, such as top speed or acceleration, giving some depth to it, but there is zero repercussions for using any upgrade for Max.  - The thunderpoon is an overpowered car weapon that is the definition of 'dominant strategy'... in the end game. There is no reason to use the awkward harpoon or any other weapon when you can just one hit kill every enemy vehicle with a fully upgraded thunderpoon.  - The currency, Scrap, becomes pointless in the end game. There is no reason to aquire it besides for fun when everything is upgraded and bought.

I liked this game enough to play it 70+ hrs and get every achievement. Having paid full price on pre-order, I still feel that I got most of my money's worth out of it in enjoyment. That being said, if you get the game on discount you will probably feel better about the purchase afterwards.   The themes of post-apocaliptia, scavenging for limited resources and exploring the ruins of a bygone era all things that appeal to me as a fan of the Mad Max world. The added bonus of vehicular mayhem with a somewhat customizeable car certainly adds alot of potential fun factor.  What this game does right:  - Stylistic atmosphere and graphics (lighting, smoke effects, wind and dust, explosions... good stuff)  - Crazy car vs. car combat with limited adherence to real world physics makes for a fun arcade feel  - Varied, but not overly difficult ground combat, with multiple ways (with skill upgrades) to eliminate enemies in gloriously brutal fashion  - Colorful and interesting NPC character models  - Varied enemy types and their respective combat techniques and day/night appearance of alternate enemies keeps fights from feeling overly repetitive  - Making each location to explore unique enough that the numerous 'fetch-quests' give you reason to really explore the open world provided without it growing too stale  - Opportunity to race your car in 'Death Races'  - Mostly good in-game engine cutscenes  - 60fps highly optimized PC Port (with minor menu flubs)  Where this game falls short:  - This game is crazy easy for any mildly experienced gamer  - No pressure for survival as all resources are abundant and/or need is completely nullified through game progress  - Limited story provides no real opportunity to become attached to main character or any NPC  - Apart from achievement, no reason at all to do 'Death Races' since rewards are nil/laughable  - Mixing and matching car upgrades is pointless... best is best, period  - In-game currency of 'scrap' is so abundant and easy to acquire that intermediate character and car upgrades could easily be bypassed for top quality gear too early in gameplay providing no feel of progression  - Limited or no tutorialistic explanation of simple game elements (how to quickly abort a failed race run or progress in the story) leads to avoidable web-searching frustration  - Major bosses feel extremely 'cookie-cutter' in a boring way  - One really stupid and nonsensical cutscene (if you play, you'll see it)  Overall, the game had a fair balance of pros & cons that neither made nor ruined the game for me. Play this game for the atmosphere and the arcade style simplicity. Don't play this game for the story or the survival aspect. This is a casual game with ZERO replayability. Purchase with hefty discount is reccomended.

Mad Max, the game based on the the movie franchise with the same name.  The game takes place after some sort of apochalypse, so all the oceans have dried up (Don't ask me how, but that's just how it is) and you are just driving around in the desert looking for fuel to your car, the Interceptor. As you are out to refuel your car a huge bodybuilder with a rhino horn pen*s and a chainsaw staff called  ''Scabrous Scrotus''  appeared with his big @$$ car the  ''Land Mover''  and stole the Interceptor. You jump onto the Land Mover just as it drives away and try to get it back, stabs Scrotus with his own chainsaw staff in the head, get thrown off the Land Mover, and then you have nothing to do but to walk, then all of a sudden you find someone called  ''Chumbucket''  that promise you to make a car for you, he calls that car the  ''Magnum Opus'' . And as the game goes along, you keep upgrading the Magnum Opus until it become a fortress on wheels. The game is focused a lot on car combat, you can ram, grind burn, shoot and pull your enemies in it, and the game has got great ground combat too, it's practically the exact same as in the Batman: Arkham franchise.   More game developers need to learn how to optimize their games properly, in this game we have seen EXACTLY how good well-optimized games can run and still look beautiful. In my rig I have a GTX 660 (For those who don't know what it is, a 3 year old mid-range video card, which isn't that great) and i can still run this game smooth as butter (constant 60fps) on high graphic setting.  The game really looks great, while driving around in the wasteland you get the feeling of having dust in your mouth.  If you like Middle-Earth: Shadow of Mordor you will definitely LOVE this game. The gameplay is prectically the same but better in my opinion.  I give this game 10/10, because everytime I play it I have a great time, and that's what I think all games should be like.

OK, I haven't played enough to do an in-depth review of it, but I have a couple concerns about this game that arose in the veeeery earliest missions:     Evidently, the Australian Wasteland is coated with black ice, butter, and banana peels, because that's what it feels like to drive on it. Mildly tight turns might as well be Lombard Street.    Starts off...oddly. After playing the MGSV prologue, I guess my expectations were a bit high from the get-go, but it definitely feels rushed.    Fighting feels competent, if a little boring. It definitely feels like you're actually hitting people hard, rather than giving them little love taps.    WHY THE F**K IS MAX TALKING SO MUCH? It seems like, in trying to adapt him into a video game character, they've kinda lost, like, one of his only character traits. In this, so far, he seems to be '3rd person action hero #7' rather than Max Rocktansky. I can see where they're coming from, but not many people have a problem with Chelle or Gordan Freeman, so I don't know why Max needs so many lines of dialogue.    The port here is  excellent . I simply  cannot  get it to run below ~120fps with everything set to the Max. I do have a GTX 980 and a 4790K, so it wasn't gonna run badly  anyway , but Avalanche did a seriously good job with this one, which I guess is to be expected at this point from them.    The devs seem very keen on adding mini cutscenes for things that didn't need them (e.g. putting gas in the back of the car, drinking water, and eating food.) It makes the whole flow of the game feel very disjointed, especially since the game fades to black whenever one of them ends. I don't understand why they couldn't just have that stuff be a part of gameplay.   So, I'm gonna finish this off with a table, and will be updating my score with time played, so you can see how it grows on me.       Time Played   Score/10         45 min.    6/10 (above average, but nothing to write home about)     3 hours    7.5/10 (actually pretty enjoyable, and definitely above average.)

I've already wrote a brief review of this title on reddit, but I'll expand more on here...  ---  Mad Max is probably one of the most optimized PC games. Lots of graphical options to tune, and maintains a nice fps in nearly any setup. A thing to note is that under Audio there's a setting to turn on Fury Mode, which amps all the sounds in the game. It's not so that it's louder but everything's much more furious and raspier, as the mode is named with. I'd recommend trying it out as it gives the game a much more grittier feel.   In terms of looks the game looks stunning. It's a treat to even drive around the region. And those sandstorms - they're pretty intense! It's even crazier than FO4's rad storms!  In terms of gameplay it's a little repetitive. I'd compare it to JC3 because in Mad Max you're basically reducing Scrotus' and Stank Gum's influence in each region, much like in JC3 where you reduce the DRM's influence. However Mad Max does it a bit better because there's a number of ways to reduce influence, whether it's taking down oil wells, removing scarecrows, or removing convoys off the map.  Other stuff you can do is take out scarecrows, take out snipers, blow up Buzzard lairs, find high-value cars (for some reason these aren't explicitly tracked), build Archangels (basically special variants of your main car that require certain upgrades to build), do Death Runs (sort-of like races but with twists), and so on. Basically there's a lot of stuff to do. As of this review I'm still not done. So in terms of replayability there's a good amount. But I doubt I'll be repeating another playthrough, as the story itself is very linear.   Vehicular combat isn't very common in games these days, but Mad Max gets it right. Eliminating convoys for example are surprisingly lots of fun. And you have plenty of tools to take them out, like the Harpoon or the Thunderpoon (aka a rocket launcher). Outside of convoys you'll run into War Boys or Stank Gum itching for a fight, but sometimes they won't even chase you, either because you're too fast or they won't bother. These guys don't seem to provide very much loot, so it's better to ignore them.   Speaking of combat there's also on-foot combat. That means that you can upgrade Max, so you can spend your Scrap on more skills or better gear. Now onto combat: It's a bit like Batman, but isn't. Meaning there's no actual flow to it. Max can enter Fury which boosts his attacks, but it doesn't introduce anything jaw-dropping. There's also different archetypes of enemies which spices things up but you still throw the same punches. Top Dogs act as bosses but they all seem to have the same moveset and weapon.  I honestly thought there was gonna be combat where Max would get out of his car, climb onto the roof and fend off the guy next to him. A bit like in the movie Fury Road. Abit disappointed there wasn't one.   The story is good but not groundbreaking or anything. Max himself is almost like a silent protagonist and takes favors as long as he gets something in return. There's also Wasteland missions but those are basically fetch quests. The characters you meet are interesting (like Gutgash) but they aren't that developed (however their respective Wasteland Missions expand on their intent). The history relics you find in the world tell sad tales of the past and how it became as it is now. Max commentating on the relics are a nice touch (some of what he says are surprisingly profound). There's also Wasteland encounters you find when you explore the wasteland. Most of those are just jargon that you already knew, but some of them can provide Intel to help in taking a difficult camp. But there's the odd encounter or so that made me pretty depressed, really bringing out that it's really the end of the world.   Much of the upgrades in this game don't seem very worth it, especially the Griffa tokens. Mostly because the game is inherently easy. Though once you unlock the northen region the game gets much tougher, while the southern region is exceptionally easy.  Plus in spite of being a post-apocalyptic game there aren't many hardcore or survival aspects. Max doesn't get hungry or thirsty, so eating food or drinking your canteen only heals you. And fuel is plentiful and declines slowly enough to not worry about (there is a weapon that uses fuel though).   Each region has a Stronghold that houses the main guy of that region, like Jeet or Deep Friah, as well as their followers. You can improve these places by setting out and finding project parts to construct Water Storages or Maggot farms. These projects provide Max instant full water or instant full ammo when you enter the Stronghold, as well as improving the looks of the place. While the projects do make searching for water or gas redundant, bear in mind that there's a time limit after you get your stuff, so it kinda forces you to go out and find more sources. Of course that only affects the Stronghold you've entered. Additionally some projects are unavailable until you've done the main guy's Wasteland missions.  The game's 'currency' is Scrap, and you find it pretty much anywhere. You can earn them through clearing camps, so allies can populate 'em to deliver you Scrap every once of a while. You can also find them in places that you can loot, off of cars you take out, and so on. There's even a project in the Strongholds that adds Scrap when your game is off! Essentially it doesn't really run out. Of course you spend the Scrap on upgrades or improving Strongholds. However a lot of the upgrades require prerequisites to be done first. This can be like doing Wasteland missions or achieving a certain level.  Speaking of levels, you can gain more levels by completing Challenges. I don't personally track 'em but getting upgrades that require a certain level take some time. Fortunately the bulk of the Challenges come pretty naturally so they don't become a huge chore.   All in all Mad Max is a great PC title that's optimized and has pretty engaging gameplay. In terms of story I'd say it's decent but it isn't Undertale or anything.     Recommend?  If you want a nicely optimized PC title, yes.  If you want good vehicular combat, yes.

What a lovely game. Mad Max takes The Road Warrior and Fury Road and runs with it. What you get is an open world game with a lovely wasteland. The developers made each of the regions look distinct and they are crammed with stuff to do: places to loot, camps to take apart, scarecrows to pull down, snipers to neutralize, and so forth. You also get to upgrade friendly strongholds, whose inhabitants will slowly go from utterly despising you to pointing you out to their friends as your legend grows. The story is interesting and there are a wealth of side missions to go on.   Hand-to-hand combat is a simplified version of the battle system found in the Batman: Arkham games, with one button to strike and one button to counter. You also have a shotgun and can pick up melee or throwable weapons off the ground. Along the way, you will upgrade Max and be able to pull off special finishing and counter moves that add variety to the combat, which otherwise moves along at a steady clip.   The main feature of the game is, of course, your car. The black-on-black gets stolen at the beginning of the game, but Max gets a new friend (Chumbucket) who want to build a new car called the Magnum Opus. As you level up Max and engage in various missions, you will be able to unlock new upgrades for the car that can be installed if you have enough scrap to pay for them. The car is as much a character in the game as Max, Chumbucket, and any of the other people in the game. It is also a delight to drive this vehicle around the wasteland and use its harpoon to take down gates or, with the 'thunderpoon' upgrade, make opposing vehicles explode.   All in all, this is really a terrific experience that has kept me capivated from the moment that I first started playing. The game looks gorgeous and runs great, and it's the closest thing to actually being in one of the Mad Max movies. I really recommend that you give this game a go.  Edit: I have finished the game and must admit that the last two or so story missions have soured the experience a bit for me. I don't want to spoil the story, but let's say that the ending doesn't really fit what we've seen of Mad Max in the movies. Once the final cutscene played out, I was dropped back in the wasteland, but I had zero interest in continuing to play and ended up uninstalling instead. Still, I really enjoyed the 40 hours I spent cruising the desert and would still recommend the game. I don't see myself replaying it again, though -- at least, not for a long while.

First things first: this is a great game. Some of the critics gave this game average reviews, which I think was undeserved. The gameplay seems to draw in elements from lots of different third-person open world games in a way that really works. The game itself is beautiful and really easy to get immersed in. If you play for long enough you really get that feeling of bleakness and despair driving around the wasteland.  That being said, some of the complaints for this game are fair. I'm going to point some of these out because if they make a sequel, I hope they improve on some of these aspects:  -The customization is bad. The game sort of markets itself on giving you the ability to create your very own Magnum Opus. Unfortunately, there doesn't seem like there's a whole lot of customization options when it comes to designing the look of your car. You can mix and match different upgrades, but for the most part the cosmetic options are pretty limited. For a Mad Max game, this is pretty bad.  -Some of the side missions are repetitive and monotonous. Throughout the game you have to clear out camps, scarecrows, minefields, etc. in order to reduce the threat level in the different areas. Some of these can be pretty fun, but some of them, such as the minefields, can be pretty tedious. A lot of the car upgrades require that you reduce the threat level a lot, so you will be forced to do a lot of these if you want the best upgrades.  -The story really only picks up during the second half of the game, mostly at the end. Sure, there are little side stories when you go to the individual strongholds, but they're not very in depth. For a vast majority of the game there's not a whole lot of story elements going on, you're mostly running around and taking care of side missions, clearing out camps, scavenging, etc.

This is one of those games that's great but leaves you wanting more. The game itself looks great, runs great, is genuinely fun and is generally free from bugs. The few that were there at release were taken care of quickly. It immerses you in the world of post apocalyptic Australia really well where the only thing in abundance is blood and oil. Even remembered to make the cars right-hand drive. Max out your graphics if you can and you'll forget it's a game and not a movie during the amazing looking cutscenes. It's one of those games that is so good that it feels way too short. It's just a linear story with a few missions but with a serious jump in difficulty between each one since you're meant to build your car and yourself up in between them. If you're that hardcore you can bulldoze your way through the main story in half a day but if you're a completionist who doesn't want to fight the last boss without having your car and Max be as badass as possible then it is going to take awhile. It has really nice feeling driving of course as well as a surprisingly satisfying melee combat system. There's sniping and racing and bomb defusing with your bomb disposal dog. It has strongholds that are tough to fight your way through and have a collectathon feel to finding all the hidden collectables and there are no hints to guide you. Not just that though as you can collect most of the cars in the game by simply taking it and driving it home. I don't usually approve of DLC but I would really love some more things to explore, cars to drive, and more customization for the hero car. It gives a lot of freedom in how you can play. You can build a car for ramming or grinding or speed and eventually all of the above. Make a lowered speed demon or a lifted rat rod or something in the middle. It's not like a racing game where you just blindly upgrade it though as most mods add in one aspect but equally subtract in another. Also for maximum immersion play with headphones with the volume maxed out so you can properly enjoy your eardrum shattering exhaust. The two downsides I see to this game are the high price and that once you beat the game there isn't a new game plus or anything. You just get to go back and explore what you missed with a few new cosmetic items. Oh and there is the mysterious lack of Australian accents. Still it's one of the best single player games I've ever played. I really hope there are as many of these games planned as there are Mad Max movies.  In short if you like cars and fighting and games where the fun part of the game is from beginning to end, you're gonna like this game.   Overall is it worth full price? I'd say yes. Is it addictingly fun? Yes Will it make you drive more like a psycho? Possibly Is it a gateway drug into modding your own car? Oh yes

I had little expectation that Mad Max would amount to much, as all of the gameplay videos I had seen felt a little lifeless and repetitive. The first few hours, as I had feared failed to impress and I found the whole experience a little dull and underwhelming. However, I persevered and something pulled me back in for another try.   It's frustrating in the first few hours, and you will die a lot. You'll be punched to death/fall off a ledge/get ran over repeatedly while your car is slowly repaired.   Yet if you give it a chance - and the mood takes you, and you can get into Mad Max it really is a fantastic, criminally overlooked game, which looks gorgeous, is fantastically optimized and addictive as anything you have played.   In a nutshell, the game is split into regions (all completely open after an early mission, with no load screens or barriers inbetween, at least not that I came across) and you need to perform tasks such as destroying an enemy camp, in order to reduce the threat level, which in turn unlocks upgrades for Max and your car the Magnum Opus. If you've played Far Cry/Assassins Creed/Shadow of Mordor you know how this type of game mechanic works.   There is something strangely satisfying and addictive about leveling up in this game. It has a certain old school flair, whereby nothing ever feels impossible, even if you fail at the first few attempts. To me, that was always the mark of a great, well balanced game - you always have a shot of accomplishing your goal the first time around, and it never takes more than two or three attempts should you fail - including the racing challenges which are optional, thankfully.   It captures the spirit of the films nicely in terms of the character names and bizarre, twisted traits found in the bosses and main personalities found throughout the game. Mostly inspired by Fury Road, much of the game will seem familiar if you have watched the movie, and there are plenty of nods to the original trilogy as well.   The voice acting is good, the landscapes are bleak and beautiful, and the Magnum Opus feels suitably powerful. There are character bios (all of which are in keeping with the tone of the films) and a wealth of information and tidbits about the world available from the menu screen.   Mad Max is a rarity for an open world game - given it's enormity, it almost has a linear feel to it, and you have very limited options as to how you can approach the game - once you've done it, it's unlikely you would ever consider a replay, but in the near fourty hours I have played I have enjoyed it tremendously, and often found that sitting down for twenty minutes to destroy some oil pumps or tackle a convoy turned into an obsessive three hour stint, being unable to tear myself away chasing that next upgrade or hood ornament.   Overall Mad Max is an excellent game I find it difficult to fault, other than in terms of replay value.   Oh, and one thing - there is a glitch with one camp - you'll know it when you get there - whereby waves of enemies keep on coming at you, and the doors don't open, and you'll Google Youtube videos of the wall trick to complete it. Take note - remove all accessories from the Magnum Opus, blast up there, and DON'T AIM - JUST AUTO FIRE! Camp complete.  Sole glitch in an otherwise awesome game. 8.5/10

Mad Max is a game about Max Rockatansky, a mentally ill man just looking for his car that a unicorn stole.   Okay but on a serious note, this game is amazing. If you're looking for a game that's close to the newest movie, this isn't it. All it's got Max and Gas Town with some nods to the movies that you'll understand but not see. What you'll find in this game is a bunch of awesome car combat, along with some hand to hand combat. If you're a completionist this game will be great for you. I find the 100%ing extremely fun and it's not extremely terrible like a lot of games are. If you have the money, the $60 price tag isn't an issue, but if cash is tight and you don't want to pay full price, the game goes on sale on Steam at $20 pretty frequently, and lower on some other sites.  I don't write many game reviews but I loved this game so much. I highly recommend you try it.

The game mechanics of Mad Max are very much like Shadows of Modor - you run around in the different areas and do missions. Or, in case of Mad Max, you don´t run around, you drive. And that is the second very cool part about the game as you can modify your car as you see fit. The whole design follows the Mad Max Fury Road movie design with awesome desert landscapes and some really cool interior ideas. You can upgrade the car, Max himself (gear and abilities) and the holdouts you unlock on your way.   Like Shadows of Modor you have to be careful and pick your fights carefully until your car, your character etc. have reached a certain level but once you reached that the game becomes really fun as you can rampage away as you please.   Again like Shadows of Modor the story line is a bit meager but as both games are more about running/driving around and slicing up/kicking ♥♥♥ that was to be expected.   I give this game a 7/10. It´s really fun but the story is (as I said) a bit meager and the game forces you to jump through a couple of hoops I consider unnecessary. I particularly hate it when forced into story time missions without proper controls where you have to grind and grind and have to be lucky to get passed just because some overpaid developer didn´t have any fresh ideas.

If you're like me; and enjoy the Mad Max movie franchise this game is for you. Is it a great game? No its not... But as a fan of this universe I found myself smiling and really having fun being in this world. The tone of this game is very much like the tone of the movies. Morbid, lacking color and crazy.     Gameplay 7/10:  Take every RPG game made in the last 10 years and throw its elements into a Mad Max world. Seriously.... why does every game need to fill the void with collecting things, breaking things, tearing down things, climbing things. Isn't there some other game mechanic that devlopers can come up with? Throw in a mix of exciting and fun car combat and a copy/paste clone of the batman fighting mechanics and you have a really medicore mix of smiles and yawns. For the most part when I was outside of my car I hated the game. When I was inside it was a blast. Much like the movies you could say. Leveling system a very simple one. Do things get tokens which you can then use with the weirdo/philosopher guy to uprade yourself. The worst part of the game actually comes inside of the car though. Through a game mode called 'Death Run' which is a race. With exploding barrels and bombs and snipers taking out your tires. It's a dumb mode, that lets you litterly blow up the other races at the start line as soon as the race starts. The barrels often knock your car out of control and make you lose the race.     Visuals 9/10: From the lighting to the dust storms, this game is beautiful. This is the shining example of building a world that looks and feels like its movie counterpart. The fire and smoke shoots out like a scene from Fury Road. With that amazing dark red and black mixed with a hint of orange. Fire flys from your car and drops on the ground still burning fuel from your muffler and adds a deep effect to the games realism. Sparks fly, explosions everywhere. If Michael Bay made a video game, this would be it. The dust storms rolling in on the horizon make your jaw drop. Like that scene from Fury Road. Looks like a painting coming to life. Negitive points only because of the poor use of Depth of Field sometimes make things grainy and out of focus.     Story 8/10: Short, to the point. First plot point is just to build a sick car. Max is Mad about building a beast of a car. He has his trust companion Gollum on his side. I mean Chumbucket. A hunchback, radiation poisoned mad man that prays to the combustion god. He is all about taking care and building the car, which he calls the Magnum Opus. Then after doing some car things and chours for people in order to get some car things, you get to experience the 1979 Mad Max movie plot all over again. Which I guess is fine.     Sound 9/10: Everything but the soundtrack is brilliant. Gun Shots, explosions, engines screaming. Soundtrack is dull and sometimes there is silence. I actually turned on the Fury Road soundtrack in the background and it made the game feel 100% more awesome. I suggest doing the same. The Fury Road soundtrack while in a car chase or beating people up will give you chills and make you feel like a badass.     PC Port 9/10: Some problems with depth of field and other consoley thigns hold it back a little. The devs still did a good job of making it run at 60+ fps and have made some great strides in optimising the game.     Value 10/10: If you're a OCD collector like myself you will find this game will offer you 50+ hours of gameplay and even more if you are into really 100% things. If you are into just doing the main storyline then take a 5 off of the score. Because its short that way.     TL:DR: A great Mad Max story redone with stunning visuals and very fun car combat gameplay. Falls short on gameplay outside of cars and has a bunch of tedious collections and loot scavaging. Story is what you would expect from a Mad Max title. Tons of hours of play time if you are OCD and like to 100% things, if not you should get 15-20 hours or so.    Total Score: 7.5 out of 10. Higher if you a Mad Max fan.

After using as much of my free time as possible (and probably most of the time i should've spent on college homework), I finished the story line and probably about 60% of gameplay in just under 40 hours. My review won't be reflecting graphics quality as i've had issues running a lot of my games since a current update to my OS i'll be working with. But the gameplay itself was rather solid.  pros: -extremely sizable open world -single player (a nice almost relaxing change if you're burnt out from online games and need a break) -you get to see and use your progress through the game. Something felt rather satisfying seeing more people join the strongholds as it grew (as did my scrap wallet) -explosions, lots  mehs: -from my gameplay quality i'm unsure of how well optimized the game has been, in my lower framerate range i noticed it varying a lot -for all of you batman arkham series fans, the battle mechanics are near identical with less controls to worry about -enemy AI seem always vigilant, making my total count of sneak kills about 3 by this review. -unless I'm missing something, (and granted i should have gone and checked before writing this review, will check and edit this part once I do) the possibility for griffa tokens seems to be incredibly unbalanced to the max total you can use on him to max your stats. This could be so that players can play to their style and still hopefully rack up enough to max their stats but with going around and simply doing story missions and most of the death races You'd more than likely have more than enough without doing intel quests/whatever else with all the killing you'll be doing just to get to the next story mission  cons: -Even after patch 3 i've noticed numerous audio bugs, which for me was a dissappointment after the rather high-quality audio from the arkham series. -mouth movement in cutscenes often didn't match up with the audio (could probably be added to the previous con) -scrap locations.... if you are one to 100% a game, then have at it, but I believe the creators set these up to gain avg. gameplay hours from their players. You'd gain as much scrap taking out 3 cars as you would in some of the scavanging locations. The only vital scrap locations are maybe the pallets and the stronghold items which i found ammo (storyline) and cleanup crew to be some of the most useful ingame, the scrap crew is nice for being away but i've seen little advancement with it vs. the regular stronghold profit.  and the big one, the story. I won't go into detail as to not spoil anything for newcomers. The most irksome thing to me in the story is the bonding of the characters. To me it seems like they wanted max to continuously push away those around him yet his actions and talks with griffa constantly betray this main plot idea. Maybe more that Max just isn't being honest with himself. Later in-game bonds begin to form with what I assume the creators wanted to be major characters instead of minor characters but their role by this point was undeveloped and felt half-baked. Max is meant to continue on alone, he is the modern lone ranger, I get that. However, I feel like a lot of the game's story could've gone more fluidly. A game with straight-forward linearity can be nice, but being able to make some slightly pertinant decisions to characters or situations in the game, allow the player to feel attached to part of the game, making the sensation deeper and gaining a better experience from the player. Mad max was more a 'I'm gonna tell you to go here, go here, kill, blow stuff up, and in return you get chunks of metal to slap on your car like you can make a fully functional engine out of the 300 superchargers and 200 radiators you've scavanged across the great white.'  All negative points aside, in the end I actually very much enjoyed it, and plan on continuing to play and clear out the rest of the camps and such. It may not be suitable for everyone and I'd suggest watching a playthrough or something of it if you are unsure, don't waste your money if you dont know if you'll like it. But I certainly enjoyed it, and I would still reccomend this game. Some of the hiccups can be fixed, and I hope they offer some sort of story DLC to the game as I think it could use a little more support to the backbone of the game.

The formula of the game is a classic open world game with a bit RPG leveling. You go around a pretty large world, doing races, taking fortresses, blowing up cars in brutal car combat, and driving. Lots of driving.  Usually, I would go into the story here, but I won't spoil it. The beginning is great so... The basics are that you need to create a new car, The Magnum Opus. As you progress you get to customize your car a ton, so you can have a car that's slow, but almost impossible to destroy, or you can have a car that is fast, but weak etc.....  Ground combat is brutal, It's like Shadow of Mordor but without the swords. You really don't use guns, aside from a shotgun which you don't have mutch ammo for. HOWEVER. If you don't like games like Far Cry 4, Assasin's Creed, Watch Dogs, or Shadow of Mordor you will not like this game, at all.

I grew fond of Max in this game, I admit.  I believe the strong point in the game that it might provide fun for those who are hasty and for those who like making every small detail on an open world or a mix of those (such as myself).  Having means to make your Magnus Opus a car of legend, you soon start looking for means to have the parts and the scraps to build them. Besides, you also have Fortresses where you can replenish your resources (if you build them), and make fast travels, and run for your death trying to get new vehicles.  I admit that near the ending I started getting bored with the worldly missions and got rushed up to the last missions at Gas Town, so the game ended rather suddendly (although it'll continue from there, if you want).  Car battles can be rather nice and/or extremely annoying, depending on what you have to do. Sometimes some stupid small rock you make your world an inferno. Alas, that's what it takes when driving at high speed trying to explode other cars which are trying to do the same to you.  Man-to-man battles get fairly easy in no time. You must mainly be wary of counter-attacking at the exact moment, even when you a surrounded by a dozen foes of different attack styles, it's not hard finishing them up without being hit once. Also, learning battle skills make these battles even easier and faster to finish up.  I also think that you must visit Griffa more often to learn what he has to say to Max. I used to visit him after collecting around 15 or so Griffa Tokens, so I visited him not that often and got Maxed out in all my abilities too soon, then I guess something was left 'unsaid'.   Graphically, it is a pleasing game that I need not to play in low stats. The voice casting was also nice.  Something that got a bit boring was sniffing out land mines with the dog and cleaning the maps whole, sometimes going to very far fetched places to get only a handful of scraps in which you could also get by exploding a single car in your way down there. I believe some places could be a bit more rewarding.  Story-wise the game is not groundbreaking. It does show some situations in which you ponder about how it would be if it was real, specially considering natural resources, food and the likes. Still, it has room to show a branch of expansion towards Bullet Farm, which is again only mentioned here, just like it was in the movie, so I think there's a probability to have an Expasion entitled Bullet Farm. As long as they don't simply only add a new region without any tweaks in gameplay to make the game less repetitive and more engaging and insteresting.  All in all I would give a 8.5 even a 9-10 for this game. It was fun.

So, now that I finished the game 100%, I can properly and thoroughly review it.  It should be noted that the game has a somewhat faint connection to the movie, and it's probably a good thing - game devs had a greater freedom in terms of things they could make.  Before you read the review, you should understand that this is a sandbox game with all the cliches and quirks sandbox games have: lots of collectibles, vast map, going from A to B, killing X enemies. I do not mind such gameplay, if the game provides something in return for my struggles, and Mad Max delivers.   What I loved about the game:     Graphics are absolutely gorgeous - I had no idea the desert could be so beatiful. Cars and people are made in great detail, and special effects are top-notch. True eye-candy.     Storyline and atmosphere - the game is true to older, darker, grittier vision of Mad Max - the character has no remorse, he is a broken shell of a man, willing to sacrifice anything to complete his goals.     Car gameplay - driving your Magnum Opus is always pleasant experience - it really responds to your modifications and changes, gently pushing you to find new pieces to improve it. The game also provides quite a vast customization pool for the car, allowing you to choose various tactics to deal with numerous enemies on roads.    As you can see by the amount of hours I spent in the game, I found a lot of elements of the game appealing, but these come to mind as gems. However, there were some little problems that reduce my final grade a little bit.     Hand-to-hand combat is lacking depth. It has a well-known batman mechanic of one-button hit and one-button parry, and you can take melee weapons, and use shivs and shotguns, but the upgrades do not add any real definition or depth to the fighting. At first 8-10 hours it is not visible, because you do not really fight that often, and Max has a lot of moves to compensate for lack of depth.    At first, it appears that there are many types of enemies, since there are 3 factions: Roadkill, Scrotus and Buzzards, but they are essentially recolours of existing models, and there are only 4-6 distinct fighting mechanics along the enemies.    Bomb defusal optional objectives and the Dog. The Dog plays semi-important part of the story in the beginning, but then gets unceremoniously put away until you explicitly need it. I know this is not Fallout, and Max does not care much about Dog, but it is not mentioned at all later on.    You can see that most of my complaints have the same basis - lack of content. The game could be much better if the devs tried to introduce a little bit more diversity to the enemies, Max's moves, and Wasteland missions. However, you will only start noticing the abovementioned problems after 8-10 hours in the game, which means that you pretty much already get a good value from it.   Final grade: 8/10.  If you are a fan of Mad Max - play it. If you are a fan of sandbox games - play it. If you like dark, gritty, post-apocalyptic settings - play it. It is all-around good game, and you probably won't regret getting it.

This is an incredible game. It is so much fun it may very well go down as one of the best games of all time. It uses a model similar to Batman Arkham City and if you play this title you will know what I mean. I want to get into it's finer points, but first I'd like to point out that Mad Max does better at capturing the Post Apocalyptic theme than does Fallout 3 & 4.  - Open World.  Similar to Arkham City in that you have free open world, but it's bigger and you have a vehicle to rampage through it in. The Open world feel is perfect. Some games try to do this but can't get it right. There are some amazingly creative contructed spots to explore. The desolation fits and makes you feel a sense of   -Customization. The vehicle customization is unhinged and is one of the most fun aspects. To some it might be strange to center the main plot around building the perfect car, but I swear if any developer could have done it right it was these guys. If customizing your car isn't enough then customize Max Rockantowsky. Still not enough there are a bunch of different bases that have some needed customizations or upgrades too.  -Sound or music. I work in film and I know how important this is to making a good movie. I didn't realize how well it enhanced my experience in this game as well. Whoever did sound really did nicely even down to whatever value they set for hearing a person talk from at a distance to the roar of the car engines to explosions to hearing the voices in open areas to caves. I can tell a lot of work went into this and it deserves honorable mention.  -Characters and Voice acting. The sound crew really did well at capturing these fine actors voices. I believe it is some of the finer acting I've seen in gaming and I can be very critical as an actor myself. Character wise, oh my gosh, Chum is the best NPC I have ever seen done in a video game. The character Chum who is your mechanic is fanatastic! He is creepy, his comic relief isn't forced, and if you play this you wil see he is the most useful. When I first started playing I didn't trust him. Once he started proving himself I wastalking to my computer screen telling him to shut up. By the time we were smoking the best V6 engines I loved him, he was my pal and made me feel an array of opinions about him which I believe is the halmark of a truly well done character. Seriously, great job Warner Brothers and great job to Jason Spisak in this role.  All in all, I don't really need to go into the finer points just look at the screen shots. Look, if you have the system to run this game then you should really just reward yourself and let this game rock your world. Honestly, I'm worried that Mad Max (2015) may have ruined Fallout 4 for me; in a good way.

The User Reviews are correct - Mad Max is an over-looked gem of a game.   At first glance you'd think you were playing another canned, boring formula game such as 'Rage' employed. But Mad Max is much, much more fun and interesting, well-polished and balanced.  The inspiration to keep playing comes from the need to upgrade your car and fighting abilties by collecting scrap, parts, and completing open-world objectives, such as clearing 'camps.' Camps are fun, because there is some real variety to their types and layouts, and assortment of enemies...and the hand-to-hand combat is fun, well-done, and shows that it's not just another FPS action game.  And that's the key - you battle enemies and overcome obstacles in the game, in a variety of ways...your car, its harpoon, sniper and shotgun options (with very limited ammo so you use them spaingly, as they're tied to set hot-keys), or you can toss a lighted gas can, or use a melee weapon if there's one lying around (temporarily).  You essentially take-over various areas of the map, leading up to the final confrontation with Gas Town, which is the key to survival, dominance, and easy-living in the desert. But it will also take a buffed-out car and abilities to do it.  The driving is fun and well-done, although the camera can be a tad wonky when fighting or driving, it's tolerable and otherwise similar to any other modern game in that regard. Your main car (Magnus Opus) is heavy and loud, and comes from 3-4 different models of your choice (they are not drastically different).  Finally, the voice-acting is fantastic! What a surprise to experience Ace voice actors and characters in a game, makes such a big difference to the game's charm and sense of immersion. Chum, your mechanic assistant, is a classic video game character who is constantly jabbering warning you of on-coming enemies in the distance. He's a great, whacky character, and have nothing but praise for his voice actor, seriously one of the best voice-over jobs and writing I've ever experienced in a game.  The environments are detailed and immersive (for a desert), the storms are crazy cool, and the sunsets are great to drive around in. Roads are faster than the shiftier, deeper sand off the road, cars spin accurately in the dirt.  Got this for $10 on sale, and maybe that makes me a bit biased, but the game deserves more praise from the gaming media than it has received.
