I was really positive about the game around its release. The environmental designs are more varied than in most other open world games. The melee combat is not just a bleak copy of the Arkham games, but improves upon them in some ways. The car combat is not the gimmick that some people make it out to be, but is grounded in non-trivial gameplay systems that feel satisfying to use.  However, the one issue with the game that I couldn't get over was the awful pacing for someone doing a completionist playthrough. If you clean up all the outposts, missions and pickups in the first area, you have seen a lot of what the game has to offer. There is no clear motivation to go and do the other areas, and if you attempt them you get mostly negative reinforcement when you realize that the new outposts and missions are extremely similar to those you have already done.  It is possible that the pacing works better if you skim on the surface of the additional content and focus on the main quest, but I didn't play the game like that. I would have preferred a shorter game that offers a reasonable amount of additional content that is meaningful, avoids repetition and builds towards something. Mad Max is still a decent game, but it could have been so much more.

Good: +Open desert world +Mad Max inspired all the way +Optimized like ♥♥♥♥ yeah  Bad: -Deja vu -Late game car combat difficulty -Missions   -Missions: I have never cared so little about the story for a game I've spent over 20 hours playing. It really only seems to exist as an excuse to move you from zone to zone. Several missions, including one that forces you to do every activity in a zone, serve only to impede your ability to aquire upgrades. Too many missions or activities require you to slow your momentum or return to an early zone and thereby suffer outright boredom if you want to complete this game.  -Late game car combat difficulty: I like the vehicle handling. It reminds me of the Mad Max muscle cars and the indie movie Bellflower (inspired somewhat by Mad Max). What I don't like is the way that car armor is used late game to remove the most enjoyable part of the car combat (the grapple gun) and the way the AI can outperform you or get random speedboosts in cars without nitro. It's something that can be learned to deal with, but it's just not fun.  -Dejay vu: The huge game world is split up into zones that feature the same tasks in every zone. The developers did a great job adding random touches of personality here and there. However, it's far too easy to experience moments of 'didn't I just do this?'  +Optimized like ♥♥♥♥ yeah: Even on my old GTX 750 this game runs surprisingly well. There are occasional stutters at Low with resolution 1920x1080 but that's about it.  +Mad Max inspired all the way: Mad Max as a character isn't very interesting. However, this game is arguably more about exploring his world then exploring him, and from that perspective the game does really well. The cars, the combat, the guns, even the stupid hot-air balloons feel like they belong (the hot-air balloons are stretching it a bit, though).  +Open desert world: I am a huge fan of post-apocalypse wastelands, and the open world for this game is on par with Fallout and STALKER. Actually, between Fallout 3 and Mad Max, I'd say Mad Max wins both in terms of world building and personality. My hours were spent driving everywhere and trying to see everything, because there is always something new when you least expect it.

Brief Linux port technical review (i.e, not reviewing gameplay/story)  CPU: i7-3770k @ 4.20GHz GPU: Nvidia GTX 970 Distro: Mint 18 x64 Cinnamon Kernel: 4.4.0-42-generic GPU Driver: Nvida 370.28  Right off the bat, let me say this game performs phenomenally and looks great. Running an Nvidia 970 with every setting cranked up to its highest possible value (beyond the presets), I get a solid 60-80 FPS at 1080p. The only time I've noticed the framerate drop is, oddly, around numerous latern/candles (not sure exactly how to describe them), which only bottomed out at 48fps. The issue seems to be limited to these particular objects and no other sources of fire (like burning cars) or other graphically demanding things (like giant sand storms) seems to bring it down at all.  The game, like many these days, seems to handle controllers relatively well. I plugged in my 360 controller while the game was still running and automatically detected it and instantly switched the buttons displayed on the interface upon using it, and switched it back upon using mouse/keyboard (you can swap between the two, no problem). My only complaint here, which, I know is nitpicking, but the game doesn't seem to be able to handle simultanious controller and mouse/keyboard input well. As absurd as I'm sure it may seem to some, I like to be able to use my controller to drive with one hand and my mouse to aim with the other, and while I'm using the mouse the controller input goes undetected, so I'm not able to drive and shoot as well as I'd like. The slow-mo and aim-assist makes aiming fairly easy to do with the controller, so this is a pretty minor gripe.  The audio seems to be great (using the headphone configuration), but I've had a few relatively trivial issues here as well. When opening something with the crowbar (I think it's called something else in game), the sound for when something is finally opened seems to be absent. I also had an odd experience where the audio was very slightly muffled off and on for about 15 minutes. I can't say whether or not this is normal game behavior though, just the two things that stood out as seeming odd.  Overall, this definitely seems to be a great port. The few issues I've encountered are minor to the point of being something that could easily go entirely unnoticed without looking for it. While the negatives may seem highlighted over the good things here, that's mostly an artifact of any port review - if it's done perfectly there's really nothing at all to talk about, and so much of this port seems to be that.  If the game sounds interesting to you and you're a linux gamer, I'd definitely suggest picking it up.   Edit: Here's a video showing off an example of a low-fps area. The video was captured and uploaded at 60fps (so watch at either 720p60 or 1080p60 quality). The video also shows an example of one of the audio bugs (at the start of the fight). It may potentially contain spoilers.         Mad Max (linux), Low FPS area

In my honest opinion it's a great game, loads of fun and worth it. - When your near dead the absence of water can be the difference between life or death, but without any real consequence while getting checkpoints it's really not that meaningful when you die. - The AI is very basic and over time can be very predictable, Max is just that good of a fighter. - Storywise the game does have a good story, but there have been alot of complaints that the main story isn't long enough. - The layouts of each camp can be different, the mission objectives of each camp have only minor differences that repeat with most of the other camps. - Your in a place surrounded with people that want to kill you, so don't just hang out in the middle of the road, because there will be enemies coming for you, the only safe place is camps you've either taken over or ally strongholds. - The storm events look spectacular, and help to make things interesting during a chase, and can even help assist in destroying objectives in camps if you stay near the gate way, in the safety of your car, also they come with tons of scrap if you survive it out, or you can skip the weather events by going to the base camps. These are not random, so if you can memorise where the blasts hit, you can use it to your advantage. - Difficulty it's a standard button masher, if you've ever played a button masher before you know what your getting into here for example the Batman Arkham games;  For those who are unfamiliar with button mashers, I will explain certain events that occur while battling enemies. Sometimes you'll get certain enemy notifications like charging you, the other ones a parry, car battling is pretty simple especially once you can upgrade Thunderpoon and can just blast your enemies dead. Like many other games of this genre they play quite the same even ending off with a slow motion finish, once all enemies in the immediate area (the gang currently attacking you, have been taken care of.. Some enemies require you perform a parry move first, before you can attack them, or catching them off gaurd, or using an attack shield move, before you can really begin doing any attacks to them.   Gameplay: 8/10 (Great story although short, it's easy to pick up and play, great time spender, could use more things to do in the world)  Difficulty: 5.8/10 (When compared to other open world games. Mad Max is borderline easy, but just enough difficuly where you can still die if you're not careful, it's extremely easy to learn and master, getting upgrades just makes it more easier)  Controls: 10/10 (It does what it's supposed to do very well)  Graphics: 10/10 (While comparing it to other open world games, it definitely has gorgeous graphics, they could only get better)   Music/Sound: 7/10 (Some times the sound almost kinks out completely, while driving, but when it does play correctly, it sounds nice)  -------  Possible Spoilers:   -Your car when damaged fully will engulf on fire, if you don't get out within 5 seconds, it explodes, but if you do get out, Chum just fixes it back up, (watch for repair meter to hit the arrow to be able to re-enter your vehicle, or you can also quick repair, any vehicle for those where your helper Chum isn't with you, for a price.  - Giving beggars some water, or just helping out allys grants a nice bonus to your XP/points for skills, and also grants loot locations around the world. All events are done in real time, the game doesn't stop while your giving someone water or seeking info, which can cause you to get attacked while performing certain actions, which can even cause the ones your trying to help, end up dead.  - The absence of bikes in this game, was a real downer, while playing you'll even notice they had a few tiny jokes about them, and having bikes could have really increased the dificulty.  Glitch wise:  - Invisible walls glitch: while underground (Subway train car) also while standing on certain objects, can force you into getting stuck on them.  - Missing enemies glitch: one or more of the enemies go out of the immediate area, and the game can forget about them, while you are required to kill for an objective, forcing you to run around in circles desperately trying to find them, only to realise he's no longer in the camp, requiring you to find a way to kill yourself in order for the enemy to respawn. Very frustrating.      Boss Strategy:   While standing infront of fire, aim your weapon at the boss, boss will then begin to charge toward you, dodge out of the way, the boss will usually run into fire, which leaves them open for an easy attack, repeat this tactic and you'll have that big mean bully down in no time. ;)

From start to finish, this was a really fun game. All of its various elements worked well together, and the game is as stable and bug-free as you'd hope it to be. The setting is intriguing and fun, even though it's handled as a bit of flavor rather than the focus of the game. The focus is simple: you're killing bad guys with your fists and your car. Along the way there are goals to accomplish. Most of those goals are optional, and you aren't penalized if you only focus on the main storyline while avoiding the somewhat repetative sidetracks. I loved the sidetracks, except for the races, which were just hard enough for me to only bother finishing a couple (I'd rather bash heads).   I would criticize the repetative aspect of the game, but it works to train you in getting better, and the most repetative part is also the most enjoyable: driving a nigh-indestructable scrap hot rod! Where I really wanted more from the game is in the survival aspect. There is so much water that it's hard to want for it. Fuel is simple never, ever an issue at all. Maybe since the game revolves around Gastown that makes sense, but I would have had to blow up or ignore 5 gas cans in a row to ever risk running on fumes. You do not get the sense that surviving the ravages of Nature is an issue for Max, even though it is hammered over and over that survival is an issue for everyone else. That keeps the focus more on the combat, but I would have liked to have a 'survival is hard' option.  The plot is extremely simple and offers few twists and turns, but the dialogue throughout is immersive, engaging, and bordering on exceptional. Where the story part of the game really shines is in the ending: maybe the best end for a video game I've ever experienced. Play the game and experience it for yourself; it is not an ending you can appreciate without having played through the whole thing.

Prepare thine buttox, ye who enter this realm of criticism. I'm not trying to be a prick here, I just want to be honest about what I actually think and experienced.   While this game has cool GRAYFIX and all that, gameplay is lacking pretty hard.  Here's the generally good stuff;  *Very nice visuals, as I mentioned. *Even though the world is mostly sand and rock, each territory has nice variety and cool locations to check out. *Melee combat has a lot of fun moves and contextual things like slamming heads into walls or pushing people over rails to their doom. *Vehicle combat is satisfying and visceral. *Story is fairly good, not much to complain about here, except the ending is a bit anticlimactic in my opinion. *Characters are interesting and memorable. *Voice acting is superb. *Low usage of invisible walls, instead uses level design and deadly storms to create boundries, that's a plus in my book.  And here's the rest;  *Poorly balanced, very easy to get very overpowered. You can reach close to Max (ohoho) level before you leave even the first territory of the game, obviously designed towards being rushed through, which is a bit sad. *Supplies are extremely abundant, fuel, water, food, ammo, whatever. Never once did I run out of anything other than water, which I promptly refilled moments later. Skill upgrades are detrimental to the game, making supplies 'even' more abundant, giving you a ton of health turning you into a tank (combine with good armor and you'll be unstoppable), making combat even easier, etc. *The only thing that ever got me killed was me being silly where I fell off cliffs or such, oops.  *Melee combat is pizz-easy(yay censorship), even if you use no combat upgrades. Melee combat also had potential to be a bit more interesting, but for no actual reason everyone fights with their fists, nobody except you has a gun (not counting snipers), and melee weapons are fairly useless and magically break after a handful of hits. You also can't store melee weapons, not even in your car. *Vehicle combat is pretty fun and provides some challenge, only real complaint here would be that you'll never ever leave the main vehicle to drive any of the other tons of vehicles available, because you can't bring cumbucket with you on anything else. *Vehicles handle poorly with keyboard controls, so get a controller if you wanna have more fun driving. Additonally, vehicle physics are a bit strange, with vehicles uprighting themselves constantly and being near impossible to flip. *Some vehicle upgrades are a bit silly, for example Armour upgrades where you stick a few guard rails on the side of your car and suddenly it weighs enough to warrant a military tank licence. You also can't even unlock and purchase the V8 stuff until there's like, 5-10% left of the game to play.  *Gameplay is very (VERY) repetative, all bosses (yes literally all) are copy-pasted with different colours and voice lines. That is a huge point deduction in my little book. *Side missions are fun for the first few times, until you realize they're all copy-pasted as well, sadly. *Sub-par freedom of movement, unbefitting a modern game with a modern engine, you can only climb specially marked areas, nothing else, not even a belly-high fence. It feels very primitive and unorganic, especially for a modern 3rd person game.  *Racing is, as you probably would guess by now, pizz-easy. You either outrace every other driver within 20 seconds or shoot out all their tires within 10 seconds ( ͠° ͟ʖ ͡°) I can't write much else about it since it nullifies its own existance so quickly.  *Exploring can be fun for eyecandy alone, but don't expect to be rewarded with anything substansial, only generic supplies, and Project Parts here and there, but.. Projects makes the game, once again, even easier, giving you infinite fuel, ammo, water, health refills, etc.  'But hey, it's fun to upgrade strongholds you big meanie!' So thought I, as I assumed it actually had purpose, but it turns out it has no function whatsoever. None. Unless you count looking less arze with each stage, but yeah..  *So this is supposed to be related to Fury Road right? Supposedly, but there are no real ties between the movie and the game, in either direction. Max himself also acts wildly differently between the movie and the game, it doesn't even seem like they're the same person. Compared to the movie, in the game barely anybody has guns and Max can't fight anywhere near as good in the movie as he does in the game. But now I'm stepping towards reviewing the movie instead of the game so let's drop it here shall we.   All in all, if you like Mad Max, you'll get a thrill or two out of this generally casual game, but it's certainly not worth full price, it's more along the lines of 15-20 euros.

Let me just say this game is really not that bad. In fact , its the best movie-tie-in game I've ever played which you really do feel like Max on a post-apocalyptic wasteland . My opinion about this game is like a tug of war and it really does have its highs and lows .    Highs     Beautiful setting - Although it really is a wasteland , it doesn't feel that repettive . The game developers try there best to make the experience of driving around the wasteland actually more entertaining with each region have a unique character to it . Alogn with change of weather and nighttime.    Gritty Combat - Akrham-y combat mechanic without the cool gadgets and kungfu moves . When your playing Max , the only combat experience is your two fists and boy it really does feel good suckerpunch a godamn war boy in face .    World - If you like the crazyness of the franchise, then this game gives that same lust of insanity and madness that we all crave with specific tribes with there own culture and beliefs . Typical Mad Max trope to survive by scavenging scraps , food and water is also the main theme for this game.   Car mechanics and Combat - The soul of this whole franchise and this game is the car combat . Its basically Pimp-My-Ride with your sidekick Chumbucket as xzibbit . Car Combat is as entertaining as it gets especially when you high tail a convoy all by yourself , rampaging through dozens of cars jsut to get that head ornament as the cherry on top of your sweet Magnum Opus .    Story - This is probably in the middle but like any Mad MAx movie . It is kept pretty simple with a clear objective      Lows    The Grind - This is the bad apart about customizing your car , to upgrade the best parts for it you have to start doing small missions by destorying camps and clearing the region which is a chore especially if majority are almost the same . This is what BREAKS ME for this game , its tiring &repetitive and I had to take a long rest from playing this game before going at it again .    THE DOG IS USELESS - At first when I saw the dog at the first part of the game you'll be like ' hell yeah , Dog partner in wasteland just like Road Warrior ' NOOOOOOPPPEEEE . The only thing that dog does in this game is to sniff out mines and there is no reward other then clearing the region out of doing this . It is menial and boring as heck .    Mini-Boss are the SAME- THroughout parts of each region theres a mini-boss camps for you to beat to get that sweet paintjob on your crib but my god is it boring . Each Mini-boss has the same moves , body and mask and it is repetitive and lazy which makes the game almost a cakewalk .     Verdict   Overall , its really not a bad game but for those who enjoy a collectathon with a same-y sandbox gameplay with added car combat and collecting while experiencing post-apocalyptic franchise then you would love this game but for me it felt like chore .

This game has too many good reviews for its own good. I can't honestly recommend it. Have doubt about all the good reviews, as this game is sadly too much sandbox and too much about graphics, anything else didn't got the proper attention. The bad things are outweighing the good things.   Good: +Graphics: Even rocks are looking good. +Cars: Yeah, yeah, it's Mad Max alright. +Fighting: Have Batman/SoM style of combat, with a Shotgun and Shivs! +Sandbox: Have the sandiest Sandbox you can imagine and give it Mad Max style, done. +Mad Max: Most of us know it, most of us love it. +Controls: Simple and easy, sadly.  Neutral: ~Sandbox: Yep, it keeps going to be sandy with Mad Max style. ~Weapons: Yeah, nothing bad, nothing good. ~Mad Max: They try to fit it into the Mad Max Universe with collecting History Relics.  Bad: -Sandbox: At the end are you just tired of this, with Mad Max style! Feels like you are on a island. -Mad Max: They don't even try, sometimes you can tell, they are forcing to fit into the Mad Max Universe. -Fighting: Yes, it is good, and it is bad too. -Enemies: Copy-paste Enemies in different looks in different Factions. 'Top Dogs' are literally all the same actually. -Cars: Why take other cars? -Unnecessary Challenges: Yeah, if you manage to use the game mechanics against your enemies, its going easy mode. -Territories: Reducing the threats to get all the Upgrades, not really fun after half the game. Especially the damn Minefields, that have actually no impact, but yet are a Threat, for whatever reasons. Even enemy patrols are caring for Minefields. -Stealth: There is no stealth, the Enemies know, you are there, even if they are behind a thick wall and you have your lights off in a dark tunnel, you being in complete darkness. -Enemy awareness: The enemy knows, that you are there, don't try to hide or going around them. -Enemy cars spawning: You can keep looking around and stare on your minimap, you don't see them coming until Chum tells, what kind of enemies are appearing and then they are magical there. -Simple controls: Yep, bad point there too. Because too much is bound to ONE button. That ONE button opens doors, loot the corpses, pick up weapons, putting Finishers on enemies and to climb marked stuff. Yep, best part, the actions overlap each other. Top Dog fight, you want to finish him and...loots the corpse instead, because Reasons! -No combos: Yes, there is a lack of combos. -Scraps: EVERYTHING UNLOCKABLE is brought with Scraps. Just take Scraps to get a better Jacket! Or Scraps to get better Tires! Oh, you found the best Tires? Still spent Scraps to install it! Seriously, they tried to put Grind into this Game and that Grind is actually just a joke. -Upgrades: You must earn Tokens to upgrade Max. Sounds good, but after half the game i already have a full buffed Max, taking away the actual difficulty of the camps. -Difficulty Spikes: Yep, even fully buffed and unlocked all the Upgrades of your Car, there are missions, you hate and are FORCED to play. Best Example, the Big Chief Race, you have to change your Car to be fast and agile, and yet does the game not tell you, that you have unlimited ammo, while you try to save ammo for Gum. -Nice Start and Terrible Ending: Sounds complicated? Well, you are forced to watch a little move at the Start, that gives you the Mad Max feeling, but it is a movie, you have to wait. Then finally, after the movie, you can start playing, the tutorial, which you can't skip it as it unlocks the stuff you need to be able to do. And the end finishes off with a movie too! But that ending...terrible. -Yellow Marked stuff: Want to climb and interact with the world? Look out for yellow marked stuff, because Max refuses to touch anything else! -Unnecessary stuff: Jumping, why is jumping in the game when Max doesn't want to jump? And the forced Jimmybar, which is actually a Crowbar, just feel unnecessary and forced. What were the Devs thinking? -Sound Bugs: Yep, this exists too in the game. -Story: Won't spoil it, but to be honest, go watch the Mad Max movies, they are better. -Literal Screenshot places: Yep, there are spots, where you are thinking: Best place to make screenshot with the graphics and the special option to do so. I don't even try to find them but the game is full of them, i started to think, that the Devs wanted a Mad Max Screenshot game instead of this. -No DLC: In SoM atleast had DLCs, one in particular which gave us wonderful content to play with. But this game, no DLC, no reason to keep playing it.   I played it through, i got all the Upgrades and upgraded all the Strongholds. And this game gets mediocre after half the game, as you really have nothing to fear actually. All these good reviews must had their Honeymoon phase as this game just offers Mad Max, in a Car, in a Sandbox with Objectives. Sounds like a Mad Max Movie? Atleast the Movies are nice to watch and enjoyable.  In all honesty, i'm dissapointed. The start feels good, really. But at the half of the game, are you starting to wonder, why there are so many stones in the way, not obstacles, because obstacles would be atleast challenging. With the stones, you are just forced to stumble over them. And the end, UGH, so dissapointing, so stupid, so foreseeable and no challenge at all.

The car driving, which I imagined was the centerpiece of the game, feels sluggish and just does not feel rewarding like it ought to. It may be 'realistic' to desert driving, I have never driven on sand so I don't know. But dang at least make it fun somehow.  The story is a bore as well, Max is about as dull as the sand, and the 'crazy characters' kind of wear thin as they are all just nonsensical in the same, blaring way.  The car combat is okay, it is not great but at least the harpoon is alright and being that I have not played much I hope it gets better but I cannot get through more grinding to find out. Also, DO NOT watch the movie if you plan to play this game as it is even a larger let down from the fantastic film. To sum up, I would rate this game akin to a puppy dying slowly. Super short summary: Mad max is far cry 3 on a desert with a ♥♥♥♥ing cliché storyline.  That is the main game I will use to compare mad max with because they really share a lot. But mad max also borrowed tons of gameplay mechanics from other games, in fact the game doesn’t have a single ♥♥♥♥ing unique mechanic. The devs only included tried and tested mechanics from other games like Batman (melee combat) but without batman’s intensive amount of tools/gadgets making the combat very shallow. Ubisoft’s Assassins’ creed and far cry 3’s watchtower replaced by a hot air balloon to view legends on the map. Repetitive encounters in ubisoft open world games replaced with scavenging locations where most of them you only need to get 1-4 actions/scrap to finish which are pretty meaningless since you’ll be overflowing with scrap anyways.   I don’t get why this game has such a high rating since everything was done in mediocrity and the map is only filled with repetitive tasks. Even the ♥♥♥♥ing bosses are not unique! They are all the same with very minimal changes on the terrain you are fighting with. The skill tree and upgrade tree for you and the car is very shallow, the archangels serves no purpose but to put prefabricated cars with specific parts which is most of the time weaker than your custom car (they didn’t even put a ♥♥♥♥ing bonus for using a prefabbed car). Only 3 modes in the races and they are so boring. It is such a ♥♥♥♥ing chore to finish with its hundreds of checklist to finish, I think out of the 54 hours I’ve played, the story is only 4 hours and 50 hours was spent doing all those chores to 100% the achievements and challenges. And the story line? Easily ♥♥♥♥ing forgettable, I won’t spoil but the side characters aren’t fleshed out to get the treatment that the game had given them.  Now that I have finished my rant, let’s see some of the pluses on this game. Game is well optimized, most of the time 120fps on all settings on max @ 1080p on my 980ti, but I guess it’s easy to run this game since it’s empty (desert setting remember?). Cool ♥♥♥♥ camera filters for screenshot and in-built recording (I know I said mad max didn’t have a unique gameplay mechanic, this is a feature not a mechanic). Andd uhhh, that’s it I guess?  This game could have been amazing, they could have put survival aspects where you need to eat and drink to survive making the game even longer, they could’ve added more cars and unique weaponry and ♥♥♥♥, they could’ve make each boss unique and racing duels different. But no, devs have made a very safe decision to only put simplistic designs and gameplay to it.  For this, I cannot recommend the game since this is easily forgettable. If you really want to get it, get it @ 75%, you probably can get it the next summer sale since it was already on Humble monthly for $12

For short, I don't recommend this game for that price, not because there isn't enough content in it, but because half the content feels rushed and not fully thought out. The story is well done but they failed in every aspect of gameplay. If you are a very big Mad Max fan and only want the game for the story and setting in the Mad Max universe you will probably get enough out of this game for the price.  The one things I really like in this game is the story and the characters, these things are wonderfully implemented, the setting is also pretty well done even though we already have so many post apocalyptic desert settings.  Everything else is either needlessly prolonged and tedious or doesn't work as it should and is tedious. Here are a few of the annoying things that get me mad: - You never feel like you have a badass car because everytime the enemy cars are finally weaker than you, you get to a new region where your car once again is weaker than even the weakest enemy. - The driving works like in any other game, it sends you flying off in random directions only because you drove over a tiny bump on the road and one doesn't need to be on full speed for that to happen, while the enemy drivers can pull off nearly impossible maneuvers. - The enemy cars will always catch up to you when they are trying to engage you, it doesn't matter how fast your car and how fast their car should be, but when your trying to get a fleeing car it's nearly impossible to only stay near it much less attack it. - In meele fighting the button presses only register half the time, so 50% of all blocks and finisher just won't register, it seems to me that somebody with no knowledge on what exactly makes that style engaging and fun tried to copy the batman game finghting style. - If you want to interact with anything you have to stand in the exact right spot and also look in the right direction or the game won't realise that you're trying to interact with it. - Everytime you want to interact with anything you have to hold the interact button instead of just pressing it, man is that tedious. - The jump they give you is the most pathetic jump I have ever seen in a video game. - Sometimes things can fall through the floor, an example: one of the hood ornaments you can get from defeating a convoy gliched trough the floor - Trying to aim with the shotgun or throwing weapons while engaging in battle is poorly implemented, because when you try to aim, the camera needs a few senconds until it's in the right place for the aiming and normally you get hit in the time it takes for that. There is a 'fast shot' where you don't need to aim, but that doesn't help you when your trying to kill the warcryer while you're getting swarmed.  And these are just a few of the things that drive me crazy. So when you can buy the game for 20-30 bucks it might be worth your money, but for a 50 buck game I can only say it's really rage inducing and disappointing.

First negative review of a video game. Here is why. 1) Every boss is exactly the same, no real variation. 2) The most linear combat since 2d side scrolling. Play it the way the devs want or don't play at all. 3) A death race where every time you take someone out they respawn. 4) Scrap. Either pick up the scrap 6 at time for that 1400 scrap upgrade or let your game run in the background for days. 5) No incentive to do side activities. You max out early in the game, eliminating the need to do any side activities unless you're a completionist. 6) No customization. You're Max and your Magnum Opus will be the same as everyone elses. Awesome. 7) Downgraded combat from Shadow of Mordor. I don't know about Batman, but Talion could chain together multiple takedowns to form a nonstop chain of awesomeness. Max can't do that. Max can be mid takedown and get punched in the back. Max can not chain multiple take downs in a row. Max will refuse to parry 50% of the time unless the target is right in front of him. 8)Glitches. A) Sink in sand. B) Fall through world. C) Get flung through air by dust devil. Just the ones I've personally experienced, not the ones that I've heard of or scene on YouTube.  If you were looking for something similar to Shadows of Mordor then you looked in the wrong place. They took everything but the awesome parkour, the good stealth, the better combat, and the nemesis system and made Mad Max with the disgusting leftovers. Sure the game is well optimized, but that's the best I can say about it.  [Edit]: If you're wondering why I put some much time in this game and then suddenly stopped it's because I spent a long time doing side stuff. Lots and lots of scrap. I completely upgrade Jeet's and Gutgash's strongholds. I nearly had Pink Eye's complete. If you own this game and you don't understand why I've chose to give it a bad review then just go and take down all the top dogs and then do the mission in Gastown called Immortal Enemy. If you complete all that and you still like the game then I doff my proverbial hat to you.

I really wanted to like the game. I loved the movie and was immediatley excited at the idea of a Mad Max game. But it just is boring.  The graphics in the game are superb and the animation quality is even better. The story gave me no motivation and didnt really make me care for the characters-even though the voice acting was very good- this was partly why i didnt finish the game.  The gameplay here is where it really falls apart though. Car combat is fun and dynamic but they dont spend enough time utilising it. It eventually gets a bit boring when you are trying to get from point a to point be and enemies contantly spawn interupting your journey forcing you to fight them. It makes the car combat feel like a chore. The ground combat though is much worse. It is the free flow combat from the Batman Arkham series but not done as well. It starts off fun but NEVER evolves and you will eventuall be spamming the same 2 buttons over and over again without having to ever change your style, beside a few times when they throw a diffrent enemy type. In the game there are only three enemy types. There is little mission variety and you will end up feeling like you have done the exact thing already. Not too mention being forced to collect scrap which often takes too long and just forces you to extend you playtime.  I really had high hopes for the game but due to a mediocre story, repitive gameplay and mission design it ends up falling flat on its face. It lays really solid groundwork for a possible sequel which could be very good, but for now rather use your 60$ to buy a game like the Witcher 3 or Metal Gear Solid V that really have amazing gameplay and story. I suggest you get this game when it costs something like 20$, because right now it really isnt worth 60$.  5/10

Switched my review to a negative.  After over 20 hrs I'm pretty much sick of MM. You do the same old boring scrap grinding from zone to zone. Here's the gameplay: -Go to an outpost. -Meet the leader. -Do something for the leader. -Find all the parts for the scrap crew (they harvest scrap while you're offline) -Take over all the camps in that part of the district. -Go to the next outpost with a leader and rinse and repeat.  The gameplay and narrative is sooo uninspired and drab. There isn't much of a story and the gameplay leaves alot to be desired. For one, the ground combat is buttom spam. The car combat has bad controls at times until you fully upgrade the Magnum Opus. Then it becomes fun. Until then, farm scrap by taking over every camp in the game.   Taking over camps is a contest in tedium. Each one is practically the same. Kill all the guys in each camp, or torch their oil well (which doesn't make sense, since you would want the oil for yourself) and then your cronies come on in and take it over, giving you scrap over time.   The controls are so floaty while you're Max. Dropping down a ladder or just falling down entirely makes you feel like you're on the Moon. They made the run button right trigger. Everything just feels awkward. You can't customize Max's look all that much. I just have several minor gripes that take away from the expeirence.  Mad Max's plot should've been this: You are trying to create your own outpost for yourself and those you trust. To do that, you have to take out all the corresponding tribes in the area. You also need parts to upgrade your outpost to withstand attacks. From time to time, you get attacked by rival factions and have to drive to your base to defend it. You can set up defenses as a mini game in case you arent there and your cronies can defend it. That would've made more sense and been alot more enjoyable then just driving from zone to zone doing the same ♥♥♥♥ as before.

This game has so much potential, but Avalanche chose to reuse their 'if you can't dazzle them with gameplay, bore them with tedium' formula which made Just Cause 1 & 2 lackluster.  I imagine the dev conversation went something like this...  RAD = Radical Avalanche Developer SAD = Standard Avalanche Developer  RAD - Let's have him hijack vehicles to collect them, drive back to his shop to get upgrades off them and scrap for parts, and he'd have several frames to upgrade and use. Because in real life car thieves steal cars and take them to chop shops for parts and scrap.  SAD - Nah, let's bore the player by making them wander around for hours collecting paltry bits of garbage we hide everywhere which is used to to upgrade one single vehicle, there by removing the entertainment of hunting down vehicles.  RAD - Let's make them configure their car at a garage, so they have to strategically choose how to load it out, since they'll be stuck with it like that until they get back to base.  SAD - Nah, let's just let them insta-alter their vehicle on-the-fly, even in the middle of the desert while doing 80mph. People like convenience, so let's let them rip all the weight off their car instantly to make it go faster, then load it all back on to protect themselves right before they hit an enemy.  RAD - So you're gonna bore people to death by making them collect tons of garbage to upgrade the vehicle, but they can insta-swap parts while drifving... on the one extreme it's super inconvenient, and on the other it's illogically over-convenient.  SAD - Yeah, we like to throw logic out the door here.... whatever we can do to annoy players by either frustrating them with tedium or trashing all logic ... that's what we do.  RAD - Let's give Max a dog and mechanic companion, and he can have both ride with him in any vehicle he takes. Reviewing Mad Max is a mixed bag for me. I'm a fan of the franchise and have watched and enjoyed all four movies. I had already seen the mixed reviews ranging anywhere from 60% upto 85%, and the Very Positive rating by gamers on Steam. Had a voucher for GMG so used it and got Mad Max for a bragain, so if the game turned out to be mediocre I wasn't exactly losing much.  Truthfully, having now finished the game (with only a few locations left to loot), I did enjoy my time in Mad Max, but this comes with some cavaets. Firstly, I'll start with the pros.  Pros: Environment - The game is generally beautiful... for a post-apocalyptic wasteland. The crafting of the desolation, particularly the ocean floor is in my opinion stunning. Strangely, the working of the overly saturated pallet actually adds to the atmosphere instead of detracts and the place really feels like a world gone awry. Not much more I can say about the environment, it's just done really well. The first visit to Buzzard underground areas (i.e. the Underdome) was very nice indeed.  Driving - The driving, though extremely simplistic, is really allot of fun. The is one exception, but I'll cover that in the cons. Otherwise, whether cruising through the wasteland, or battling Road Kill, Scrotus minions or Buzzards, the handling of the vehicles just feels right. The sense of speed when hitting the higher gears is nice, espeacially after some of the later stage Magnus Opus upgrades. Using the various weapons, particularly in the wide open spaces, is simple and doesn't generally cause issues.  Fighting - I've read a few reviews where the reviewers bagged the melee combat with negative comparisons to the Batman series. I think this is a little unfair. Having played the majority of the Batman series I think Madmax's holds up pretty well on its own and feels allot more viceral than any of the Batman games. The moves are obviously less flashy (being Mad Max vs. Batman), and the game is actually less forgiving than Batman (Batman is allot more forgiving for poorly timed counters and combos), but if you pay attention to your opponents, and don't always try for the heavy hits you can chain together some very cool combat sequences... espeacially when Max's rage bar fills up and you go berzerk.  Base assaults - Probably my favourite part of the *repetitive* missions. Actually really enjoyed attacking the various bases. Prep work while driving (destroying defenses etc...), exploration and plenty of melee combat. Nearly all of the bases were hand crafted, can't really remember any carbon copies, so was interesting exploring the various bases.  Cons: Repetition - Three primary game zone hubs (3 1/2 if you include the Gas Town zone), and three sets of identical missions. The base assaults I enjoyed, but tearing down the scarecrows and sniper posts, and hunting mindfields in 3 zones was actually fairly boring. Also, the loot locations became rather boring as well. In the last zone I ended up only hunting out historic relics and base project parts. The repetition wasn't a massive detractor, but was still annoying.  Driving - Now I have this as a Pro, but there is one particular point where this is really really bad. The Big Chief race is seriously ♥♥♥♥ing annoying. What worked out in the open areas, causes nightmares in the tight confines of the Big Chief race. Partially hampered by exagerated vehicle physics which cause you to ricochet at crazy car-stopping angles off smooth walls, the real problem is the cinematic camera. If you have to target a vehicle to the side or behind, the camera stays locked on the vehicle as it's destroyed which prevents you seeing where your car is heading. Not so bad in the wide open wasteland, but in tight windy corridors it's a nightmare.  Griffa - The RPG elements are just odd, and really game breaking. I actually enjoy the conversations Max has with Griffa, but there isn't any decision to make in the point allocation. You will max everything pretty easily, so what is the point? Also, once maxed the game becomes just too easy, which is saying something when the game kinda starts out easy to begin with. The game needs hard and nightmare difficulties. Any seasoned player is going to find the game pretty casual, and if they make the mistake like I did and spend the Griffa points the game becomes Hello Kitty's Desert Fun Race.  Story/Character Development - Spoiler warning, so read with caution.   This is perhaps the worst part of the game for me. Not just have they rehashed the revenge story from the original Mad Max, they've turn Max into a completely unredeeming murderer. With how well Mel Gibson played the fracturing pysche in Thunderdome, and Tom Hardy's understated almost-mute protagonist, how could they get it so wrong in the game?   In the last three Mad Max's, Max has always shown a hint at a redeemable character. In Mad Max the game he simply a psychopath. Narcissitic, emotionless, and cruel. He is entirely at fault in the deaths of the two female characters, and in his misguided revenge spree he murders the only character that has help him. Then, just drives off. Baffling.    With that list of pros/cons, do I still think the game is worth playing? Sure, if it's cheap enough. Don't grab this at full price, it really isn't worth the price of admission. But if you get it for a bargain like I did, then it's worth a few hours, particularly for the environment, the driving and the base assaults.

No 2nd-half-of-the-game-as-DLC? Great. Aesthetics and Environments that support Immersion? Wonderful. In-depth Dialogue and flow of the story. Incredible.  Really, there was a huge amount of work put into this game. You can see it in the way that the landscape has tell-tale icons and signifiers of an old world. You can see it in the carefully-crafted expressions and dialogue between characters (  and ol' Dinky Di  ). The gameplay concept is deceptively simple, and it all works together to draw you in.  Apart from a few annoyances, I would have given this game a 10/10. I'm a reasonable critic, and as such, I would give this game:  A solid 6. The aesthetics and the storyline carried over half the weight. Flawlessly.  As I see it, a 6 is generous, a ****ing 7 would be asking the world of me for the following reasons:  Mad Max uses the same progress-limiting tactics as the newer RPGs (see Dragon Age: Inquisition, Witcher III, etc.), where you are in an open world, but you don't have access to it until you complete enough filler quests to 'buff up' your neighborhood stronghold. While I understand that company big-hats (looking at you, Warner Bros.) want their games to have big numbers and get big ratings, this mechanic becomes anti-fun if it yields no actual  gameplay reward . In other words, this mechanic detracts from the immersion of Mad Max and prevents progression from feeling rewarding to players.  All of the big battles and the little battles are  the exact same difficulty . I don't expect the game to twiddle my   Scrotus   and give me a   Rim Jobbie  , but even the bosses and sub-bosses dealt so little damage and used such insultingly simple tactics that    the hardest part of Mad Max happened mid-way through the game, when players had to break through The Jaw  . Why even use a difficulty gauge on various locations when you can mow through the hardest areas just by performing the same block/punch/parry combo for a slightly longer amount of time? Why even bother   making a last fight with Scrotus seem like a big deal when it's so obvious that the original concept was deemed 'too hard' and dumbed down to an idiot child's level? Chumbucket even tells you how to ****ing kill him, it's insulting.    I know that I black-boxed a ton of that text, so I would like to recompose myself and reiterate: A good game  rewards  players for time and effort spent in a game. While Mad Max rewards players for time -- and it does so excellently --  the reward for effort is almost nonexistent .   To who this may concern, If I spend the twenty or so minutes that it takes to defeat a Top Dog, do me the favor of  actually making the in-game notification address him by name . Hell, go ahead and  give him a unique character model while you're at it . You already gave him a name and a background bio. If you knew this game was rated Mature from the get-go, please do not try to set the standard difficulty to toddler-level and rewarding the players accordingly.  Sincerely, Jeddest Min'Add  P.S. Please go ahead and correct the other in-game notifications containing immersion-detracting text. Your tech team and your design team worked too hard for Mad Max to be the absolute ****ing disappointment that it is.

Mad Controls, Grind Max  There's a lot of stuff to love about this game and I'd like to do just that, but the things I don't like pretty much ruin the game for me.  Unskippable animated logos of WB Interactive & Avalanche Studios. It's just a few seconds, but it still annoys me.  The controls (keyboard & mouse, but I guess it's the same with a controller) are just wrong. Few examples:  * There is one general action key (E) used pretty much for everything. It picks up a weapon when you are unarmed. It drops weapon when Max is armed. This key is also used for climbing up ladders and also for various executions of stunned enemies. All too often you just accidentaly drop weapon instead of climbing up a ladder or (which is much worse) you just drop the weapon in the middle of the combat when trying to execute an enemy. This key is also used for all possible executions, where some cost you a shiv and some do not. Sometimes enemy is on the ground, making it possible to perform some kind of execution which does not cost a shiv. At the same moment when you press the E key, this enemy stands up and the execution mode is changed to 'kill with shiv' and this costs you that shiv. * Similar problem is with the F key when holding a gas canister. Normally this key lights up the canister so that it can be used to blow something up. But when you're standing behind a car, the same key is used to refuel the car from the canister. So when trying to refuel, it is not that uncommon to accidentaly light the canister on fire. * The right mouse button is used both for aiming the shotgun and for countering enemy attacks. Sometimes you can see enemy approaching you and you start to counter a little bit prematurely which ends in Max drawing the shotgun and thus being unable to counter the attack and dropping any melee weapon he was holding. * The game hints when you can counter an attack or perform an execution. The problem is that apparently all these actions have some max range (you can't execute an enemy at the other side of the room) and the game does not take that into account when hinting a possible action. So all too often you press E for 'melee weapon execution' just to drop the weapon because Max is not in range. The same is with countering enemy attacks which started out of range, which result again in drawing the shotgun and dropping any equiped melee weapon. * Problem with hints is that if in combat you have two stunned enemies and one on the ground, you have on screen three hints which all say that by pressing E, you will do this action. At these moments I'm really confused as to what action exactly will pressing the E perform. Most often in these situations I'm happy with just dispatching any of the hinted enemies, but end up just dropping equiped weapon instead. * The controls sometimes feel bit unresponsive and there is no reaction from the game when I'm trying to perform an execution or block enemy attack.  Advanced car components have various requirements, where some of them are tied to grinding. I'm completely fine with the approach where to get the best engine, you have to completely clear some part of map of enemies and then get the engine as a bonus reward (just an example, not actually in game). There are similar requirements for some of the components. The problem is that some of these are not optional and you need these grind-earned components for some of the main story missions. I have my moments where I like just to roam the map and destroy enemy buildings / capture bases and there are other times where I'd like to advance the story. I don't like being forced to 'destroy N enemy structures' to lower threat, earn another component and thus be able to advance the story.  You can raid various small settlements for scrap (used as a currency for upgrades), but it's not really worth it. Raiding any settlement takes at least few minutes (defeat enemies, explore the settlement and find all the scrap lying around) and you get few tens units of scrap. Low tier components cost 100-200 scrap, mid tier around 900 and the best even more. So it's not really worth it to try to get the scrap for upgrades by raiding these settlements. You get much more scrap by capturing enemy bases. These are then occupied by allies who give you some scrap on regular basis. So the best way is to actually capture few bases and then let the game running in AFK mode, to get the scrap needed for upgrades.  At times the game fails to explain some (possibly important) concepts:  * In strongholds, you can build stockpile by giving up large amounts of scrap. The game says that building the stockpile helps the stronghold grow. OK, but it is never mentioned what are the benefits of stronghold growth (other than more people showing up in the stronghold when visiting it). * You can break enemy limbs by performing a 'perfect parry'. Unfortunately it is not mentioned what that is. Judging from the Arkham series experience I guess it would be hitting the 'block' button at the exact moment when enemy blow lands, but so far it just feels pretty random.  In combat you can break enemy limbs and bury knives deep into their eyes. The problem is that the enemy is then completely happy to punch you with the broken hand or attack you again with no regard to the knife in the eye (which also magically disappears).  Upgrading stronholds is bit unnecessarily time consuming. To build an upgrade you first need to find it's components scattered in the wastes and I'm completely fine with that. But to actually build that upgrade, you then have to go to the stronghold and find the empty spot where this upgrade is supposed to be built and then build it there. It would be much better just to arrive to the stronghold and build it without having to go anywhere else, or have it auto-build just by visiting the strongold.  Apart from the very poor controls (car control seems OK) and story-required grinding, the game itself is not that bad. For me it's not worth the full price and I regret buying it now. For lower price or with at least the controls fixed I could recommend it.

If it weren't for the movie backing this game, it'd be pretty generic. When you have 9+ large areas to canvas, it becomes tedious, especially trying to collect all the upgrades for the different strongholds in the land. There isn't a lot of difficulty thus far either, and with how quickly you gain upgrades I can't imagine it'll get much harder as time goes on. There's really no sense of urgency or death looming above you as it's easy to keep your tank filled, health high, and ammo stocked.  Either way if you're a fan of the movie you'll probably like this game, but I wasn't a fan of the movie yet I wanted to give the game a chance. Maybe it can at least hold me over until the other wasteland game comes out in November.  Other notes... People seem to be confusing 'well optimized' with 'not very demanding.' This game doesn't have spectacular graphics, at least compared to Arkham Knight which everyone else seems to also be comparing it to. It's also clearly made for consoles, the keyboard/mouse controls are pretty bad. The menus are clunky, space-bar is dodge by default rather than jump, and for some reason I have to hit Q to exit most menus instead of Escape. You can only jump about three inches high and countering during combat has the same Arkham Asylum 'works when it wants to' feel. I've been in battles where I completely perfectly demolish everybody, and that's after I died in the exact same battle where I got completely demolished by everybody. Use an Xbox controller if you have one.

Although I mildly enjoy this game and will probably finish the main storyline, I cannot recommend this game.  So the polish is there, the game runs great, the graphicaly is nice.  The game dumps you right into action.... and the driving model is awkward... I guess this is expected. The 'cars' are make-shift conglomerations of scrap parts with V8 in them.  Then we go to combat, it's the exactly same system which was in Batmans and SoM. Sadly the upgrade paths of the fight system aren't as interesting in the former games using this system.  And then we get to the open world parts, and this is the major disappointment.   Sure, the world is dry, desolate and barren as expected. There are some wreckeges which you can scavenge for couple of scrap pieces, and sometimes an 'old-world relic' which is issually a picture of a kid and a dog.  Issue here is that the scrap ammount obtained from these is really low, almost to the point, that it doesn't make sense to scavenge.  There are ubisoftian towers in form of balloons. Issually they are guarded by a terrain traversal puzzle. When you get to the balloon you need to wait til you get high enough then to manually observe the surrounding. Which is nice, but it is quickly becoming a choir.  Other thing I highly dislike are arbitral restrictions on stuf, especially harpoon and upgrades.  I'm getting stoked with my harpoon, tearing down scarecrows and suddenly - (Level X Required). Man, I've just got a special talon thingy to tear down the hinges of the jaw and still can't rip out wheels from random buggies?  Ok, I want to upgrade the harpoon. Oh wait, I need to reduce the threat level on a territory I just left. I need to go back do more more choirs for to gain access to stuff.  You know what game did the exact same thing? Watch Dogs.  Mad Max is Watch Dogs, but with a big of fun, and lots of choir... and sand storms.

Mad Max Review.  All in all, I can\'t complain much about this game.   It is like a blend of Tomb Raider (for the 3rd person perspective), Far Cry (the exploration, game mechanics, and towers to increase your field of vision on the map) and the Batman Arkham Series (for the combat system). When you are not progressing the story, you can participate in optional events, such as racing, random encounters, and exploring, just to name a few. These get really repetitive. The vehicular combat, in my opinion, can be heavily improved upon. You drive fast, hit a car, shoot it. Rinse, and repeat. The enemy cars seem incredibly overpowered, and there is a steep increase in difficulty from the beginning of the game to just after the tutotial.   7/10, wait for a sale.

+ graphic and style of the game is fitting to the Mad Max universe + story is mostly good and the characters are as well - ending is anticlimatic as it is completly forced on you not giving you any chance to intervene at any point. You are basically just looking, never get a chance to fully fight Scrotum, and in the end it all just feels very unsatisfying as the last part is full scripted and cinematics. - The story is absolutely linear, no alternate endings, no way to influence anything at all ever -- you may have spent much time and effort ugprading those strongholds and what it does in the end for you is really absolutely 0, nothing, worthless. Games are supposed to give you choice, but this one has none. Whenever you would normally use your unlocked abilities to intervene in what is happening, the main storyline will force some illogical other route of happenings on you if you want it or not. You could as well watch a movie instead of this, in a movie you would also likely not be confronted with the same fights and same bosses over a timespan of multiple hours. -- full of repetitive chores (defusing entire mine fields seriously?) and grinding if you want to upgrade anything to a meaningful degree - full of unskippable, boring cutscenes during simple actions, at least these can be skipped if upgrading max at Griffa - Boss fights are always exactly following the same pattern to defeat the boss, almost all bosses are just reskins - Melee fights make up a large chunk of the game and get boring really fast, you just click two buttons in the right moments repeatedly + Driving and causing havok with your car is fun but... - ...mostly you will destroy other cars by shooting at them instead of ramming them etc., since that is often the fastest and only practical way - Voice acting for Max is ridiculously bad at many many times. At many points it sounded to me like an uninterested body-builder, who is at the very end of the autism spectrum, is voice acting for him. That's also why I never could immerse myself into Max. It is very different from the original Mad Max movies (old ones).  Summary: Overall good, but too much grinding, repetitive fighting, focus on melee, and fully linear story in a relatively open world
